(e) TEM-EDS image of ppLTO taken after 20 cycles.</p></div></figcaption><div class="figure-bottom-links"><div class="download-hi-res-img"><a title="High Resolution Image" href="/cms/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/asset/images/large/ja4c06823_0001.jpeg"><span>High Resolution Image</span></a></div><div class="download-ppt"><a title="Download MS PowerPoint Slide" href="/action/downloadFigures?doi=10.1021/jacs.4c06823&amp;id=fig1"><span>Download MS PowerPoint Slide</span></a></div></div></figure><div class="NLM_p">Previous studies in our group showed the deleterious effect of carbon black additives, commonly employed to increase the electronic conductivity of the film, on ssNMR sensitivity enhancement via DNP. This was attributed to the absorbance of microwave irradiation by the carbon, resulting in sample heating. <a onclick="showRef(event, 'ref82'); return false;" href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref82" aria-label="reference 82">(82)</a> In the case of LTO as a LIB anode, we have shown that good electrochemical performance can still be achieved in carbon-free electrodes by calendaring the films. This formulation enabled significant DNP enhancements in carbon-free LTO following electrochemical cycling. <a onclick="showRef(event, 'ref83'); return false;" href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref83" aria-label="reference 83">(83)</a> Here, we opted to use ppLTO as electrode without both the carbon black and the PVDF binder so that the formed SEI could be entirely attributed to electrolyte reduction processes at the surface of LTO. To test our ppLTO electrode formulation, we compared the electrochemical performance of ppLTO and conventional film electrodes (mixed with carbon black C-45 and PVDF), with results shown in <a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig1" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 1</a>b. Overall, at the moderate rate of C/10 used here, the voltage profiles are quite similar for both formulations. However, the film-based cells show slightly better capacity retention, as well as improved rate performance (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig1" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 1</a>c), particularly at high current densities. This is most likely due to the improved electronic conductivity from carbon black and better physical contacts of LTO particles provided by the PVDF binder. Nevertheless, our results suggest that, for SEI studies at C/10, the ppLTO electrodes are comparable to conventional film electrodes with the advantage of enabling high sensitivity ssNMR characterization by leveraging DNP. We note that, in contrast to LTO used in LIB cells, SIB cells are much more sensitive to the LTO morphology. A comparison of the electrochemical performance of different LTO samples in LIB and SIB is provided in the Supporting Information (<a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/suppl_file/ja4c06823_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S2a</a>), indicating the superiority of the hydrothermal route for LTO, most likely due to the high surface to volume ratio obtained through this route. <a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig1" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 1</a>d depicts an SEM image obtained on a ppLTO electrode sample after 3 cycles, which shows no significant difference from the pristine LTO electrode (<a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/suppl_file/ja4c06823_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S1b</a>). However, TEM-EDS map obtained on an LTO sample after 20 cycles exhibits a distinct Na-rich surface layer (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig1" id="" class=" internalNav">Figures 1</a>e and <a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/suppl_file/ja4c06823_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">S3</a>), which is likely a Na-containing SEI. This is expected based on the significant irreversible capacity loss observed on the first cycle.<named-content content-type="anchor" rid="fig1" type="simple"></named-content></div><div class="NLM_p last">Next, we wanted to examine the effect of an electrolyte additive on the electrochemical performance. Due to its reported positive effect on SEI properties, <a onclick="showRef(event, 'ref57 ref84'); return false;" href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref57 ref84" aria-label="reference 57 and 84">(57,84)</a> 2% FEC was added to the electrolyte solution. It is well accepted that FEC acts as a sacrificial additive, as its lowest unoccupied molecular orbital is higher than that of the electrolyte, which leads to FEC decomposition before other electrolyte constituents. <a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig1" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 1</a>f shows the voltage profile of ppLTO with 2% FEC, exhibiting a high irreversible capacity during the first cycle. Furthermore, the addition of FEC also results in differences in the first cycle voltage profile, as evidenced by an obvious slope between in the 1.2–0.7 V range. This new slope in the voltage profile is in agreement with the sacrificial nature of FEC. Dis/charge curves in subsequent cycles are similar to those obtained with the 0% FEC electrolyte formulation, although with significantly reduced capacity. Surprisingly, in the case of LTO, it is clear that adding 2% FEC has a detrimental effect on the performance. As seen in <a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/suppl_file/ja4c06823_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S2b</a>, the capacity after 20 cycles for ppLTO cells with 2% FEC drops to approximately 50 mA h/g, in contrast to that obtained for cells with 0% FEC, around 140 mA h/g. <a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig1" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 1</a>c shows the results from a rate performance test on LTO/Na cells with 0% and 2% FEC, revealing that the addition of 2% FEC causes a severe decrease in the rate performance of the ppLTO electrodes. To verify that these results are not due to the electrode formulation, we performed similar rate performance tests on half cells comprising conventional LTO film electrodes. While overall achieving better performance, the LTO films show a similar trend (<a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/suppl_file/ja4c06823_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S2c</a>), although the difference between 0 and 2% FEC containing electrolyte is milder. As expected, the addition of FEC in the electrolyte results in a high irreversible capacity on the first cycle, suggesting that FEC is reduced to form a different SEI, and the FEC is fully decomposed by the end of the first cycle shown in <a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig1" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 1</a>f. Thus, we speculate that the main difference between the two electrochemical systems is the SEI composition and its properties, as will be discussed in the following sections.</div></div><div id="sec3_2" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_2"><div id="ac_i16" class="anchor-spacer"></div><h3 class="article-section__title" id="_i16">3.2.  SEI Composition</h3><div class="NLM_p">Multinuclear NMR was used to gain information on the composition of the native SEI formed on ppLTO electrodes during cycling. The <sup>23</sup>Na NMR spectrum of LTO in the discharged state after 8 cycles with 0% FEC, shown in <a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig2" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 2</a>a, reveals three main <sup>23</sup>Na environments. To assign the different <sup>23</sup>Na resonances, CP experiments were performed as they result in polarization transfer between nuclei that are in close spatial proximity. <sup>19</sup>F to <sup>23</sup>Na CP indicates that the resonance at 6 ppm corresponds to a Na environment with nearby F, while <sup>1</sup>H to <sup>23</sup>Na CP shows that the broad resonance at −10 ppm corresponds to protonated phases. Additional <sup>23</sup>Na NMR measurements of various reference Na salts are provided in the SI (<a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/suppl_file/ja4c06823_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S4</a>). These spectra further support the assignment of the 6 ppm <sup>23</sup>Na resonance to NaF, while the resonance at −10 ppm most likely arises from an organic Na salt (NaOH, which would also give rise to a signal in the <sup>1</sup>H–<sup>23</sup>Na CP spectrum, has a different <sup>23</sup>Na resonance frequency and line shape). An additional broad <sup>23</sup>Na resonance is detected at 20 ppm, which corresponds to a Na environment with no fluorine or hydrogen and is not observed in any of the measured salts. We assign this resonance to residual Na  within the LTO framework (labeled as Na<sub><i>x</i></sub>LTO). This assignment is discussed in more detail at the end of this section.</div><figure id="fig2" data-index="3" class="article__inlineFigure"><h2 class="fig-label">Figure 2</h2><button class="figure-viewer__trigger" aria-label="open figure viewer"><img src="/cms/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/asset/images/medium/ja4c06823_0002.gif" alt="" data-lg-src="/cms/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/asset/images/large/ja4c06823_0002.jpeg" id="gr2" class="inline-fig internalNav"></button><figcaption><div class="hlFld-FigureCaption caption"><p class="first last">Figure 2. (a) <sup>23</sup>Na MAS NMR spectrum collected on LTO in the discharged state after 8 cycles with a recycle delay of 2.5 and 256 scans, along with <sup>19</sup>F–<sup>23</sup>Na and <sup>1</sup>H–<sup>23</sup>Na CP experiments obtained with a recycle delay, number of scans and contact time of 5.2 s, 3020, 0.25 ms and 2.5 s, 20,480, 1 ms, respectively. (b) <sup>23</sup>Na MAS NMR spectrum of LTO after 1 cycle with 0 and 2% FEC using recycle delay and number of scans 4, 1024 and 7.5 s, 1024 for the 0 and 2% FEC samples, respectively. (c) <sup>19</sup>F spectrum of LTO after 1 cycle with 0 and 2% FEC acquired using rotor synchronized Hahn echo with recycle delay of 225 s, 48 scans and 93 s, 128 scans, respectively. (d) <sup>19</sup>F{<sup>7</sup>Li} REDOR dephasing curve for LTO after 1 cycle with 2% FEC. The REDOR experiment was performed with a recycle delay of 20 s and 48 scans. The inset shows the deconvolution of the spectrum. (e) <sup>19</sup>F RFDR 2D experiment acquired with 10 ms mixing time, 180 increments, a recycle delay of 19 and 16 scans of LTO after 1 cycle with 2% FEC. (f) <sup>23</sup>Na{<sup>19</sup>F} REDOR experiment for LTO after 3 cycles with 2% FEC. Recycle delay and number of scans were 5 s, 1664 scans, respectively. All experiments were performed at room temperature and sample spinning at 25 kHz.</p></div></figcaption><div class="figure-bottom-links"><div class="download-hi-res-img"><a title="High Resolution Image" href="/cms/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/asset/images/large/ja4c06823_0002.jpeg"><span>High Resolution Image</span></a></div><div class="download-ppt"><a title="Download MS PowerPoint Slide" href="/action/downloadFigures?doi=10.1021/jacs.4c06823&amp;id=fig2"><span>Download MS PowerPoint Slide</span></a></div></div></figure><div class="NLM_p">A comparison of the <sup>23</sup>Na and <sup>19</sup>F NMR spectra collected on ppLTO cycled with 0 and 2% FEC (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig2" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 2</a>b,c) shows substantial differences in the SEI composition in these two systems. Adding 2% FEC induces the formation of a considerable amount of NaF, as seen in both the <sup>23</sup>Na and <sup>19</sup>F spectra. Moreover, addition of FEC leads to the appearance of an additional resonance between −2 and −4 ppm. This environment was assigned to sodium bicarbonate, NaHCO<sub>3</sub>, based on its <sup>23</sup>Na resonance frequency <a onclick="showRef(event, 'ref85'); return false;" href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref85" aria-label="reference 85">(85)</a> and correlation experiments that will be discussed in the following sections. The formation of LiF, as observed in the <sup>19</sup>F spectrum in <a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig2" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 2</a>c, is not affected by the addition of FEC. Note that the difference in the NaF signal intensity in the spectra obtained on the two 0% FEC samples shown in <a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig2" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 2</a>a,b stems from the difference in the number of cycles after which the samples were harvested (8 cycles vs 1 cycle, respectively), consistent with the fact that more NaF forms upon extended cycling. We note these experiments were performed on LTO that undergone varying number of cycles due to the low-efficiency of <sup>1</sup>H/<sup>19</sup>F–<sup>23</sup>Na CP experiments. CP experiments were feasible on LTO following multiple cycles with thicker SEI that contained overall similar chemical composition to that after 1 cycle.</div><div class="NLM_p">Insight into the formation of different fluoride phases upon addition of 2% FEC, and their distribution within the SEI, can be gained through correlation experiments. Here, we performed two experiments which provide insight into the spatial proximity between fluoride phases. Namely, <sup>19</sup>F{<sup>7</sup>Li} and <sup>23</sup>Na{<sup>19</sup>F} REDOR experiments. Briefly, in an X{Y} REDOR experiment the spectrum of nucleus X is detected following varying number of pulses that are applied on nucleus Y. These pulses lead to decreased signal intensity for nucleus X if it is a few Angstroms away from nucleus Y. The extent of signal loss (so-called dephasing) is then plotted as a function of time, normalized by a reference signal collected with no Y pulses. Such a curve provides qualitative information into the proximity between the chemical environment of X and Y. As the SEI structure is very heterogeneous (and phases are composed of multispin systems) we cannot extract quantitative distance information by fitting the data. Nevertheless, based on previous reports for similar nuclei we expect that a REDOR effect observed in <sup>19</sup>F{<sup>7</sup>Li} and <sup>23</sup>Na{<sup>19</sup>F} experiments would indicate nuclear proximity below ∼1 nm. <a onclick="showRef(event, 'ref86'); return false;" href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref86" aria-label="reference 86">(86)</a> Furthermore, we performed a <sup>19</sup>F radio frequency driven recoupling (RFDR) homonuclear correlation experiment. In this two-dimensional experiment, the distance dependent dipolar interaction between <sup>19</sup>F nuclei is used to identify <sup>19</sup>F containing chemical environments that are less than ∼2 nm apart. <a onclick="showRef(event, 'ref86'); return false;" href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref86" aria-label="reference 86">(86)</a> Such distance results in formation of spectral correlations (in form of cross-peaks) between the different resonances. <a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig2" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 2</a>d shows the normalized integral difference of the nondephased (S<sub>0</sub>) and dephased (S) <sup>19</sup>F{<sup>7</sup>Li} REDOR. The LiF resonance is quickly dephased, as expected since fluorine and lithium are less than 2 Å apart in this phase. The NaF <sup>19</sup>F resonance slowly dephases, indicating some proximity to <sup>7</sup>Li environments. An additional broad <sup>19</sup>F signal centered around −215 ppm, and flanked by the NaF and LiF <sup>19</sup>F signals, is detected, and its intensity varies across samples (this resonance is more clearly observed in the inset of <a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig2" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 2</a>d). This −215 ppm environment is assigned to F species at the interface between LiF/NaF phases, as its signal displays rapid and almost full dephasing within 200 μs, suggesting Li–F distances of less than 10 Å (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig2" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 2</a>d). The <sup>19</sup>F RFDR correlation spectrum in <a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig2" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 2</a>e shows strong cross peaks between NaF and the Li/NaF resonances. As correlations are expected from F species within less than 2 nm, this indicates nm scale mixing between these two phases, which could also explain the mild dephasing observed for the NaF resonance in the <sup>19</sup>F{<sup>7</sup>Li} REDOR experiment. Lastly, the <sup>23</sup>Na{<sup>19</sup>F} REDOR spectrum shown in <a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig2" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 2</a>f was performed on ppLTO after 3 cycles with 2% FEC. As expected, the NaF peak dephases most rapidly, followed by the NaHCO<sub>3</sub> resonance and the resonance assigned to organic phases, the latter showing the least, but non-negligible, dephasing. The <sup>23</sup>Na{<sup>19</sup>F} REDOR results imply that the organic phases contain significant amount of fluorine, presumably as a result of FEC decomposition. This mechanism is supported by a comparison of <sup>23</sup>Na{<sup>19</sup>F} REDOR experiments on samples cycled with and without FEC, shown in <a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/suppl_file/ja4c06823_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S5</a>, which reveal a much smaller dephasing of the resonance assigned to organic phases in the absence of FEC.</div><div class="NLM_p">As the organic Na salts cannot be resolved in the <sup>23</sup>Na NMR spectrum, we turned to <sup>13</sup>C detection. The low natural abundance of NMR-active <sup>13</sup>C (only 1%), compounded by its low NMR sensitivity and the small amount of SEI phases in the sample, prevent the detection of any <sup>13</sup>C signal from the samples of interest even with <sup>1</sup>H–<sup>13</sup>C CP. Thus, to enable detection of the organic components of the SEI we employed exogenous DNP. Here, the polarization agents were nitroxide biradicals (TEKPol), which were introduced by gently wetting the LTO powder with a radical solution containing 16 mM of TEKPol in TCE. The sample was then inserted into the DNP probe and kept at 100 K. CW microwave irradiation resulted in polarization transfer from the radicals to nearby protons in the sample, followed by <sup>1</sup>H–<sup>13</sup>C CP, which allowed sensitive detection of the <sup>13</sup>C species in the SEI.</div><div class="NLM_p"><a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig3" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 3</a>a shows the DNP enhanced <sup>1</sup>H–<sup>13</sup>C CP spectra of LTO after one cycle with 0 and 2% FEC. In both samples, a 64-fold signal enhancement was obtained for the <sup>1</sup>H TCE resonance transferred to the <sup>13</sup>C resonances via CP. The spectra were scaled according to the resonance at 74 ppm corresponding to the TCE solvent (truncated to better reveal the resonances corresponding to SEI components), which allows a semiquantitative comparison of the SEI resonances. The resonances at 20–50 ppm are assigned to different alkoxy groups such as CH<sub>3</sub>CH<sub>2</sub>O– or CH<sub>3</sub>O–. <a onclick="showRef(event, 'ref87'); return false;" href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref87" aria-label="reference 87">(87)</a> Such environments are associated with the decomposition of the EC and DEC electrolyte solvents. The width of these resonances is due to a distribution of chemical shifts, implying a mixture of disordered products. The addition of 2% FEC to the electrolyte leads to even more pronounced formation of alkoxy species in the SEI. The signal resonating at 130 ppm is assigned to unsaturated carbon species and is attributed to DEC/EC decomposition products; its formation does not seem to be affected by the addition of 2% FEC. The <sup>13</sup>C resonances at 160–170 ppm belong to carbonate groups such as Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> and organic carbonate salts (NaCO<sub>3</sub>R) and are strongly affected by FEC addition. This is corroborated by previous reports indicating that FEC induces the formation of both NaF and Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub>. <a onclick="showRef(event, 'ref47 ref57'); return false;" href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref47 ref57" aria-label="reference 47 and 57">(47,57)</a> Additional <sup>13</sup>C resonances at 163 and 180 ppm appear only in the 2% FEC sample. These resonances are assigned to a bicarbonate and a carboxyl group, respectively.</div><figure id="fig3" data-index="4" class="article__inlineFigure"><h2 class="fig-label">Figure 3</h2><button class="figure-viewer__trigger" aria-label="open figure viewer"><img src="/cms/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/asset/images/medium/ja4c06823_0003.gif" alt="" data-lg-src="/cms/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/asset/images/large/ja4c06823_0003.jpeg" id="gr3" class="inline-fig internalNav"></button><figcaption><div class="hlFld-FigureCaption caption"><p class="first last">Figure 3. (a) <sup>1</sup>H–<sup>13</sup>C CP spectra of ppLTO after 1 cycle with 0 and 2% FEC enhanced by exogenous DNP. The spectra were taken using recycle delay, number of scan and contact time of 6 s, 1024, 0.5 ms and 6 s, 984, 2 ms, respectively. 2D heteronuclear correlation (HETCOR) of LTO cycled once with 0 and 2% using CP transfer for correlating (b) <sup>1</sup>H–<sup>23</sup>Na using 5.5 s recycle delay, 4 scans, 2 ms contact time and (c) <sup>1</sup>H–<sup>13</sup>C with recycle delay of 5.5 s and 48 scans, contact time of 0.5 and 2 ms for 0 and 2% FEC, respectively. All spectra were acquired with MAS of 9 kHz.</p></div></figcaption><div class="figure-bottom-links"><div class="download-hi-res-img"><a title="High Resolution Image" href="/cms/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/asset/images/large/ja4c06823_0003.jpeg"><span>High Resolution Image</span></a></div><div class="download-ppt"><a title="Download MS PowerPoint Slide" href="/action/downloadFigures?doi=10.1021/jacs.4c06823&amp;id=fig3"><span>Download MS PowerPoint Slide</span></a></div></div></figure><div class="NLM_p">Additional insight into the organic species found in the SEI could be gained from 2D HETCOR experiments enabled by exogenous DNP. <a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig3" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 3</a>c shows an overlay of the 2D <sup>1</sup>H–<sup>13</sup>C HETCOR DNP spectra obtained on LTO samples after 1 cycle with 0 and 2% FEC. Most of the <sup>13</sup>C resonances are correlated with the <sup>1</sup>H resonance at 6.4 ppm, which belongs to the TCE solvent. This suggests that these organic species are accessible to the TCE solvent, meaning that they are found in the outer layers of the SEI, as will be discussed later. However, in the 2% FEC sample, an additional <sup>1</sup>H resonance is observed at 18 ppm. This 18 ppm <sup>1</sup>H shift is strongly correlated to the FEC degradation products resonating in the 163–170 ppm range in the <sup>13</sup>C dimension, suggesting that it corresponds to an acidic bicarbonate species forming upon FEC decomposition. The <sup>1</sup>H resonance of sodium bicarbonate has previously been reported at 14 ppm, here, it is likely shifted to a higher frequency due to differences in hydrogen bonding within the SEI. <a onclick="showRef(event, 'ref88 ref89'); return false;" href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref88 ref89" aria-label="reference 88 and 89">(88,89)</a> Exogenous DNP was also used to detect the <sup>23</sup>Na species in these phases with the resulting 2D HETCOR spectra shown in <a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig3" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 3</a>b for 0 and 2% FEC. In both 0 and 2% FEC, the <sup>23</sup>Na signal corresponding to the organic phases is enhanced and is correlated with the TCE proton species resonating at 6.4 ppm, indicating that these Na sites are exposed to TCE. In the 2% FEC sample, the <sup>23</sup>Na resonance associated with NaHCO<sub>3</sub> at about −4 ppm is enhanced the most. This resonance is strongly correlated to the <sup>1</sup>H signal at 18 ppm, again suggesting that sodium bicarbonate formation is correlated to FEC decomposition.</div><div class="NLM_p last">Insights from solid-state NMR and exogenous DNP enabled us to gain a compositional map of the native SEI components formed during cycling of LTO, for both organic and inorganic constituents. HETCOR experiments such as REDOR and HETCOR assisted in elucidating the extent of nanoscale-mixing between the different phases of the SEI. It is clear from the results shown above that adding 2% FEC to the electrolyte results in formation of a thicker SEI layer, richer in NaF, as well as containing larger amount of organic species.</div></div><div id="sec3_3" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_2"><div id="ac_i17" class="anchor-spacer"></div><h3 class="article-section__title" id="_i17">3.3.  Irreversible Na–Li Exchange</h3><div class="NLM_p">We now discuss in more detail the origin of the remaining <sup>23</sup>Na resonance at 20 ppm (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig2" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 2</a>a). First, as indicated earlier, this sodium phase does not contain fluorine or hydrogen as it does not appear in the CP spectra (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig2" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 2</a>a). We also found that this 20 ppm resonance is not in proximity to <sup>19</sup>F environments, as it does not display a <sup>23</sup>Na{<sup>19</sup>F} REDOR effect (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig4" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 4</a>a). This result further confirms that the Na<sub><i>x</i></sub>LTO is not mixed with SEI components and is not part of the SEI. Furthermore, a comparison of this resonance frequency to that of other <sup>23</sup>Na-containing reference compounds (<a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/suppl_file/ja4c06823_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S4</a> and literature reports) suggests that this signal originates from an oxidized Na environment that is different from Na<sub>2</sub>O. <a onclick="showRef(event, 'ref85'); return false;" href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref85" aria-label="reference 85">(85)</a> Based on this information, we hypothesize that this resonance corresponds to residual Na ions in the bulk LTO structure at the end of discharge. To test this hypothesis, quantitative <sup>23</sup>Na and <sup>7</sup>Li NMR experiments were performed on LTO at different states of charge (SoC, <a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/suppl_file/ja4c06823_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S6a</a>). In <a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig4" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 4</a>b, the <sup>23</sup>Na spectrum of LTO with 0% FEC after one full cycle (fully desodiated) is compared to that of half cycled LTO (fully sodiated). The spectrum collected on fully sodiated LTO contains peaks at −10 and 4 ppm, assigned to organic species and NaF respectively. An additional broad <sup>23</sup>Na resonance is observed at ca. −40 ppm. As this resonance increases in intensity and shifts toward more negative ppm values with the LTO SoC (<a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/suppl_file/ja4c06823_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S6c–e</a>), it is assigned to Na ions intercalated in the 16c sites. This suggests that the 20 ppm resonance does not correspond to Na intercalated into regular 16c sites. <a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig4" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 4</a>c shows the quantification of the <sup>7</sup>Li and <sup>23</sup>Na NMR resonances as a function of SoC. In theory, the Li content in LTO should stay constant on sodiation. In practice, however, we observe a clear decrease in Li content upon sodiation to approximately 20% of the theoretical capacity. The decrease in <sup>7</sup>Li signal, along with the formation of LiF, can be explained by an ion exchange process between the Na ions and the Li ions in the initial LTO anode. This exchange may involve the Na ions present in the electrolyte and occur after the cell is stopped during <i>ex situ</i> sample preparation, or could be electrochemically driven and result from the replacement of Li ions by Na ions in the 8a/16d sites of the spinel structure during charge. We note that the drop in <sup>7</sup>Li signal intensity is not due to LiF formation (which would contribute to the total Li signal measured) but rather a dissolution process of Li ions into the electrolyte. This is supported by the detection of <sup>7</sup>Li species in solution NMR measurements performed on the electrolyte extracted from a battery cell after cycling (<a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/suppl_file/ja4c06823_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S6f</a>).</div><figure id="fig4" data-index="5" class="article__inlineFigure"><h2 class="fig-label">Figure 4</h2><button class="figure-viewer__trigger" aria-label="open figure viewer"><img src="/cms/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/asset/images/medium/ja4c06823_0004.gif" alt="" data-lg-src="/cms/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/asset/images/large/ja4c06823_0004.jpeg" id="gr4" class="inline-fig internalNav"></button><figcaption><div class="hlFld-FigureCaption caption"><p class="first last">Figure 4. (a) <sup>23</sup>Na{<sup>19</sup>F} REDOR spectra of an LTO anode after 1 cycle, acquired using recycle delay of 20 s, 128 scans and 1 ms recoupling time with (S) and without (S<sub>0</sub>) pulses on <sup>19</sup>F. (b) <sup>23</sup>Na MAS NMR spectra of LTO with 0% FEC after one sodiation and desodiation. The fully desodiated spectrum is the same as in <a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig2" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 2</a>b, whereas the full discharge sample was obtained using a relaxation delay of 0.375 s and 5120 scans. (c) Quantification of the <sup>7</sup>Li and <sup>23</sup>Na NMR signal of LTO anodes cycled at C/10 and extracted from the cell at different SoC, specified by hours (see <a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/suppl_file/ja4c06823_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Supporting Information</a> for NMR spectra). All experiments were performed with 25 kHz MAS.</p></div></figcaption><div class="figure-bottom-links"><div class="download-hi-res-img"><a title="High Resolution Image" href="/cms/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/asset/images/large/ja4c06823_0004.jpeg"><span>High Resolution Image</span></a></div><div class="download-ppt"><a title="Download MS PowerPoint Slide" href="/action/downloadFigures?doi=10.1021/jacs.4c06823&amp;id=fig4"><span>Download MS PowerPoint Slide</span></a></div></div></figure><div class="NLM_p">To facilitate the assignment of the 20 ppm <sup>23</sup>Na resonance, first-principles CASTEP calculations were conducted on various LTO-derived structures, with nominal composition Li<sub>3.5</sub>Na<sub>0.5</sub>Ti<sub>5</sub>O<sub>12</sub> (replacement of 1 Li by Na in a 1 × 2 × 1 supercell of Li<sub>4</sub>Ti<sub>5</sub>O<sub>12</sub>), to determine the chemical shift of <sup>23</sup>Na species after exchanging with Li into the 8a or 16d sites. The computed <sup>23</sup>Na chemical shifts are provided in <a class="ref showTableEvent internalNav" data-id="tbl1" href="#tbl1">Table 1</a> and support the assignment of the 20 ppm resonance to Na in the bulk LTO structure, either in an 8a or a 16d site, which appear to be close in frequency. Further details on the calculation of these NMR parameters including quadrupolar parameters of Na positions in LTO are provided in the methods section and <a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/suppl_file/ja4c06823_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Tables S1 and S2</a>. As Li ions are found to leach out of the electrodes, this suggests that Li–Na ion exchange occurs at the periphery of the LTO anode material particles, at the electrode–electrolyte interface. Whether the formation of a bulk Na<sub><i>x</i></sub>LTO phase is beneficial for the function of LTO as a Na-ion anode is yet to be determined and beyond the scope of this work.</div><div class="NLM_table-wrap" id="tbl1"><div class="hlFld-FigureCaption"><div class="NLM_caption" id=""><div class="title2">Table 1. <sup>23</sup>Na Chemical Shift Computed by DFT for Na/Li Exchanged on 8a and 16d Crystallographic Sites</div></div></div><div class="scrollable-table-wrap"><table class="table "><colgroup><col align="left"><col align="left"></colgroup><thead><tr valign="top" class="colsep0"><th class="colsep0 rowsep0" scope="col" align="center">crystallographic position of Na in LTO</th><th class="colsep0 rowsep0" scope="col" align="center">computed δ (<sup>23</sup>Na) [ppm]</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr valign="top" class="colsep0"><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" scope="row" align="left">8a</td><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" align="left">26.7, 26.8, 26.9, 30.7, 30.8</td></tr><tr valign="top" class="colsep0"><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" scope="row" align="left">16d</td><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" align="left">16.1</td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></div><div id="sec3_4" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_2"><div id="ac_i19" class="anchor-spacer"></div><h3 class="article-section__title" id="_i19">3.4.  SEI Structure</h3><div class="NLM_p">It is well accepted that the SEI composition is not the only factor affecting SEI functionality. The order in which phases form at the electrode surface has a strong impact on ionic transport across the SEI. <a onclick="showRef(event, 'ref8 ref90 ref91'); return false;" href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref8 ref90 ref91" aria-label="reference 8, 90 and 91">(8,90,91)</a> Furthermore, a nonhomogenous deposition of SEI phases results in nonuniform charge transfer through “hot spots” in the SEI. This can lead to fast capacity fading due to blockage of regions of the electrode material and, in the case of low voltage anodes such as Na metal and HC, nonuniform Na deposition and dendrite formation. Thus, in addition to the SEI composition, the SEI architecture has a strong effect on the cell performance.</div><div class="NLM_p">Currently, depth profiling using XPS or mass spectrometry are the most common approaches to gain insight into the SEI structure. <a onclick="showRef(event, 'ref6 ref7'); return false;" href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref6 ref7" aria-label="reference 6 and 7">(6,7)</a> However, both approaches are limited in terms of their chemical resolution and require aggressive sputtering techniques that can alter the composition of the SEI. NMR offers a nondestructive approach with which to probe the SEI. Furthermore, the availability of different sources of polarization for DNP can be used to derive structural insight, as we have demonstrated in the case of thin coatings acting as an artificial SEI. <a onclick="showRef(event, 'ref43'); return false;" href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref43" aria-label="reference 43">(43)</a> We now turn to examine this approach for probing the electrochemically formed SEI on LTO.</div><div id="sec3_4_1" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_3"><div id="ac_i20" class="anchor-spacer"></div><h4 class="article-section__title" id="_i20">3.4.1.  Exogenous DNP</h4><div class="NLM_p">External polarization agents were used in the DNP SENS approach to polarize the SEI by two paths. First, the radicals were used to polarize <sup>1</sup>H nuclei in the sample (in the solvent and SEI) which gave rise to an enhancement factor of 64 (<a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/suppl_file/ja4c06823_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S7a,b</a>) for both 0 and 2% FEC samples. The <sup>1</sup>H spectrum is dominated by the solvent resonance at 6.4 ppm and thus is not very informative on the SEI. The <sup>1</sup>H polarization was transferred to <sup>13</sup>C (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig3" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 3</a>a), revealing the composition of the organic phases in the SEI. <sup>1</sup>H polarization could also be transferred to <sup>23</sup>Na through CP (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig5" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 5</a>a,c), resulting in a significant enhancement factor for the nonresolved <sup>23</sup>Na resonances centered around −10 ppm, which we previously assigned to Na-containing organic species, as discussed in <a class="ref internalNav" href="#sec3_2" aria-label="Section 3.2">Section 3.2</a>. In the 2% FEC sample, the signal at −4 ppm was enhanced as well, even more so than the −10 ppm resonance (<a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/suppl_file/ja4c06823_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Table S3</a>). Thus, as expected, <sup>1</sup>H–<sup>23</sup>Na CP provides an efficient path for highlighting the organic SEI components.</div><figure id="fig5" data-index="6" class="article__inlineFigure"><h2 class="fig-label">Figure 5</h2><button class="figure-viewer__trigger" aria-label="open figure viewer"><img src="/cms/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/asset/images/medium/ja4c06823_0005.gif" alt="" data-lg-src="/cms/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/asset/images/large/ja4c06823_0005.jpeg" id="gr5" class="inline-fig internalNav"></button><figcaption><div class="hlFld-FigureCaption caption"><p class="first last">Figure 5. MW on/off spectra of indirect <sup>1</sup>H–<sup>23</sup>Na CP enhanced by exogenous DNP for LTO after one cycle with (a) 0% FEC and (c) 2% FEC. (a) and (c) were obtained with 6.35 s polarization time, 8 scans and 2 ms contact time. (b,d) are <sup>23</sup>Na direct excitation exogenous DNP comparing MW on/off spectra of LTO after one cycle with 0 and 2% FEC, respectively. (b) Was acquired using a recycle delay 600 s and 8 scans and (d) using a recycle delay 60 s and 16 scans. All experiments were performed at 100 K and MAS of 9 kHz.</p></div></figcaption><div class="figure-bottom-links"><div class="download-hi-res-img"><a title="High Resolution Image" href="/cms/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/asset/images/large/ja4c06823_0005.jpeg"><span>High Resolution Image</span></a></div><div class="download-ppt"><a title="Download MS PowerPoint Slide" href="/action/downloadFigures?doi=10.1021/jacs.4c06823&amp;id=fig5"><span>Download MS PowerPoint Slide</span></a></div></div></figure><div class="NLM_p last">Another route for enhancing resonances in the SEI is to transfer polarization from the radical directly to the <sup>23</sup>Na nuclei at the surface of the LTO particles, as shown in <a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig5" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 5</a>b,d. In this case, DNP did not result in increased signal, and on the contrary the <sup>23</sup>Na resonances decreased in intensity, most likely due to sample heating by the microwaves. Surprisingly, even the organic Na species were not enhanced under these conditions. This can be rationalized considering the very short <sup>23</sup>Na nuclear relaxation time of these species, which was found to be about 100 ms even at 100 K, as determined by a selective T<sub>1</sub> measurement following <sup>1</sup>H–<sup>23</sup>Na CP (<a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/suppl_file/ja4c06823_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S7c</a>). Such short relaxation is likely a limiting factor in direct polarization transfer from the radicals. We note that the <sup>23</sup>Na T<sub>1</sub> of the same resonance measured without CP is of the order of 1 s, suggesting that not all of the organic SEI is enhanced via indirect DNP with <sup>1</sup>H CP. Thus, exogenous DNP provides ssNMR signal enhancement that is limited to the organic phases in the outer layers of the SEI. This effect was similar for LTO samples cycled with and without FEC. In order to probe the inner buried layers of the SEI, endogenous DNP must be employed.</div></div><div id="sec3_4_2" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_3"><div id="ac_i21" class="anchor-spacer"></div><h4 class="article-section__title" id="_i21">3.4.2.  Endogenous DNP</h4><div class="NLM_p">Optimization of Mn(II) dopants for DNP: For endogenous DNP Mn(II) dopants were introduced into the LTO lattice. To this end, Mn(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub> used as the Mn(II) precursor was added to the hydrothermal synthesis route in varying amounts. EPR measurements were performed in order to confirm the Mn(II) doping of the LTO anode material, with spectra acquired on a Q-band spectrometer are shown in <a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig6" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 6</a>a. While the undoped material has no EPR signal, the addition of Mn(II) leads to the appearance of the characteristic six hyperfine transitions of Mn(II) in the EPR spectrum. The increase in signal intensity with Mn(II) concentration clearly indicates successful incorporation of Mn(II) into the LTO anode material.</div><figure id="fig6" data-index="7" class="article__inlineFigure"><h2 class="fig-label">Figure 6</h2><button class="figure-viewer__trigger" aria-label="open figure viewer"><img src="/cms/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/asset/images/medium/ja4c06823_0006.gif" alt="" data-lg-src="/cms/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/asset/images/large/ja4c06823_0006.jpeg" id="gr6" class="inline-fig internalNav"></button><figcaption><div class="hlFld-FigureCaption caption"><p class="first last">Figure 6. (a) CW-EPR spectra of LTO doped with different Mn(II) concentrations measured on a Q-band spectrometer at 298 K. (b) Q-band CW-EPR spectra of Mn(II) doped LTO before and after cycling with 0 and 2% FEC taken at 298 K. Inset: X-band CW-EPR spectra of Mn(II) doped LTO before and after cycling with 0 and 2% FEC acquired at 100 K. (c) Endogenous DNP-NMR enhancement factors of <sup>6</sup>Li and <sup>23</sup>Na of LTO doped with varying amount of Mn(II).</p></div></figcaption><div class="figure-bottom-links"><div class="download-hi-res-img"><a title="High Resolution Image" href="/cms/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/asset/images/large/ja4c06823_0006.jpeg"><span>High Resolution Image</span></a></div><div class="download-ppt"><a title="Download MS PowerPoint Slide" href="/action/downloadFigures?doi=10.1021/jacs.4c06823&amp;id=fig6"><span>Download MS PowerPoint Slide</span></a></div></div></figure><div class="NLM_p">An important consideration when incorporating Mn(II) dopants into battery materials for endogenous DNP is whether they affect and/or are affected by the electrochemical processes in LTO. For example, the oxidation state of the doped Mn(II) metal ions might change during cycling, resulting in their deactivation for DNP, as was observed for Fe(III) in LTO used as a LIB anode. <a onclick="showRef(event, 'ref83'); return false;" href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref83" aria-label="reference 83">(83)</a> EPR measurements of cycled LTO powder were performed to verify that the Mn(II) dopant maintained its oxidation state after cycling. Room temperature spectra acquired at Q-band are shown in <a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig6" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 6</a>b, revealing no significant difference between pristine Mn-doped LTO and samples cycled with 0 and 2% FEC, indicating that the Mn(II) species were not affected by the complex electrochemical processes taking place during cycling. The similarity in signal intensity and line-shape also rules out dissolution of Mn(II) ions to the electrolyte (as is often observed in Mn containing cathode materials <a onclick="showRef(event, 'ref92'); return false;" href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref92" aria-label="reference 92">(92)</a>) or changes in its local environment. However, X-band EPR measurements of cycled LTO acquired at 100 K (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig6" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 6</a>b, inset) reveal a more complex scenario. These spectra are dominated by a large resonance at ca. 340 mT which is assigned to residual Ti(III) paramagnetic centers that form during sodiation of LTO in the battery cell. The dark blue color of LTO after cycling, shown in <a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/suppl_file/ja4c06823_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S8a,b</a> provides another indication for the presence of Ti(III). These Ti(III) species are visible by EPR only at low temperatures due to their fast relaxation which prevents their detection at room temperature. Ideally, the Ti(III) formed upon sodiation should be fully oxidized back to Ti(IV) by the end of the charging step. However, our EPR results suggest that a significant amount of Ti(III) is still present at the end of the cycling process, likely caused by partial irreversibility of Na intercalation and SEI formation. The amount of Ti(III), based on the EPR spectra, correlates well with the poor electrochemical performance observed for the 2% FEC samples, which have larger irreversible capacity compared to 0% FEC samples. Interestingly, as seen in <a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/suppl_file/ja4c06823_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S8c</a>, the Ti(III) EPR signal decreases with time, indicating a self-oxidation mechanism, possibly by spontaneous reduction of the SEI (note that these samples were sealed in capillaries and stored in an argon glovebox between measurements). The self-oxidation mechanism is also evident by a slow change in color of the LTO sample, from dark blue (characteristic for Ti(III)) to white (<a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/suppl_file/ja4c06823_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S8a,b</a>). Importantly, Mn(II) doping did not have an observable effect on the electrochemical performance of LTO. This is likely due to the very small quantities of Mn(II) dopants introduced for DNP (less than 0.5% in stoichiometry). Thus, EPR characterization confirms Mn(II) incorporation within the LTO lattice and its persistent oxidation state following cycling, a fundamental requirement for it acting as a viable polarization agent for DNP. EPR also revealed significant residual Ti(III) in the samples, reflecting the partial reversibility of the LTO sodiation, which may affect the DNP process as will be discussed below.</div><div class="NLM_p">Next, we optimized the concentration of the Mn(II) dopant to maximize signal enhancement. <a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig6" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 6</a>c shows the <sup>6</sup>Li and <sup>23</sup>Na enhancement factors obtained for LTO cycled with 0% FEC as a function of Mn(II) concentration. In comparison with our former study, <a onclick="showRef(event, 'ref83'); return false;" href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref83" aria-label="reference 83">(83)</a> relatively high enhancement factors are achieved for <sup>6</sup>Li after cycling the doped LTO electrodes, with a factor of 50 obtained for a sample doped with 40 mM of Mn(II). This factor corresponds to about 50% of the <sup>6</sup>Li enhancement obtained in pristine LTO, and is impressive considering the complex electrochemical phase transformation occurring in LTO upon (de)sodiation, as well as the significant contribution from residual Ti(III). We were also able to acquire an <sup>17</sup>O spectrum via direct polarization from Mn(II) DNP in cycled LTO samples (<a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/suppl_file/ja4c06823_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S8d</a>), demonstrating the efficacy of Mn(II) dopants in polarizing the bulk of LTO. As in our former study on Mn(II)-doped LTO, <sup>6</sup>Li enhancement increases with decreasing Mn(II) content, seen also in <a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig6" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 6</a>c. <a onclick="showRef(event, 'ref38'); return false;" href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref38" aria-label="reference 38">(38)</a> This trend can be attributed to the increase in Mn(II) interactions with increasing concentration, which leads to faster Mn(II) electron relaxation and thus lower efficiency in DNP. <sup>23</sup>Na enhancement shows a similar trend to <sup>6</sup>Li with higher signal enhancement obtained at the lowest Mn(II) concentration. Further cycling of LTO significantly reduced the <sup>23</sup>Na enhancement factors, as seen in <a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig6" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 6</a>c for samples after 1 and 3 cycles. The reduced <sup>23</sup>Na enhancement after three cycles is most likely due to higher content of Ti(III) that slightly increases after each cycle due to partial irreversibility of the electrochemical process. Subsequent endogenous DNP experiments were performed on LTO samples doped with 20 and 40 mM Mn(II).</div><div class="NLM_p">Surface enhancement through endogenous DNP: MIDNP from Mn(II) dopants was then used to study the inner layers of the SEI. This was performed through direct polarization of <sup>23</sup>Na in LTO samples that went through one electrochemical cycle with an electrolyte with and without FEC additive (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig7" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 7</a>a,b). First, in the samples that did not contain any FEC, we observed significant signal enhancement for all three environments, as shown in <a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig7" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 7</a>a for a sample with 40 mM Mn(II). Interestingly, the resonance at 20 ppm, assigned to Na<sub><i>x</i></sub>LTO, is enhanced the most by a factor of 16–30, followed by NaF and the organic sodium environments have the lowest enhancement in the range 1.5–2 (we note that the enhancement factors slightly varied across different samples but the trends were similar). The NaF enhancement has the highest error due to limited resolution, for the spectra see <a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/suppl_file/ja4c06823_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S9</a>. The high enhancement obtained for Na<sub><i>x</i></sub>LTO supports the assignment of this resonance to sodium environments within the LTO particles. The three phases also display varying relaxation times, which affects the extent of their enhancement as will be discussed below. In most samples cycled with FEC, we did not observe enhancement of the SEI phases (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig7" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 7</a>b). We attribute this to the presence of a significant amount of Ti(III) in these samples (see <a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig6" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 6</a>b, inset). We note, however, that most of these samples showed non-negligible <sup>6</sup>Li signal enhancement in the bulk (<a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/suppl_file/ja4c06823_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S10a,b</a>), suggesting that the residual Ti(III) species are trapped closer to the SEI. However, in one sample cycled with FEC, the SEI environments were enhanced, with similar enhancement factors for different SEI components. This is in contrast to the differential enhancement observed in samples cycled with no FEC (<a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/suppl_file/ja4c06823_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S10c,e</a>). Differences in the enhancement distribution across the SEI with and without FEC could be a result of varying SEI structures, as will be discussed later.</div><figure id="fig7" data-index="8" class="article__inlineFigure"><h2 class="fig-label">Figure 7</h2><button class="figure-viewer__trigger" aria-label="open figure viewer"><img src="/cms/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/asset/images/medium/ja4c06823_0007.gif" alt="" data-lg-src="/cms/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/asset/images/large/ja4c06823_0007.jpeg" id="gr7" class="inline-fig internalNav"></button><figcaption><div class="hlFld-FigureCaption caption"><p class="first last">Figure 7. Endogenous DNP-NMR <sup>23</sup>Na MW on/off spectra for 40 mM Mn(II) doped LTO with (a) 0 and (b) 2% FEC. Experiments were performed with a recycle delay of 1200 and 240 s, respectively, and 4 scans. Inset shows the deconvolution of the MW off spectrum. (c) <sup>23</sup>Na{<sup>7</sup>Li} REDOR dephasing curve acquired for LTO after 1 cycle with 0% FEC and 20 mM Mn(II) doping. The REDOR experiment was enabled by endogenous DNP with a recycle delay of 140 s and 16 scans. All data acquired at 100 K and MAS of 9 kHz.</p></div></figcaption><div class="figure-bottom-links"><div class="download-hi-res-img"><a title="High Resolution Image" href="/cms/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/asset/images/large/ja4c06823_0007.jpeg"><span>High Resolution Image</span></a></div><div class="download-ppt"><a title="Download MS PowerPoint Slide" href="/action/downloadFigures?doi=10.1021/jacs.4c06823&amp;id=fig7"><span>Download MS PowerPoint Slide</span></a></div></div></figure><div class="NLM_p">The sensitivity from Mn(II) DNP is sufficient to perform correlation experiments which can provide further insight into the spatial proximity of the different phases. To this end, <sup>23</sup>Na{<sup>7</sup>Li} REDOR experiments with enhanced sensitivity due to MIDNP were performed to determine the proximity of the different Na phases to the LTO. <a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig7" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 7</a>c shows results from REDOR experiments for LTO sample with 20 mM Mn(II) after 1 cycle with 0% FEC. In this experiment, the <sup>23</sup>Na resonance is dephased due to the effect of dipolar interactions with <sup>7</sup>Li species. In this case, we observe that the Na<sub><i>x</i></sub>LTO resonance at 20 ppm and the NaF resonance both reach the value of 1, while the resonance associated with the organic species at −10 ppm does not. The full dephasing observed for the NaF and Na<sub><i>x</i></sub>LTO Na species suggest that in these environments Na sites are a few Angstroms away from Li sites. For the 20 ppm resonance, this further confirms its assignment to <sup>23</sup>Na sites within the LTO framework resulting in significant <sup>23</sup>Na–<sup>7</sup>Li dipolar coupling from multiple nearby <sup>7</sup>Li. The strong dephasing observed for NaF might be due to its proximity to LiF in SEI or to intimate nanoscale contact with LTO. In contrast, the lower dephasing of the organic sites suggests this phase is not in very intimate contact with <sup>7</sup>Li containing phases. Some dephasing is observed which could be due to minimal contact with the LTO substrate as well as formation of LiF in the SEI, as was also supported by the dephasing observed in <sup>23</sup>Na{<sup>19</sup>F} REDOR (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig4" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 4</a>a).</div><div class="NLM_p last">Depth profiling with XPS: Finally, XPS depth profiling experiments were performed to further support our observations from DNP (<a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/suppl_file/ja4c06823_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S11</a>). In this case, we observed a significant decrease in the carbon content with sputtering time, in agreement with our observation of organic species in the outer layer of the SEI. The Li content is roughly constant across the depth of the SEI, possibly due to distribution of LiF in the SEI. On the other hand, the F and Na contents decrease when moving deeper into the SEI, albeit slower than the C content. Furthermore, the decrease in the F and Na contents is more gradual in samples containing FEC. These results are in qualitative agreement with our NMR-DNP characterization, where the SEI formed in FEC had high F content also in its outer layers. Finally, the Ti signal seems to be growing with sputtering time, which is consistent with the sputtering beam moving deeper into the LTO particles. Nevertheless, we note that significant reduction of the Ti species was observed in these experiments (indicated by the formation of metallic Ti, <a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/suppl_file/ja4c06823_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S11c</a>). Such reactivity makes it challenging to quantify the Ti signal, as well as infer on the exact chemical species in the SEI due to chemical changes that may undergo during the sputtering process. Furthermore, the use of pressed powder samples (rather than flat surfaces) makes it challenging to extract reliable spatial distribution of the different species detected, as the signal is contributed from many particles at once.</div></div></div></div><div id="sec4" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_1"><div class="article_content-header"><div class="article_content-header-row"><div class="article_content-title" tabindex="0"><h2 id="_i22">4.  Discussion</h2><div class="article__copy"><button class="article__copy__btn"><i class="article__copy__icon icon-copy-solid" aria-hidden="true"></i></button><span class="article__copy__text">Click to copy section link</span><span class="article__copy__success">Section link copied!</span></div></div></div></div><hr><div class="NLM_p">The use of different polarization sources in DNP allows us to draw some conclusions about the SEI structure. The extent of polarization transfer with both exogenous and endogenous DNP approaches depends on three main rates: the rate of direct polarization transferred from the electron spins (radicals or metal ions) to the SEI, the rate of spin diffusion between the nuclei across phases, and the nuclear relaxation rate which sets the temporal limit for these processes to occur.</div><div class="NLM_p">Our exogenous DNP results showed that the radicals’ polarization could only be transferred to <sup>23</sup>Na via protons, with no enhancement obtained in direct <sup>23</sup>Na DNP. This provides a strong indication that the organic phases, which contain hydrogens, reside in the outer layers of the SEI. The abundance of <sup>1</sup>H nuclei in these phases allows polarization from the radicals to propagate effectively, either directly to <sup>1</sup>H in the SEI or indirectly through <sup>1</sup>H spin diffusion from the frozen TCE solvent. This is further supported by the strong correlations observed for <sup>13</sup>C and <sup>23</sup>Na resonances in the SEI and the <sup>1</sup>H TCE resonance (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig3" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 3</a>). We attribute the lack of direct enhancement of <sup>23</sup>Na to its very short relaxation time in the outer organic environments, which would also prevent spin diffusion from the outer SEI layers to the inner ones. As the inorganic phases detected in the SEI (NaF) have relatively long T<sub>1</sub> relaxation times (&gt;10 s), we would expect it to be directly polarized by the radicals if it were to reside in the outer layers. Thus, our exogenous DNP results suggest that predominantly organic phases are found in the outer layers, which is corroborated by our carbon depth profiling in XPS.</div><div class="NLM_p">Endogenous DNP enabled enhancement of the inner SEI layers. In this case, we rely on direct polarization of <sup>23</sup>Na in the SEI. When considering enhancement in the bulk, we have found that in crystalline solids, direct polarization is independent of the nuclear distance from the polarization agent. This is a result of the opposing effects of the paramagnetic metal ions, which act as the main source of nuclear relaxation and of nuclear polarization. Since both nuclear relaxation through paramagnetic agents (paramagnetic relaxation enhancement, PRE) and DNP have the same dependence on the electron–nuclear distance, these two effects cancel each other resulting in efficient polarization transfer across a crystalline lattice. <a onclick="showRef(event, 'ref39'); return false;" href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref39" aria-label="reference 39">(39)</a> We have also found that the presence of inherent relaxation sources limits the polarization transfer. In the case of the SEI, we expect a plethora of relaxation processes including ion dynamics, quadrupolar and strong dipolar interactions, as well as presence of paramagnetic defect (such as Ti(III)), all of which provide efficient sources for relaxation. To evaluate the effect of inherent nuclear relaxation on the extent of polarization transfer, the steady state polarization obtained via direct DNP was calculated based on previous derivations. <a onclick="showRef(event, 'ref39'); return false;" href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref39" aria-label="reference 39">(39)</a> Here, in addition to relaxation due to paramagnetic dopants, we included inherent relaxation <i>T</i><sub>1n</sub>. The result, shown in <a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig8" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 8</a>, suggests that even for an intrinsic relaxation time of 100 s (longer than what was measured for any of the <sup>23</sup>Na SEI components), the nuclear polarization from DNP drops within 15 Å. For <sup>23</sup>Na sites with inherent relaxation of 1–10 s (which is closer to the experimental observation for SEI components) direct polarization transfer is limited to 3–6 Å. Thus, we expect that any enhancement obtained from endogenous DNP would only be observed for SEI phases that are deposited directly on the LTO surface. We note that we also assume spin diffusion, which spreads the polarization between nuclear spins, would be inefficient with short intrinsic relaxation times. In this case, the extent of enhancement measured would correspond to the fraction of the phase that is in contact with the LTO substrate compared to its overall fraction in the SEI, i.e. large enhancement corresponds to large fraction on the surface and lower enhancement suggesting only a small fraction of the phase is at the inner SEI. Taking this into account, we conclude that the NaF phase is most likely the first to deposit on the LTO surface followed by the organic components. Considering the discussion above, as well as the quantitative results from <sup>23</sup>Na MAS NMR revealing that the SEI in this electrolyte is predominantly organic (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig2" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 2</a>a,b), we propose the following layered model (<a class="ref internalNav" href="#sch2" aria-label="Scheme 2">Scheme 2</a>) for the SEI formed on LTO in NaFSI and EC/DEC electrolyte. In the case of adding FEC to the electrolyte, the result is less conclusive, suggesting a more mixed structure for the SEI. This is also supported by the different REDOR experiments performed, showing significant mixing at the nanoscale between LiF, NaF and the organic SEI (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig2" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure 2</a>).</div><figure id="fig8" data-index="9" class="article__inlineFigure"><h2 class="fig-label">Figure 8</h2><button class="figure-viewer__trigger" aria-label="open figure viewer"><img src="/cms/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/asset/images/medium/ja4c06823_0008.gif" alt="" data-lg-src="/cms/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/asset/images/large/ja4c06823_0008.jpeg" id="gr8" class="inline-fig internalNav"></button><figcaption><div class="hlFld-FigureCaption caption"><p class="first last">Figure 8. Calculated ratio of <sup>23</sup>Na polarization (<i>P</i><sub>n</sub>) and electron polarization (<i>P</i><sub>e</sub>) as a function of the dopant-nucleus distance (<i>r</i>) and the intrinsic nuclear relaxation time (<i>T</i><sub>1</sub>). The dashed line indicates the distance at which the intrinsic <i>T</i><sub>1</sub> is equal to the relaxation caused by the paramagnetic ions (PRE). For this calculation an electron relaxation time of 1 μs was used.</p></div></figcaption><div class="figure-bottom-links"><div class="download-hi-res-img"><a title="High Resolution Image" href="/cms/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/asset/images/large/ja4c06823_0008.jpeg"><span>High Resolution Image</span></a></div><div class="download-ppt"><a title="Download MS PowerPoint Slide" href="/action/downloadFigures?doi=10.1021/jacs.4c06823&amp;id=fig8"><span>Download MS PowerPoint Slide</span></a></div></div></figure><figure id="sch2" data-index="10" class="article__inlineFigure"><h2 class="fig-label">Scheme 2</h2><button class="figure-viewer__trigger" aria-label="open figure viewer"><img src="/cms/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/asset/images/medium/ja4c06823_0010.gif" alt="" data-lg-src="/cms/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/asset/images/large/ja4c06823_0010.jpeg" id="gr9" class="inline-fig internalNav"></button><figcaption><div class="hlFld-FigureCaption caption"><div class="title2">Scheme 2. Structural Model of Native SEI Formed in LTO During Cycling Based on Data Acquired with Different Polarization Sources and Correlation Experiments<sup>a</sup></div></div></figcaption><div class="figure-bottom-links"><div class="download-hi-res-img"><a title="High Resolution Image" href="/cms/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/asset/images/large/ja4c06823_0010.jpeg"><span>High Resolution Image</span></a></div><div class="download-ppt"><a title="Download MS PowerPoint Slide" href="/action/downloadFigures?doi=10.1021/jacs.4c06823&amp;id=sch2"><span>Download MS PowerPoint Slide</span></a></div></div><p class="last"></p><p class="last"><span class="fn-label"><sup>a</sup></span>The outer SEI, detected by exogenous DNP, is predominantly organic compounds (green) whereas the inner SEI, detected with endogenous DNP, is more inorganic (dark blue). NaF is the main inorganic species estimated to form a thin layer at the inner SEI. Na<sub><i>x</i></sub>LTO formed due to Li–Na exchange at the outer layers of the particles is shown in dark purple.</p><p></p></figure><div class="NLM_p last">Our compositional study of the SEI reveals that the SEI formed in NaFSI in EC/DEC electrolyte is composed of NaF, Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> and organic carbonates, alkoxy and unsaturated polymer species. The addition of FEC increases the content of organic species in the SEI, specifically alkoxy and carbonate containing phases, as well as results in more pronounced formation of NaF and acidic species such as NaHCO<sub>3</sub> and carboxylic salts. In terms of its performance, it is clear that FEC, in contrast to the fluoride beneficial effect in LIB cells, decreases the electrochemical performance of LTO as a SIB anode. Cells cycled with the addition of only 2% FEC displayed much higher irreversible capacity, poor capacity retention as well as worse rate performance. Since FEC clearly is consumed in the process, this suggests that the SEI formed with FEC is deleterious to the cell performance. The decrease in rate performance as well as significant amount of residual Ti(III) suggest limited transport of Na<sup>+</sup> ions, both of which can be due to the formation of ionically insulating SEI, in this case rich in NaF. Thus, we conclude that NaF formation, in this case, is not beneficial in contrast to what is commonly reported for LIB but in agreement with recent reports on potassium-based cells. <a onclick="showRef(event, 'ref93 ref94'); return false;" href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref93 ref94" aria-label="reference 93 and 94">(93,94)</a> These results highlight the need to develop new understanding of the SEI formed in SIB, independent of the accumulated knowledge on LIB systems.</div></div><div id="sec5" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_1"><div class="article_content-header"><div class="article_content-header-row"><div class="article_content-title" tabindex="0"><h2 id="_i24">5.  Conclusions</h2><div class="article__copy"><button class="article__copy__btn"><i class="article__copy__icon icon-copy-solid" aria-hidden="true"></i></button><span class="article__copy__text">Click to copy section link</span><span class="article__copy__success">Section link copied!</span></div></div></div></div><hr><div class="NLM_p">In this work, we showed that NMR can be used as a powerful tool to sensitively characterize the native SEI formed during electrochemical cycling of LTO as part of a SIB. The detrimental effect of the FEC additive on the electrochemical performance in our SIBs was studied and correlated to SEI composition through multinuclear NMR experiments that enabled identification of the various compounds found in the SEI. NMR signal enhancement of <sup>13</sup>C by exogenous DNP assisted in identifying the organic phases of the SEI which were found to be rich in alkoxy, unsaturated polymers and carbonate species. Furthermore, a sodiated LTO phase (Na<sub><i>x</i></sub>LTO) that forms due to irreversible Na–Li ion exchange was identified in LTO bulk anode material via quantification of <sup>7</sup>Li signal during cycling in addition to REDOR experiments and DFT calculations. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first time that such a phase is reported in a sodium LTO cell, however its effect on Na transport is still an open question.</div><div class="NLM_p">Valuable information regarding the architecture of the SEI was obtained from endogenous and exogenous DNP under the premise that the polarization transfer is distance-dependent. Enhancing the inner SEI layers with endogenous DNP resulted in a <sup>23</sup>Na spectrum with differential signal enhancement for the SEI components. Analyzing the different enhancement factors revealed that the Na<sub><i>x</i></sub>LTO phase is found closest to the Mn(II) polarizing agents, followed by inorganic NaF at the inner part of the SEI, and organic species at the outer SEI layer. Signal enhanced <sup>23</sup>Na{<sup>7</sup>Li} REDOR by endogenous DNP further validated that the sodium found in the Na<sub><i>x</i></sub>LTO phase is in close spatial proximity to <sup>7</sup>Li. Performing <sup>1</sup>H–<sup>23</sup>Na CP with signal enhancement by exogenous DNP confirmed that the organic SEI species are indeed at the outer part of the SEI. By combining the information from both endogenous and exogenous DNP methods, we were able to suggest a model of the SEI formed in LTO due to Na de/insertion including chemical and structural information.</div><div class="NLM_p last">The study of the SEI is extremely challenging due to its sensitive, heterogeneous and disordered nature. The approach presented here has several advantages compared to more traditional approaches for SEI investigations as it benefits from the superior chemical resolution of NMR. Leveraging NMR and the high sensitivity enhancements of DNP, we are able to obtain a detailed chemical compositional map of the SEI. Furthermore, the utilization of multiple polarization sources, demonstrated here for the first time in probing the native SEI, provides spatial information which is used to derive structural models of the SEI. This is a particularly powerful approach as it provides a chemically resolved, nondestructive alternative approach to depth profiling via XPS or TOF-SIMS, both of which have limited applicability in the case of nanoscale SEI layers formed on nonflat substrates. We expect the presented approach, combining exogenous organic radicals and endogenous metal ions, can be extended to other titanate oxides anodes for SIB and K -ion batteries. <a onclick="showRef(event, 'ref94 ref95 ref96 ref97 ref98'); return false;" href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref94 ref95 ref96 ref97 ref98" aria-label="reference 94 to 98">(94−98)</a> Furthermore, elucidating both the composition and the distribution of phases across the SEI, and comparison with electrochemical performance, will benefit the development of new electrolyte chemistries. The presented approach, utilizing different polarization sources, can also be envisioned to provide structural insight into the SEI formed on other SIB and LIB anodes, such as Na and Li metal or graphite-based anodes, where the conduction electrons can be utilized as a source of endogenous DNP. <a onclick="showRef(event, 'ref99'); return false;" href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref99" aria-label="reference 99">(99)</a> As such, DNP-NMR spectroscopy is a valuable tool in the arsenal of techniques used to probe and understand the SEI, an essential step in the development of improved materials and systems for energy storage.</div></div><div class="NLM_back"><div class="article_supporting-info" id="notes1"><div class="article_content-header"><div class="article_content-header-row"><div class="article_content-title" tabindex="0"><h2 id="_i25">Supporting Information</h2><div class="article__copy"><button class="article__copy__btn"><i class="article__copy__icon icon-copy-solid" aria-hidden="true"></i></button><span class="article__copy__text">Click to copy section link</span><span class="article__copy__success">Section link copied!</span></div></div></div></div><hr><p class="last">The Supporting Information is available free of charge at <a href="/doi/10.1021/jacs.4c06823?goto=supporting-info" class="ext-link">https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/jacs.4c06823</a>.</p><ul class="NLM_list-list_type-label" id="silist"><li><p class="inline">Additional materials characterization with XRD, SEM, TEM and electrochemical performance; <sup>23</sup>Na NMR spectra of reference compounds; NMR quantification of sodium and lithium at different SOC; Details on the CASTEP calculations; <sup>1</sup>H MAS DNP spectra obtained in exogenous DNP experiments and enhancement factors of different <sup>23</sup>Na sites obtained in <sup>1</sup>H–<sup>23</sup>Na CP; Images of the cycled ppLTO electrodes; CW EPR X-band spectra; <sup>17</sup>O MAS DNP spectrum of Mn doped cycled ppLTO; <sup>23</sup>Na spectra with deconvolution obtained for various samples with endogenous DNP; XPS depth profiling results (<a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/suppl_file/ja4c06823_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">PDF</a>)</p></li></ul><p></p><div class="supInfoBoxOnFTP "><div class="sup-info-attachments"><ul><li><a class="suppl-anchor" href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/suppl_file/ja4c06823_si_001.pdf">ja4c06823_si_001.pdf (1.19 MB)</a></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="testing" data-doi="10.1021/jacs.4c06823" data-url="https://widgets.figshare.com/static/figshare.js" id="figshare-widget"></div><div class="TermsAndConditionsDropzone3" data-pb-dropzone="TermsAndConditionsDropzone3"><div data-widget-def="UX3HTMLWidget" data-widget-id="85b54935-30e9-4058-a6d2-0b40fb754a85" class="mb-4">

of Science, Rehovot 761000, Israel</span>;&nbsp;
    <span class="author-orcid"><img height="20" width="27" src="/products/achs/releasedAssets/images/orchid-2856f829046fbda55b90e1582edf0e9a.png" alt="Orcid"><a href="https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1637-6366" title="Orcid link">https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1637-6366</a></span></div></li><li><div class="authorItemInformation"><span class="hlFld-ContribAuthor strong">Ayan Maity</span> - <span class="hlFld-Affiliation affiliation">Department
of Molecular Chemistry and Materials Science, Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot 761000, Israel</span></div></li><li><div class="authorItemInformation"><span class="hlFld-ContribAuthor strong">Raanan Carmieli</span> - <span class="hlFld-Affiliation affiliation">Department
of Chemical Research Support, Weizmann Institute
of Science, Rehovot 761000, Israel</span>;&nbsp;
    <span class="author-orcid"><img height="20" width="27" src="/products/achs/releasedAssets/images/orchid-2856f829046fbda55b90e1582edf0e9a.png" alt="Orcid"><a href="https://orcid.org/0000-0003-4418-916X" title="Orcid link">https://orcid.org/0000-0003-4418-916X</a></span></div></li><li><div class="authorItemInformation"><span class="hlFld-ContribAuthor strong">Raphaële J. Clément</span> - <span class="hlFld-Affiliation affiliation">Materials
Department, University of California, Santa Barbara, California 93106, United States</span>;&nbsp;
    <span class="hlFld-Affiliation affiliation">Materials
Research Laboratory, University of California, Santa Barbara, California 93106, United States</span>;&nbsp;

                        cas_cit2R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">2</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Research Development on Sodium-Ion Batteries</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Yabuuchi, Naoaki; Kubota, Kei; Dahbi, Mouad; Komaba, Shinichi</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States)</span>
