        </div><div class="casAbstract">A review of sodium-ion battery technol.  Future outlook of sodium-ion batteries is discussed.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGo_Iht8id70u7Vg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lhN2w_FN1_j4g"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhvFSiu7bL&amp;md5=d4497339c61083b2ec2c0568261e4909</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref3"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref3'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">3</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit3" data-doi="10.1002/aenm.202002055"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Goikolea, E.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Palomares, V.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Wang, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">de Larramendi, I. R.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Guo, X.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Wang, G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Rojo, T.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Na-Ion Batteries─Approaching Old and New Challenges</span>. <i>Adv. Energy Mater.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2020</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>10</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">44</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">2002055</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1002/aenm.202002055</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D10%26publication_year%3D2020%26pages%3D2002055%26journal%3DAdv.%2BEnergy%2BMater.%26issue%3D44%26author%3DE.%2BGoikolea%26author%3DV.%2BPalomares%26author%3DS.%2BWang%26author%3DI.%2BR.%2Bde%2BLarramendi%26author%3DX.%2BGuo%26author%3DG.%2BWang%26author%3DT.%2BRojo%26title%3DNa-Ion%2BBatteries%25E2%2594%2580Approaching%2BOld%2Band%2BNew%2BChallenges%26doi%3D10.1002%252Faenm.202002055&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1002%2Faenm.202002055&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit3R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">3</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Na-Ion Batteries-Approaching Old and New Challenges</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Goikolea, Eider; Palomares, Veronica; Wang, Shijian; de Larramendi, Idoia Ruiz; Guo, Xin; Wang, Guoxiu; Rojo, Teofilo</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Advanced Energy Materials</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2020</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">10</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">44</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">2002055</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">ADEMBC</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1614-6840</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Wiley-Blackwell</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">The last 10 years established the beginning of a post-lithium era in the field of energy storage, with the renaissance of Na-ion batteries (NIBs) as alternative for Li-based systems.  The development of this technol. has required intense work in materials research in order to produce and optimize anodes, cathodes, and electrolytes for NIBs.  The strong and weak points of the main families of compds. for each battery component are analyzed in this progress report.  Taking into account the achievements made in materials for NIBs, the industrial scene is analyzed through the existing prototypes and com. cells and also from an economical viewpoint.  In this scenario, where Na-ion technol. seems to be ready for a coming second generation, the use of Na can be extended to almost the whole spectrum of electrochem. energy storage systems: the new room temp. Na-S systems, high-energy Na-air technol., or high-power Na-based hybrid supercapacitors.  Thus, the degree of development of NIBs, together with the promising performance of newer Na-based energy storage systems, makes Na the key to the coming com. post-lithium systems.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGqg49dGXsRZDLVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lhN2w_FN1_j4g"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXitVWqurvL&amp;md5=a4b99938f0f562861d32bfabddb190bb</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref4"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref4'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">4</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit4" data-doi="10.1002/anie.201703772"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Nayak, P. K.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Yang, L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Brehm, W.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Adelhelm, P.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">From Lithium-Ion to Sodium-Ion Batteries: Advantages, Challenges, and Surprises</span>. <i>Angew. Chem., Int. Ed.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2018</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>57</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">102</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">120</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1002/anie.201703772</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D57%26publication_year%3D2018%26pages%3D102-120%26journal%3DAngew.%2BChem.%252C%2BInt.%2BEd.%26author%3DP.%2BK.%2BNayak%26author%3DL.%2BYang%26author%3DW.%2BBrehm%26author%3DP.%2BAdelhelm%26title%3DFrom%2BLithium-Ion%2Bto%2BSodium-Ion%2BBatteries%253A%2BAdvantages%252C%2BChallenges%252C%2Band%2BSurprises%26doi%3D10.1002%252Fanie.201703772&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1002%2Fanie.201703772&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit4R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">4</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">From Lithium-Ion to Sodium-Ion Batteries: Advantages, Challenges, and Surprises</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Nayak, Prasant Kumar; Yang, Liangtao; Brehm, Wolfgang; Adelhelm, Philipp</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Angewandte Chemie, International Edition</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2018</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">57</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">1</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">102-120</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">ACIEF5</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1433-7851</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH &amp; Co. KGaA</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A review.  Mobile and stationary energy storage by rechargeable batteries is a topic of broad societal and economical relevance.  Lithium-ion battery (LIB) technol. is at the forefront of the development, but a massively growing market will likely put severe pressure on resources and supply chains.  Recently, sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) have been reconsidered with the aim of providing a lower-cost alternative that is less susceptible to resource and supply risks.  On paper, the replacement of lithium by sodium in a battery seems straightforward at first, but unpredictable surprises are often found in practice.  What happens when replacing lithium by sodium in electrode reactions.  This review provides a state-of-the art overview on the redox behavior of materials when used as electrodes in lithium-ion and sodium-ion batteries, resp.  Advantages and challenges related to the use of sodium instead of lithium are discussed.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGrGeYJemvxIpbVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lgRJnKQm_Bgow"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhvVKmurvE&amp;md5=4342a80be51730e08dc9faec2f79fb63</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref5"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref5'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">5</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit5" data-doi="10.1149/1.2128859"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Peled, E.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">The Electrochemical Behavior of Alkali and Alkaline Earth Metals in Nonaqueous Battery Systems─The Solid Electrolyte Interphase Model</span>. <i>J. Electrochem. Soc.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">1979</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>126</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">12</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">2047</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">2051</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1149/1.2128859</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D126%26publication_year%3D1979%26pages%3D2047-2051%26journal%3DJ.%2BElectrochem.%2BSoc.%26issue%3D12%26author%3DE.%2BPeled%26title%3DThe%2BElectrochemical%2BBehavior%2Bof%2BAlkali%2Band%2BAlkaline%2BEarth%2BMetals%2Bin%2BNonaqueous%2BBattery%2BSystems%25E2%2594%2580The%2BSolid%2BElectrolyte%2BInterphase%2BModel%26doi%3D10.1149%252F1.2128859&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1149%2F1.2128859&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit5R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">5</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">The electrochemical behavior of alkali and alkaline earth metals in nonaqueous battery systems - the solid electrolyte interphase model</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Peled, E.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of the Electrochemical Society</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">1979</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">126</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">12</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">2047-51</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JESOAN</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0013-4651</span>.
    </div><div class="casAbstract">It is suggested that in practical nonaq. battery systems the alkali metal and alk. earth metals are always covered by a surface layer which is instantly formed by the reaction of the metal with the electrolyte.  This layer which acts as an interphase between the metal and the soln., has the properties of a solid electrolyte.  The corrosion rate of the metal, the mechanism of the deposition-dissoln. process, the kinetic parameters, the quality of the metal deposit, and the half-cell potential depend on the character of the solid electrolyte interphase.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGquvtn9NRsLIbVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lgRJnKQm_Bgow"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL3cXms1Knsg%253D%253D&amp;md5=fe74ffb3fec01611647df8064745f23f</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref6"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref6'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">6</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit6" data-doi="10.1149/2.1441707jes"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Peled, E.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Menkin, S.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Review─SEI: Past, Present and Future</span>. <i>J. Electrochem. Soc.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2017</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>164</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">7</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">A1703</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">A1719</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1149/2.1441707jes</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D164%26publication_year%3D2017%26pages%3DA1703-A1719%26journal%3DJ.%2BElectrochem.%2BSoc.%26issue%3D7%26author%3DE.%2BPeled%26author%3DS.%2BMenkin%26title%3DReview%25E2%2594%2580SEI%253A%2BPast%252C%2BPresent%2Band%2BFuture%26doi%3D10.1149%252F2.1441707jes&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1149%2F2.1441707jes&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit6R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">6</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Review-SEI: Past, Present and Future</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Peled, E.; Menkin, S.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of the Electrochemical Society</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2017</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">164</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">7</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">A1703-A1719</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JESOAN</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0013-4651</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Electrochemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">The Solid-Electrolyte-Interphase (SEI) model for non-aq. alkali-metal batteries constitutes a paradigm change in the understanding of lithium batteries and has thus enabled the development of safer, durable, higher-power and lower-cost lithium batteries for portable and EV applications.  Prior to the publication of the SEI model (1979), researchers used the Butler-Volmer equation, in which a direct electron transfer from the electrode to lithium cations in the soln. is assumed.  The SEI model proved that this is a mistaken concept and that, in practice, the transfer of electrons from the electrode to the soln. in a lithium battery, must be prevented, since it will result in fast self-discharge of the active materials and poor battery performance.  This model provides [E. Peled, in "Lithium Batteries," J.P. Gabano (ed), Academic Press, (1983), E. Peled, J. Electrochem. Soc., 126, 2047 (1979).] new equations for: electrode kinetics (io and b), anode corrosion, SEI resistivity and growth rate and irreversible capacity loss of lithium-ion batteries.  This model became a cornerstone in the science and technol. of lithium batteries.  This paper reviews the past, present and the future of SEI batteries.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGom_0IvfBXlibVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lgRJnKQm_Bgow"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhtVCitLvN&amp;md5=3a2703b96a3bee6a8036b35db85534a7</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref7"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref7'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">7</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit7" data-doi="10.1021/cr500003w"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Xu, K.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Electrolytes and Interphases in Li-Ion Batteries and Beyond</span>. <i>Chem. Rev.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2014</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>114</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">23</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">11503</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">11618</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/cr500003w</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D114%26publication_year%3D2014%26pages%3D11503-11618%26journal%3DChem.%2BRev.%26issue%3D23%26author%3DK.%2BXu%26title%3DElectrolytes%2Band%2BInterphases%2Bin%2BLi-Ion%2BBatteries%2Band%2BBeyond%26doi%3D10.1021%252Fcr500003w&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1021%2Fcr500003w&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit7R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">7</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Electrolytes and Interphases in Li-Ion Batteries and Beyond</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Xu, Kang</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States)</span>

    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">114</span>

        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0009-2665</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A review of advances in electrolytes and interphases in lithium-ion batteries.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGoNVF7DWmEL07Vg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lgRJnKQm_Bgow"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhvVensr3N&amp;md5=5d79be66e09915ece2c476aab47c4224</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref8"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref8'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">8</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit8" data-doi="10.1016/j.jpowsour.2023.232652"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Xu, K.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Interfaces and Interphases in Batteries</span>. <i>J.                 10.1016/j.jpowsour.2023.232652</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D559%26publication_year%3D2023%26pages%3D232652%26journal%3DJ.%2BPower%2BSources%26issue%3DJanuary%26author%3DK.%2BXu%26title%3DInterfaces%2Band%2BInterphases%2Bin%2BBatteries%26doi%3D10.1016%252Fj.jpowsour.2023.232652&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1016%2Fj.jpowsour.2023.232652&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord empty" id="
                            cas_R
                        "><div class="casContent">There is no corresponding record for this reference.</div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref9"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref9'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">9</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit9" data-doi="10.1002/aenm.202102687"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Atkins, D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ayerbe, E.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Benayad, A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Capone, F. Energy Mater.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2022</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>12</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">17</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">2102687</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1002/aenm.202102687</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D12%26publication_year%3D2022%26pages%3D2102687%26journal%3DAdv.%2BEnergy%2BMater.%26issue%3D17%26author%3DD.%2BAtkins%26author%3DE.%2BAyerbe%26author%3DA.%2BBenayad%26author%3DF.%2BG.%2BCapone%26author%3DE.%2BCapria%26author%3DI.%2BE.%2BCastelli%26author%3DI.%2BCekic-Laskovic%26author%3DR.%2BCiria%26author%3DL.%2BDudy%26author%3DK.%2BEdstr%25C3%25B6m%26author%3DM.%2BR.%2BJohnson%26author%3DH.%2BLi%26author%3DJ.%2BM.%2BG.%2BLastra%26author%3DM.%2BL.%2BDe%250ASouza%26author%3DV.%2BMeunier%26author%3DM.%2BMorcrette%26author%3DH.%2BReichert%26author%3DP.%2BSimon%26author%3DJ.%2BRueff%26author%3DJ.%2BSottmann%26author%3DW.%2BWenzel%26author%3DA.%2BGrimaud%26title%3DUnderstanding%2BBattery%2BInterfaces%2Bby%2BCombined%2BCharacterization%2Band%2BSimulation%2BApproaches%253A%2BChallenges%2Band%2BPerspectives%26doi%3D10.1002%252Faenm.202102687&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1002%2Faenm.202102687&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit9R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">9</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Understanding Battery Interfaces by Combined Characterization and Simulation Approaches: Challenges and Perspectives</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Atkins, Duncan; Ayerbe, Elixabete; Benayad, Anass; Capone, Federico G.; Capria, Ennio; Castelli, Ivano E.; Cekic-Laskovic, Isidora; Ciria, Raul; Dudy, Lenart; Edstrom, Kristina; Johnson, Mark R.; Li, Hongjiao; Lastra, Juan Maria Garcia; De Souza, Matheus Leal; Meunier, Valentin; Morcrette, Mathieu; Reichert, Harald; Simon, Patrice; Rueff, Jean-Pascal; Sottmann, Jonas; Wenzel, Wolfgang; Grimaud, Alexis</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Advanced Energy Materials</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2022</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">12</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">17</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">2102687</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">ADEMBC</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1614-6840</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Wiley-Blackwell</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A review.  Driven by the continuous search for improving performances, understanding the phenomena at the electrode/electrolyte interfaces has become an overriding factor for the success of sustainable and efficient battery technologies for mobile and stationary applications.  Toward this goal, rapid advances have been made regarding simulations/modeling techniques and characterization approaches, including high-throughput electrochem. measurements coupled with spectroscopies.  Focusing on Li-ion batteries, current developments are analyzed in the field as well as future challenges in order to gain a full description of interfacial processes across multiple length/timescales; from charge transfer to migration/diffusion properties and interphases formation, up to and including their stability over the entire battery lifetime.  For such complex and interrelated phenomena, developing a unified workflow intimately combining the ensemble of these techniques will be crit. to unlocking their full investigative potential.  For this paradigm shift in battery design to become reality, it necessitates the implementation of research stds. and protocols, underlining the importance of a concerted approach across the community.  With this in mind, major collaborative initiatives gathering complementary strengths and skills will be fundamental if societal and environmental imperatives in this domain are to be met.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGrbTmNPEz-8CrVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lgRJnKQm_Bgow"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3MXislyiurjN&amp;md5=d500b515c88eac0ecde8d7c9e8c8cb7f</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref10"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref10'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">10</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit10" data-doi="10.1149/1.1837858"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Peled, E.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Golodnitsky, D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ardel, G.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Advanced Model for Solid Electrolyte Interphase Electrodes in Liquid and Polymer Electrolytes</span>. <i>J. Electrochem. Soc.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">1997</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>144</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">8</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">L208</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">L210</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1149/1.1837858</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D144%26publication_year%3D1997%26pages%3DL208-L210%26journal%3DJ.%2BElectrochem.%2BSoc.%26issue%3D8%26author%3DE.%2BPeled%26author%3DD.%2BGolodnitsky%26author%3DG.%2BArdel%26title%3DAdvanced%2BModel%2Bfor%2BSolid%2BElectrolyte%2BInterphase%2BElectrodes%2Bin%2BLiquid%2Band%2BPolymer%2BElectrolytes%26doi%3D10.1149%252F1.1837858&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1149%2F1.1837858&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit10R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">10</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Advanced model for solid electrolyte interphase electrodes in liquid and polymer electrolytes</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Peled, E.; Golodnitsky, D.; Ardel, G.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of the Electrochemical Society</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">1997</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">144</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">8</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">L208-L210</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JESOAN</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0013-4651</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Electrochemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Recent studies show that the SEI on lithium and on LixC6 anodes in liq. nonaq. solns. consists of many different materials including Li2O, LiF, LiCl, Li2CO3, LiCO2-R, alkoxides, and nonconducting polymers.  The equivalent circuit for such a mosaic-type SEI electrode is extremely complex.  It is shown that near room temp. the grain-boundary resistance (Rgb) for polyparticle solid electrolytes is larger than the bulk ionic resistance.  Up to now, all models of SEI electrodes ignored the contribution of Rgb to the overall SEI resistance.  We show here that this neglect has no justification.  On the basis of recent results, we propose here for SEI electrodes equiv. circuits which take into account the contribution of grain-boundary and other interfacial impedance terms.  This model accounts for a variety of different types of Nyquist plots reported for lithium and LixC6 electrodes in liq. nonaq. and polymer electrolytes.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGoasX4AUDQWTLVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0ljdRpuc6aQXzA"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2sXlvFOhs7o%253D&amp;md5=2044c437192bc78375313e02b9ea9bd3</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref11"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref11'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">11</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit11" data-doi="10.1016/S0378-7753(00)00431-6"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Aurbach, D.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Review of Selected Electrode-Solution Interactions Which Determine the Performance of Li and Li Ion Batteries</span>. <i>J. Power Sources</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2000</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>89</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">2</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">206</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">218</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1016/S0378-7753(00)00431-6</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D89%26publication_year%3D2000%26pages%3D206-218%26journal%3DJ.%2BPower%2BSources%26issue%3D2%26author%3DD.%2BAurbach%26title%3DReview%2Bof%2BSelected%2BElectrode-Solution%2BInteractions%2BWhich%2BDetermine%2Bthe%2BPerformance%2Bof%2BLi%2Band%2BLi%2BIon%2BBatteries%26doi%3D10.1016%252FS0378-7753%252800%252900431-6&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1016%2FS0378-7753%2800%2900431-6&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit11R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">11</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Review of selected electrode-solution interactions which determine the performance of Li and Li ion batteries</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Aurbach, D.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Power Sources</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2000</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">89</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">2</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">206-218</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JPSODZ</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0378-7753</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Elsevier Science S.A.</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A review with 67 refs. on several phenomenol. electrode-soln. interactions which det. the performance of lithium and lithium ion batteries.  This review is based on extensive studies of the behavior of Li, lithiated carbons and lithiated transition metal oxide electrodes in a wide variety of non-aq. electrolyte solns.  These studies included spectroscopic measurements (FTIR, XPS, EDAX), morphol. and structural anal. (XRD, SEM, AFM) in conjunction with impedance spectroscopy, EQCM and std. electrochem. techniques.  It appears that the performance of both Li, Li-C anodes and LixMOy cathodes depends on their surface chem. in solns.  We address complicated surface film formation on these electrodes, which either contribute to electrode stabilization or to capacity fading due to an increase in the electrodes' impedance.  Several common classical phenomena occurring in these systems are reviewed and discussed.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGqEB6R80kTJ5LVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0ljdRpuc6aQXzA"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3cXktFenu7w%253D&amp;md5=7c6d2abf4914a6401c5e5da9992f2cc7</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref12"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref12'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">12</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit12" data-doi="10.1149/1945-7111/ab75fd"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Fondard, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Irisarri, E.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Courrèges, C.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Palacin, M. R.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ponrouch, A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Dedryvère, R.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">SEI Composition on Hard Carbon in Na-Ion Batteries After Long Cycling: Influence of Salts (NaPF 6, NaTFSI) and Additives (FEC, DMCF)</span>. <i>J. Electrochem. Soc.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2020</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>167</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">7</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">070526</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1149/1945-7111/ab75fd</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D167%26publication_year%3D2020%26pages%3D070526%26journal%3DJ.%2BElectrochem.%2BSoc.%26issue%3D7%26author%3DJ.%2BFondard%26author%3DE.%2BIrisarri%26author%3DC.%2BCourr%25C3%25A8ges%26author%3DM.%2BR.%2BPalacin%26author%3DA.%2BPonrouch%26author%3DR.%2BDedryv%25C3%25A8re%26title%3DSEI%2BComposition%2Bon%2BHard%2BCarbon%2Bin%2BNa-Ion%2BBatteries%2BAfter%2BLong%2BCycling%253A%2BInfluence%2Bof%2BSalts%2B%2528NaPF%2B6%252C%2BNaTFSI%2529%2Band%2BAdditives%2B%2528FEC%252C%2BDMCF%2529%26doi%3D10.1149%252F1945-7111%252Fab75fd&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1149%2F1945-7111%2Fab75fd&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit12R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">12</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">SEI composition on hard carbon in Na-Ion batteries after long cycling: Influence of salts (NaPF6, NaTFSI) and Additives (FEC, DMCF)</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Fondard, J.; Irisarri, E.; Courreges, C.; Palacin, M. R.; Ponrouch, A.; Dedryvere, R.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of the Electrochemical Society</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2020</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">167</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">7</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">070526</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JESOAN</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0013-4651</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Electrochemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A study of the solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) on hard-carbon (HC) electrodes in sodium half-cells is presented.  Electrochem. performances over &gt; 100 cycles were compared with two different salts (NaPF6, NaTFSI) and two different electrolyte additives (FEC, DMCF) in a mixt. of EC and DMC solvents.  The best electrochem. performances were obsd. with NaPF6 salt in conjunction with 3% FEC.  The DMCF additive had a detrimental effect in all electrolyte combinations.  The chem. characterization of the SEI was carried out by XPS and showed that the best electrochem. behavior was related to an SEI compn. based on sodium ethylene dicarbonate and NaF, whereas poorer electrochem. performances were assocd. to either low NaF or high Na2CO3 content.  The results reported herein provide an insight on the SEI chem. on hard carbon electrodes in sodium cells after long-term cycling, as a complement to previous studies dealing with the first cycles.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGq4rxL0JhE-c7Vg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0ljdRpuc6aQXzA"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXosVKisL0%253D&amp;md5=fc871aceb661bd6af19f8153b66817bd</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref13"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref13'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">13</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit13" data-doi="10.1039/C9SE00349E"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Gangaja, B.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Nair, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Santhanagopalan, D.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Solvent-Controlled Solid-Electrolyte Interphase Layer Composition of a High Performance Li4Ti5O12 Anode for Na-Ion Battery Applications</span>. <i>Sustain. Energy Fuels</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2019</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>3</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">9</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">2490</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">2498</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1039/C9SE00349E</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D3%26publication_year%3D2019%26pages%3D2490-2498%26journal%3DSustain.%2BEnergy%2BFuels%26issue%3D9%26author%3DB.%2BGangaja%26author%3DS.%2BNair%26author%3DD.%2BSanthanagopalan%26title%3DSolvent-Controlled%2BSolid-Electrolyte%2BInterphase%2BLayer%2BComposition%2Bof%2Ba%2BHigh%2BPerformance%2BLi4Ti5O12%2BAnode%2Bfor%2BNa-Ion%2BBattery%2BApplications%26doi%3D10.1039%252FC9SE00349E&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1039%2FC9SE00349E&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord empty" id="
                            cas_R
                        "><div class="casContent">There is no corresponding record for this reference.</div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref14"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref14'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">14</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit14" data-doi="10.1021/acsmaterialslett.0c00356"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Wang, E.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Niu, Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Yin, Y.-X.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Guo, Y.-G.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Manipulating Electrode/Electrolyte Interphases of Sodium-Ion Batteries: Strategies and Perspectives</span>. <i>ACS Mater. Lett.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2021</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>3</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">1</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">18</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">41</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/acsmaterialslett.0c00356</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D3%26publication_year%3D2021%26pages%3D18-41%26journal%3DACS%2BMater.%2BLett.%26issue%3D1%26author%3DE.%2BWang%26author%3DY.%2BNiu%26author%3DY.-X.%2BYin%26author%3DY.-G.%2BGuo%26title%3DManipulating%2BElectrode%252FElectrolyte%2BInterphases%2Bof%2BSodium-Ion%2BBatteries%253A%2BStrategies%2Band%2BPerspectives%26doi%3D10.1021%252Facsmaterialslett.0c00356&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1021%2Facsmaterialslett.0c00356&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit14R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">14</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Manipulating Electrode/Electrolyte Interphases of Sodium-Ion Batteries: Strategies and Perspectives</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Wang, Enhui; Niu, Yubin; Yin, Ya-Xia; Guo, Yu-Guo</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">ACS Materials Letters</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2021</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">3</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">1</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">18-41</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">AMLCEF</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">2639-4979</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A review.  After the past decade's rapid development, the com. demands for sodium ion batteries (SIBs) have been put on the schedule for large-scale energy storage.  Even though the electrode-electrolyte interphases play a very important role in detg. the overall battery performance in terms of high energy d. and long-cycling stability, studies regarding their fundamental understanding and regulation strategies are still in their infancy.  Herein, we comprehensively review the current research status and the challenging issues of the as-generated SIB interphases from three main aspects.  Firstly, a fundamental understanding of the main body interphase layers is introduced through the development of their formation mechanism, their compn./structure, and the dynamic evolution process involved, all of which are highly responsible for the Na+ ion transport behavior to det. the final kinetic diffusion.  Then, interphase manipulation via the parental electrolyte is summarized in terms of electrolyte engineering strategies, such as the solvent/salt selection, the concn. effect, and the functional additive screening to build a more stable interphase layer for desirable electrochem. reversibility.  Finally, potential effects from the chosen electrodes are discussed to provide necessary assocns. with the interphase formation and evolution.  Crit. challenges for building stable Na-based interphase are identified, and in particular, new ways of thinking about the interphase chem. and the electrolyte chem. based on SIBs, are strongly appealing.  We believe that this work is likely to attract attention to the rational design of Na-based interphase layers towards high-energy and long-life-span batteries.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGqVuJ3ZWCnEX7Vg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0ljdRpuc6aQXzA"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXisVWntb3J&amp;md5=5cc0e78592ac0fc5cb0e24007ba54fa6</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref15"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref15'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">15</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit15" data-doi="10.1016/j.electacta.2010.05.072"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Verma, P.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Maire, P.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Novák, P.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">A Review of the Features and Analyses of the Solid Electrolyte Interphase in Li-Ion Batteries</span>. <i>Electrochim. Acta</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2010</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>55</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">22</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">6332</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">6341</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1016/j.electacta.2010.05.072</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D55%26publication_year%3D2010%26pages%3D6332-6341%26journal%3DElectrochim.%2BActa%26issue%3D22%26author%3DP.%2BVerma%26author%3DP.%2BMaire%26author%3DP.%2BNov%25C3%25A1k%26title%3DA%2BReview%2Bof%2Bthe%2BFeatures%2Band%2BAnalyses%2Bof%2Bthe%2BSolid%2BElectrolyte%2BInterphase%2Bin%2BLi-Ion%2BBatteries%26doi%3D10.1016%252Fj.electacta.2010.05.072&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1016%2Fj.electacta.2010.05.072&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit15R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">15</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">A review of the features and analyses of the solid electrolyte interphase in Li-ion batteries</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Verma, Pallavi; Maire, Pascal; Novak, Petr</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Electrochimica Acta</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2010</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">55</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">22</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">6332-6341</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">ELCAAV</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0013-4686</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Elsevier B.V.</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A review.  The solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) is a protecting layer formed on the neg. electrode of Li-ion batteries as a result of electrolyte decompn., mainly during the 1st cycle.  Battery performance, irreversible charge loss, rate capability, cyclability, exfoliation of graphite and safety are highly dependent on the quality of the SEI.  Therefore, understanding the actual nature and compn. of SEI is of prime interest.  If the chem. of the SEI formation and the manner in which each component affects battery performance are understood, SEI could be tuned to improve battery performance.  In this paper key points related to the nature, formation, and features of the SEI formed on carbon neg. electrodes are discussed.  SEI was analyzed by various anal. techniques amongst which FTIR and XPS are most widely used.  FTIR and XPS data of SEI and its components as published by many research groups are compiled in tables for getting a global picture of what is known about the SEI.  This article shall serve as a handy ref. as well as a starting point for research related to SEI.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGqk3Nnl4Upo8rVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0ljdRpuc6aQXzA"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhtVajsbvM&amp;md5=15e800867b70d0844c9b688e7cc3914b</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref16"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref16'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">16</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit16" data-doi="10.1021/acsaem.8b00406"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Wood, K. N.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Teeter, G.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">XPS on Li-Battery-Related Compounds: Analysis of Inorganic SEI Phases and a Methodology for Charge Correction</span>. <i>ACS Appl. Energy Mater.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2018</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>1</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">9</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">4493</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">4504</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/acsaem.8b00406</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D1%26publication_year%3D2018%26pages%3D4493-4504%26journal%3DACS%2BAppl.%2BEnergy%2BMater.%26issue%3D9%26author%3DK.%2BN.%2BWood%26author%3DG.%2BTeeter%26title%3DXPS%2Bon%2BLi-Battery-Related%2BCompounds%253A%2BAnalysis%2Bof%2BInorganic%2BSEI%2BPhases%2Band%2Ba%2BMethodology%2Bfor%2BCharge%2BCorrection%26doi%3D10.1021%252Facsaem.8b00406&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1021%2Facsaem.8b00406&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit16R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">16</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">XPS on Li-Battery-Related Compounds: Analysis of Inorganic SEI Phases and a Methodology for Charge Correction</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Wood, Kevin N.; Teeter, Glenn</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">ACS Applied Energy Materials</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2018</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">1</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">9</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">4493-4504</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">AAEMCQ</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">2574-0962</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Accurate identification of chem. phases assocd. with the electrode and solid-electrolyte interphase (SEI) is crit. for understanding and controlling interfacial degrdn. mechanisms in lithium-contg. battery systems.  To study these crit. battery materials and interfaces XPS is a widely used technique that provides quant. chem. insights.  However, due to the fact that a majority of chem. phases relevant to battery interfaces are poor electronic conductors, phase identification that relies primarily on abs. XPS core-level binding-energies (BEs) can be problematic.  Charging during XPS measurements leads to BE shifts that can be difficult to correct.  These difficulties are often exacerbated by the coexistence of multiple Li-contg. phases in the SEI with overlapping XPS core levels.  To facilitate accurate phase identification of battery-relevant phases (and electronically insulating phases in general), a straightforward approach is proposed for removing charging effects from XPS data sets.  This approach is applied to XPS data sets acquired from six battery-relevant inorg. phases including lithium metal (Li0), lithium oxide (Li2O), lithium peroxide (Li2O2), lithium hydroxide (LiOH), lithium carbonate (Li2CO3), and lithium nitride (Li3N).  Specifically, it is demonstrated that BE sepns. between core levels present in a particular phase (e.g., BE sepn. between the O 1s and Li 1s core levels in Li2O) provide an addnl. constraint that can significantly improve reliability of phase identification.  For phases like Li2O2 and LiOH where the Li-to-O ratios and BE sepns. are nearly identical, X-ray excited valence-band spectra can provide addnl. clues that facilitate accurate phase identification.  To accurately identity the phases in this study, we show that in situ growth of Li2O on Li0 provides a means for detg. abs. core-level positions, where all charging effects can be accurately removed.  Finally, as an exemplary case the charge-correction methodol. is applied to XPS data acquired from a sym. cell based on a Li2S-P2S5 solid electrolyte.  This anal. demonstrates that accurately accounting for XPS BE shifts as a function of current-bias conditions can provide a direct probe of ionic conductivities assocd. with battery materials.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGrUZ8bdag5q3LVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0liDuIG6KZVuiA"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhsV2lsL3K&amp;md5=82af44166b14a19629c7f138f2f154cb</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref17"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref17'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">17</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit17" data-doi="10.1021/ar400022u"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Blanc, F.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Leskes, M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Grey, C. P.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">In Situ Solid-State NMR Spectroscopy of Electrochemical Cells: Batteries, Supercapacitors, and Fuel Cells</span>. <i>Acc. Chem. Res.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2013</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>46</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">9</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">1952</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">1963</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/ar400022u</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D46%26publication_year%3D2013%26pages%3D1952-1963%26journal%3DAcc.%2BChem.%2BRes.%26issue%3D9%26author%3DF.%2BBlanc%26author%3DM.%2BLeskes%26author%3DC.%2BP.%2BGrey%26title%3DIn%2BSitu%2BSolid-State%2BNMR%2BSpectroscopy%2Bof%2BElectrochemical%2BCells%253A%2BBatteries%252C%2BSupercapacitors%252C%2Band%2BFuel%2BCells%26doi%3D10.1021%252Far400022u&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1021%2Far400022u&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit17R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">17</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">In situ solid-state NMR spectroscopy of electrochemical cells: batteries, supercapacitors, and fuel cells</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Blanc, Frederic; Leskes, Michal; Grey, Clare P.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Accounts of Chemical Research</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2013</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">46</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">9</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">1952-1963</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">ACHRE4</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0001-4842</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Review.  Electrochem. cells, in the form of batteries (or supercapacitors) and fuel cells, are efficient devices for energy storage and conversion.  These devices show considerable promise for use in portable and static devices to power electronics and various modes of transport and to produce and store electricity both locally and on the grid.  For example, high power and energy d. lithium-ion batteries are being developed for use in hybrid elec. vehicles where they improve the efficiency of fuel use and help to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.  To gain insight into the chem. reactions involving the multiple components (electrodes, electrolytes, interfaces) in the electrochem. cells and to det. how cells operate and how they fail, researchers ideally should employ techniques that allow real-time characterization of the behavior of the cells under operating conditions.  This Account reviews the recent use of in situ solid-state NMR spectroscopy, a technique that probes local structure and dynamics, to study these devices.  In situ NMR studies of lithium-ion batteries are performed on the entire battery, by using a coin cell design, a flat sealed plastic bag, or a cylindrical cell.  The battery is placed inside the NMR coil, leads are connected to a potentiostat, and the NMR spectra are recorded as a function of state of charge.  7Li is used for many of these expts. because of its high sensitivity, straightforward spectral interpretation, and relevance to these devices.  For example, 7Li spectroscopy was used to detect intermediates formed during electrochem. cycling such as LixC and LiySiz species in batteries with carbon and silicon anodes, resp.  It was also used to observe and quantify the formation and growth of metallic lithium microstructures, which can cause short circuits and battery failure.  This approach can be utilized to identify conditions that promote dendrite formation and whether different electrolytes and additives can help prevent dendrite formation.  The in situ method was also applied to monitor (by 11B NMR) electrochem. double-layer formation in supercapacitors in real time.  Though this method is useful, it comes with challenges.  The sepn. of the contributions from the different cell components in the NMR spectra is not trivial because of overlapping resonances.  In addn., orientation-dependent NMR interactions, including the spatial- and orientation-dependent bulk magnetic susceptibility (BMS) effects, can lead to resonance broadening.  Efforts to understand and mitigate these BMS effects are discussed in this Account.  The in situ NMR investigation of fuel cells initially focused on the surface electrochem. at the electrodes and the electrochem. oxidn. of methanol and CO to CO2 on the Pt cathode.  On the basis of the 13C and 195Pt NMR spectra of the adsorbates and electrodes, CO adsorbed on Pt and other reaction intermediates and complete oxidn. products were detected and their mode of binding to the electrodes investigated.  Appropriate design and engineering of the NMR hardware has allowed researchers to integrate intact direct methanol fuel cells into NMR probes.  Chem. transformations of the circulating methanol could be followed and reaction intermediates could be detected in real time by either 2H or 13C NMR spectroscopy.  By use of the in situ NMR approach, factors that control fuel cell performance, such as methanol cross over and catalyst performance, were identified.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGoOc6ZHVHr4lbVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0liDuIG6KZVuiA"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXpvFamt7c%253D&amp;md5=359fa644b00c7cb5b331334746c8b638</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref18"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref18'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">18</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit18" data-doi="10.1021/acs.chemmater.6b03183"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Pecher, O.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Carretero-González, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Griffith, K. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Grey, C. P.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Materials’ Methods: NMR in Battery Research</span>. <i>Chem. Mater.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2017</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>29</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">1</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">213</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">242</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/acs.chemmater.6b03183</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D29%26publication_year%3D2017%26pages%3D213-242%26journal%3DChem.%2BMater.%26issue%3D1%26author%3DO.%2BPecher%26author%3DJ.%2BCarretero-Gonz%25C3%25A1lez%26author%3DK.%2BJ.%2BGriffith%26author%3DC.%2BP.%2BGrey%26title%3DMaterials%25E2%2580%2599%2BMethods%253A%2BNMR%2Bin%2BBattery%2BResearch%26doi%3D10.1021%252Facs.chemmater.6b03183&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.6b03183&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit18R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">18</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Materials' Methods: NMR in Battery Research</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Pecher, Oliver; Carretero-Gonzalez, Javier; Griffith, Kent J.; Grey, Clare P.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Chemistry of Materials</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2017</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">29</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">1</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">213-242</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">CMATEX</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0897-4756</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A review is presented.  Improving electrochem. energy storage is one of the major issues of our time.  The search for new battery materials together with the drive to improve performance and lower cost of existing and new batteries is not without its challenges.  Success in these matters is undoubtedly based on first understanding the underlying chemistries of the materials and the relations between the components involved.  A combined application of exptl. and theor. techniques has proven to be a powerful strategy to gain insights into many of the questions that arise from the 'how do batteries work and why do they fail' challenge.  In this special issue we highlight the application of solid-state NMR (NMR) spectroscopy in battery research - a technique that can be extremely powerful in characterizing local structures in battery materials, even in highly disordered systems.  An introduction on electrochem. energy storage illustrates the research aims and prospective approaches to reach these.  We particularly address 'NMR in battery research' by giving a brief introduction to electrochem. techniques and applications as well as background information on both in and ex situ solid-state NMR spectroscopy.  We will try to answer the question 'Is NMR suitable and how can it help me to solve my problem' by shortly reviewing some of our recent research on electrodes, microstructure formation, electrolytes and interfaces, in which the application of NMR was helpful.  Finally, we share hands-on experience directly from the lab bench to answer the fundamental question 'Where and how should I start' to help guide a researcher's way through the manifold approaches possible.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGqSktNdpE_2crVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0liDuIG6KZVuiA"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhslCkt7jM&amp;md5=d150b75264cb232248a15ba33c102dd5</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref19"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref19'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">19</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit19" data-doi="10.1016/j.jmr.2023.107516"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Shan, P.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Chen, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Tao, M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Zhao, D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Lin, H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Fu, R.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Yang, Y.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">The Applications of Solid-State NMR and MRI Techniques in the Study of Rechargeable Sodium-Ion Batteries</span>. <i>J. Magn. Reson.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2023</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>353</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">107516</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1016/j.jmr.2023.107516</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D353%26publication_year%3D2023%26pages%3D107516%26journal%3DJ.%2BMagn.%2BReson.%26author%3DP.%2BShan%26author%3DJ.%2BChen%26author%3DM.%2BTao%26author%3DD.%2BZhao%26author%3DH.%2BLin%26author%3DR.%2BFu%26author%3DY.%2BYang%26title%3DThe%2BApplications%2Bof%2BSolid-State%2BNMR%2Band%2BMRI%2BTechniques%2Bin%2Bthe%2BStudy%2Bof%2BRechargeable%2BSodium-Ion%2BBatteries%26doi%3D10.1016%252Fj.jmr.2023.107516&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1016%2Fj.jmr.2023.107516&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit19R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">19</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">The applications of solid-state NMR and MRI techniques in the study of rechargeable sodium-ion batteries</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Shan, Peizhao; Chen, Junning; Tao, Mingming; Zhao, Danhui; Lin, Hongxin; Fu, Riqiang; Yang, Yong</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Magnetic Resonance</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2023</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">353</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue"></span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">107516</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JMARF3</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1090-7807</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Elsevier B.V.</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A review.  In order to develop new electrode and electrolyte materials for advanced sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), it is crucial to understand a no. of fundamental issues.  These include the compns. of the bulk and interface, the structures of the materials used, and the electrochem. reactions in the batteries.  Solid-state NMR (SS-NMR) has unique advantages in characterizing the local or microstructure of solid electrode/electrolyte materials and their interfaces-one such advantage is that these are detd. in a noninvasive and nondestructive manner at the at. level.  In this review, we provide a survey of the recent advances in the understanding of the fundamental issues of SIBs using advanced NMR techniques.  First, we summarize the applications of SS-NMR in characterizing electrode material structures and solid electrolyte interfaces (SEI).  In particular, we elucidate the key role of in-situ NMR/MRI in revealing the complex reactions and degrdn. mechanisms of SIBs.  Next, the characteristics and shortcomings of SS-NMR and MRI techniques in SIBs are also discussed in comparison to similar Li-ion batteries.  Finally, an overview of SS-NMR and MRI techniques for sodium batteries are briefly discussed and presented.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGocjzyfiety2bVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0liDuIG6KZVuiA"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3sXhsVWku7%252FO&amp;md5=2b2076acb73be8e8de82e7fc7774c208</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref20"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref20'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">20</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit20" data-doi="10.1002/adma.201706496"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Haber, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Leskes, M.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">What Can We Learn from Solid State NMR on the Electrode-Electrolyte Interface?</span>. <i>Adv.                 10.1002/adma.201706496</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D30%26publication_year%3D2018%26pages%3D1706496%26journal%3DAdv.%2BMater.%26issue%3D41%26author%3DS.%2BHaber%26author%3DM.%2BLeskes%26title%3DWhat%2BCan%2BWe%2BLearn%2Bfrom%2BSolid%2BState%2BNMR%2Bon%2Bthe%2BElectrode-Electrolyte%2BInterface%253F%26doi%3D10.1002%252Fadma.201706496&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1002%2Fadma.201706496&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord empty" id="

                        "><div class="casContent">There is no corresponding record for this reference.</div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref21"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref21'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">21</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit21" data-doi="10.1016/j.cocis.2022.101638"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Haworth, A.                 10.1016/j.cocis.2022.101638</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D62%26publication_year%3D2022%26pages%3D101638%26journal%3DCurr.%2BOpin.%2BColloid%2BInterface%2BSci.%26author%3DA.%2BR.%2BHaworth%26author%3DC.%2BW.%2BCook%26author%3DJ.%2BM.%2BGriffin%26title%3DSolid-State%2BNMR%2BStudies%2Bof%2BCoatings%2Band%2BInterfaces%2Bin%2BBatteries%26doi%3D10.1016%252Fj.cocis.2022.101638&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1016%2Fj.cocis.2022.101638&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord empty" id="

                10.1021/acs.chemmater.5b04408</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D28%26publication_year%3D2016%26pages%3D385-398%26journal%3DChem.%2BMater.%26issue%3D1%26author%3DA.%2BL.%2BMichan%26author%3DM.%2BLeskes%26author%3DC.%2BP.%2BGrey%26title%3DVoltage%2BDependent%2BSolid%2BElectrolyte%2BInterphase%2BFormation%2Bin%2BSilicon%2BElectrodes%253A%2BMonitoring%2Bthe%2BFormation%2Bof%2BOrganic%2BDecomposition%2BProducts%26doi%3D10.1021%252Facs.chemmater.5b04408&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.5b04408&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit22R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">22</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Voltage Dependent Solid Electrolyte Interphase Formation in Silicon Electrodes: Monitoring the Formation of Organic Decomposition Products</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Michan, Alison L.; Leskes, Michal; Grey, Clare P.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Chemistry of Materials</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2016</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">28</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">1</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">385-398</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">CMATEX</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0897-4756</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">The solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) passivating layer that grows on all battery electrodes during cycling is crit. to the long-term capacity retention of lithium-ion batteries.  Yet, it is inherently difficult to study because of its nanoscale thickness, amorphous composite structure, and air sensitivity.  Here, we employ an exptl. strategy using 1H, 7Li, 19F, and 13C solid-state NMR (ssNMR) to gain insight into the decompn. products in the SEI formed on silicon electrodes, the uncontrolled growth of the SEI representing a major failure mechanism that prevents the practical use of silicon in lithium-ion batteries.  The voltage dependent formation of the SEI is confirmed, with the SEI growth correlating with irreversible capacity.  By studying both conductive carbon and mixed Si/C composite electrodes sep., a correlation with increased capacity loss of the composite system and the low-voltage silicon plateau is demonstrated.  Using selective 13C labeling, we detect decompn. products of the electrolyte solvents ethylene carbonate (EC) and di-Me carbonate (DMC) independently.  EC decompn. products are present in higher concns. and are dominated by oligomer species.  Lithium semicarbonates, lithium fluoride, and lithium carbonate products are also seen.  Ab initio calcns. have been carried out to aid in the assignment of NMR shifts. ssNMR applied to both rinsed and unrinsed electrodes show that the orgs. are easily rinsed away, suggesting that they are located on the outer layer of the SEI.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGpBEe6q-VLOG7Vg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0liDuIG6KZVuiA"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhvVOrt77J&amp;md5=0a011397966da5021fbd00b331eb3687</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref23"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref23'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">23</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit23" data-doi="10.1149/1.3559551"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Leifer, N.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Smart, M.
