R.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Billaud, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Brutti, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Younesi, R.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Analysis of the Solid Electrolyte Interphase on Hard Carbon Electrodes in Sodium-Ion Batteries</span>. <i>ChemElectroChem</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2019</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>6</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">6</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">1745</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">1753</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1002/celc.201801621</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D6%26publication_year%3D2019%26pages%3D1745-1753%26journal%3DChemElectroChem%26issue%3D6%26author%3DM.%2BCarboni%26author%3DJ.%2BManzi%26author%3DA.%2BR.%2BArmstrong%26author%3DJ.%2BBillaud%26author%3DS.%2BBrutti%26author%3DR.%2BYounesi%26title%3DAnalysis%2Bof%2Bthe%2BSolid%2BElectrolyte%2BInterphase%2Bon%2BHard%2BCarbon%2BElectrodes%2Bin%2BSodium-Ion%2BBatteries%26doi%3D10.1002%252Fcelc.201801621&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1002%2Fcelc.201801621&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit46R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">46</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Analysis of the Solid Electrolyte Interphase on Hard Carbon Electrodes in Sodium-Ion Batteries</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Carboni, Marco; Manzi, Jessica; Armstrong, Antony Robert; Billaud, Juliette; Brutti, Serfio; Younesi, Reza</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">ChemElectroChem</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2019</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">6</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">6</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">1745-1753</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">CHEMRA</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">2196-0216</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH &amp; Co. KGaA</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">The compn., morphol., and evolution of the solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) formed on hard carbon (HC) electrodes upon cycling in sodium-ion batteries are investigated.  A microporous HC was prepd. by pyrolysis of D-(+)-glucose at 1000°C followed by ball-milling.  HC electrodes were galvanostatically cycled at room temp. in sodium-ion half-cells using an aprotic electrolyte of 1 M sodium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide dissolved in propylene carbonate with 3 wt % fluoroethylene carbonate additive.  The evolution of the electrode/electrolyte interface was studied by impedance spectroscopy upon cycling and ex situ by spectroscopy and microscopy.  The irreversible capacity displayed by the HC electrodes in the first galvanostatic cycle is probably due to the accumulation of redox inactive NaxC phases and the pptn. of a porous, org.-inorg. hybrid SEI layer over the HC electrodes.  This passivation film further evolves in morphol. and compn. upon cycling and stabilizes after approx. ten galvanostatic cycles at low current rates.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGoxfxYGHDiWH7Vg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lisgzSYwz1foA"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXislCitb4%253D&amp;md5=f270889f543452dd44280d802b0dbbd7</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref47"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref47'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">47</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit47" data-doi="10.1039/D0EE03916K"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Chen, D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Zhang, W.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Luo, K.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Song, Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Zhong, Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Liu, Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Wang, G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Zhong, B.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Wu, Z.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Guo, X.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Hard Carbon for Sodium Storage: Mechanism and Optimization Strategies toward Commercialization</span>. <i>Energy Environ. Sci.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2021</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>14</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">4</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">2244</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">2262</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1039/D0EE03916K</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D14%26publication_year%3D2021%26pages%3D2244-2262%26journal%3DEnergy%2BEnviron.%2BSci.%26issue%3D4%26author%3DD.%2BChen%26author%3DW.%2BZhang%26author%3DK.%2BLuo%26author%3DY.%2BSong%26author%3DY.%2BZhong%26author%3DY.%2BLiu%26author%3DG.%2BWang%26author%3DB.%2BZhong%26author%3DZ.%2BWu%26author%3DX.%2BGuo%26title%3DHard%2BCarbon%2Bfor%2BSodium%2BStorage%253A%2BMechanism%2Band%2BOptimization%2BStrategies%2Btoward%2BCommercialization%26doi%3D10.1039%252FD0EE03916K&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1039%2FD0EE03916K&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit47R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">47</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Hard carbon for sodium storage: mechanism and optimization strategies toward commercialization</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Chen, Dequan; Zhang, Wen; Luo, Kangying; Song, Yang; Zhong, Yanjun; Liu, Yuxia; Wang, Gongke; Zhong, Benhe; Wu, Zhenguo; Guo, Xiaodong</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Energy &amp; Environmental Science</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2021</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">14</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">4</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">2244-2262</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">EESNBY</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1754-5706</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Royal Society of Chemistry</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) have shown promising prospects for complementarity to lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) in the field of grid-scale energy storage.  After a decade of continuous fundamental research on SIBs, it's becoming increasingly urgent to advance the commercialization.  For SIB anode materials, hard carbon is the most mature and currently the only material likely to be commercialized, but it is still far away from large-scale industrialization.  Herein, we carry out a comprehensive overview of the current state of the art in terms of three main aspects.  Firstly, a fundamental understanding of the microstructure and sodium storage mechanism of hard carbon is introduced, which can be categorized into three different processes: capacitive adsorption, nanopore filling, and intercalation in carbon interlayers.  Then, based on an in-depth understanding of the sodium storage mechanism, optimization methods in terms of increasing the specific capacity, rate performance, initial coulombic efficiency (ICE), and long-cycling stability are comprehensively summarized and analyzed.  Finally, potential methods and assocd. benefits for the design of carbon structures and the solid electrolyte interface (SEI) are discussed, hoping to provide useful guidelines for future research and commercialization.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGo4e0jCHDDXgrVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lisgzSYwz1foA"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3MXntlSjsb8%253D&amp;md5=d979cb5c94cd743b47028b42d41754fa</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref48"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref48'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">48</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit48" data-doi="10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00642"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Lee, B.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Paek, E.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Mitlin, D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Lee, S. W.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Sodium Metal Anodes: Emerging Solutions to Dendrite Growth</span>. <i>Chem. Rev.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2019</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>119</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">8</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">5416</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">5460</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00642</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D119%26publication_year%3D2019%26pages%3D5416-5460%26journal%3DChem.%2BRev.%26issue%3D8%26author%3DB.%2BLee%26author%3DE.%2BPaek%26author%3DD.%2BMitlin%26author%3DS.%2BW.%2BLee%26title%3DSodium%2BMetal%2BAnodes%253A%2BEmerging%2BSolutions%2Bto%2BDendrite%2BGrowth%26doi%3D10.1021%252Facs.chemrev.8b00642&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1021%2Facs.chemrev.8b00642&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit48R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">48</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Sodium metal anodes: Emerging solutions to dendrite growth</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Lee, Byeongyong; Paek, Eunsu; Mitlin, David; Lee, Seung Woo</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States)</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2019</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">119</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">8</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">5416-5460</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">CHREAY</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0009-2665</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">This comprehensive Review focuses on the key challenges and recent progress regarding sodium-metal anodes employed in sodium-metal batteries (SMBs).  The metal anode is the essential component of emerging energy storage systems such as sodium sulfur and sodium selenium, which are discussed as example full-cell applications.  We begin with a description of the differences in the chem. and phys. properties of Na metal vs. the oft-studied Li metal, and a corresponding discussion regarding the no. of ways in which Na does not follow Li-inherited paradigms in its electrochem. behavior.  We detail the major challenges for Na-metal systems that at this time limit the feasibility of SMBs.  The core Na anode problems are the following interrelated degrdn. mechanisms: An unstable solid electrolyte interphase with most org. electrolytes, "mossy" and "lath-like" metal dendrite growth for liq. systems, poor Coulombic efficiency, and gas evolution.  Even solid-state Na batteries are not immune, with metal dendrites being reported.  The solns. may be subdivided into the following interrelated taxonomy: Improved electrolytes and electrolyte additives tailored for Na-metal anodes, interfacial engineering between the metal and the liq. or solid electrolyte, electrode architectures that both reduce the c.d. during plating-stripping and serve as effective hosts that shield the Na metal from excessive reactions, and alloy design to tune the bulk properties of the metal per se.  For instance, stable plating-stripping of Na is extremely difficult with conventional carbonate solvents but has been reported with ethers and glymes.  Solid-state electrolytes (SSEs) such as beta-alumina solid electrolyte (BASE), sodium superionic conductor (NASICON), and sodium thiophosphate (75Na2S·25P2S5) present highly exciting opportunities for SMBs that avoid the dangers of flammable liqs.  Even SSEs are not immune to dendrites, however, which grow through the defects in the bulk pellet, but may be controlled through interfacial energy modification.  We conclude with a discussion of the key research areas that we feel are the most fruitful for further pursuit.  In our opinion, greatly improved understanding and control of the SEI structure is the key to cycling stability.  A holistic approach involving complementary post-mortem, in situ, and operando analyses to elucidate full battery cell level structure-performance relations is advocated.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGqQ1buYt3eMx7Vg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lisgzSYwz1foA"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXmsFCrtL4%253D&amp;md5=50399f6bff0463f55ea84f50d36fb802</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref49"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref49'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">49</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit49" data-doi="10.1038/s41467-020-15938-x"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Bray, J. M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Doswell, C. L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Pavlovskaya, G. E.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Chen, L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kishore, B.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Au, H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Alptekin, H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kendrick, E.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Titirici, M.-M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Meersmann, T.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Britton, M. M.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Operando Visualisation of Battery Chemistry in a Sodium-Ion Battery by 23Na Magnetic Resonance Imaging</span>. <i>Nat. Commun.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2020</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>11</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">1</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">2083</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1038/s41467-020-15938-x</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D11%26publication_year%3D2020%26pages%3D2083%26journal%3DNat.%2BCommun.%26issue%3D1%26author%3DJ.%2BM.%2BBray%26author%3DC.%2BL.%2BDoswell%26author%3DG.%2BE.%2BPavlovskaya%26author%3DL.%2BChen%26author%3DB.%2BKishore%26author%3DH.%2BAu%26author%3DH.%2BAlptekin%26author%3DE.%2BKendrick%26author%3DM.-M.%2BTitirici%26author%3DT.%2BMeersmann%26author%3DM.%2BM.%2BBritton%26title%3DOperando%2BVisualisation%2Bof%2BBattery%2BChemistry%2Bin%2Ba%2BSodium-Ion%2BBattery%2Bby%2B23Na%2BMagnetic%2BResonance%2BImaging%26doi%3D10.1038%252Fs41467-020-15938-x&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1038%2Fs41467-020-15938-x&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit49R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">49</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Operando visualisation of battery chemistry in a sodium-ion battery by 23Na magnetic resonance imaging</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Bray, Joshua M.; Doswell, Claire L.; Pavlovskaya, Galina E.; Chen, Lin; Kishore, Brij; Au, Heather; Alptekin, Hande; Kendrick, Emma; Titirici, Maria-Magdalena; Meersmann, Thomas; Britton, Melanie M.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Nature Communications</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2020</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">11</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">1</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">2083</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">NCAOBW</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">2041-1723</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Nature Research</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Sodium-ion batteries are a promising battery technol. for their cost and sustainability.  This has led to increasing interest in the development of new sodium-ion batteries and new anal. methods to non-invasively, directly visualise battery chem.  Here we report operando 1H and 23Na NMR spectroscopy and imaging expts. to observe the speciation and distribution of sodium in the electrode and electrolyte during sodiation and desodiation of hard carbon in a sodium metal cell and a sodium-ion full-cell configuration.  The evolution of the hard carbon sodiation and subsequent formation and evolution of sodium dendrites, upon over-sodiation of the hard carbon, are obsd. and mapped by 23Na NMR spectroscopy and imaging, and their three-dimensional microstructure visualised by 1H magnetic resonance imaging.  We also observe, for the first time, the formation of metallic sodium species on hard carbon upon first charge (formation) in a full-cell configuration.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGqlISiMMjJe-bVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lgKrINe9_gsbQ"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXosVOmu7w%253D&amp;md5=dd9f9f777d0e67de51e9f0c49bd5a1e0</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref50"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref50'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">50</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit50" data-doi="10.1039/C6TA04611H"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Mei, Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Huang, Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hu, X.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Nanostructured Ti-Based Anode Materials for Na-Ion Batteries</span>. <i>J. Mater. Chem. A</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2016</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>4</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">31</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">12001</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">12013</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1039/C6TA04611H</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D4%26publication_year%3D2016%26pages%3D12001-12013%26journal%3DJ.%2BMater.%2BChem.%2BA%26issue%3D31%26author%3DY.%2BMei%26author%3DY.%2BHuang%26author%3DX.%2BHu%26title%3DNanostructured%2BTi-Based%2BAnode%2BMaterials%2Bfor%2BNa-Ion%2BBatteries%26doi%3D10.1039%252FC6TA04611H&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1039%2FC6TA04611H&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit50R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">50</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Nanostructured Ti-based anode materials for Na-ion batteries</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Mei, Yueni; Huang, Yunhui; Hu, Xianluo</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2016</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">4</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">31</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">12001-12013</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JMCAET</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">2050-7496</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Royal Society of Chemistry</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">With the shortage of fossil energy and global climate change, renewable energy sources offer the most promising solns. to these challenges.  However, the intermittence of energy sources such as solar and wind requires sustainable energy storage technologies.  Nowadays, electrochem. energy storage technologies and applications have attracted much attention, including portable elec. devices, elec. vehicles and smart power grids.  Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have been widely applied in these areas because of their safety, portability and high energy d.  Nevertheless, the resources of lithium are limited and the vast consumption of lithium has pushed up the price of lithium compds., urging people to search for resourceful materials.  Sodium can be a promising alternative due to its high abundance and low cost.  Furthermore, titanium-based materials have become a hot spot for anode materials in sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), with their advantages of high safety and structural stability.  In this review, we summarize the recent advances in Ti-based anode materials for SIB applications.  We highlight the design and engineering of Ti-based nanoarchitectures, esp. emphasizing the effective enhancement in performance and the related sodium storage mechanism.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGpa4N56ebVXIbVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lgKrINe9_gsbQ"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhtVynt73M&amp;md5=40308f2ab8b2beb4f73c5fe67992c973</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref51"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref51'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">51</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit51" data-doi="10.1038/ncomms2878"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Sun, Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Zhao, L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Pan, H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Lu, X.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Gu, L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hu, Y.-S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Li, H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Armand, M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ikuhara, Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Chen, L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Huang, X.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Direct Atomic-Scale Confirmation of Three-Phase Storage Mechanism in Li4Ti5O12 Anodes for Room-Temperature Sodium-Ion Batteries</span>. <i>Nat. Commun.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2013</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>4</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">1</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">1870</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1038/ncomms2878</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D4%26publication_year%3D2013%26pages%3D1870%26journal%3DNat.%2BCommun.%26issue%3D1%26author%3DY.%2BSun%26author%3DL.%2BZhao%26author%3DH.%2BPan%26author%3DX.%2BLu%26author%3DL.%2BGu%26author%3DY.-S.%2BHu%26author%3DH.%2BLi%26author%3DM.%2BArmand%26author%3DY.%2BIkuhara%26author%3DL.%2BChen%26author%3DX.%2BHuang%26title%3DDirect%2BAtomic-Scale%2BConfirmation%2Bof%2BThree-Phase%2BStorage%2BMechanism%2Bin%2BLi4Ti5O12%2BAnodes%2Bfor%2BRoom-Temperature%2BSodium-Ion%2BBatteries%26doi%3D10.1038%252Fncomms2878&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1038%2Fncomms2878&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit51R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">51</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Direct atomic-scale confirmation of three-phase storage mechanism in Li4Ti5O12 anodes for room-temperature sodium-ion batteries</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Sun Yang; Zhao Liang; Pan Huilin; Lu Xia; Gu Lin; Hu Yong-Sheng; Li Hong; Armand Michel; Ikuhara Yuichi; Chen Liquan; Huang Xuejie</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Nature communications</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2013</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">4</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue"></span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">1870</span>
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn"></span>.
    </div><div class="casAbstract">Room-temperature sodium-ion batteries attract increasing attention for large-scale energy storage applications in renewable energy and smart grid.  However, the development of suitable anode materials remains a challenging issue.  Here we demonstrate that the spinel Li4Ti5O12, well-known as a 'zero-strain' anode for lithium-ion batteries, can also store sodium, displaying an average storage voltage of 0.91 V.  With an appropriate binder, the Li4Ti5O12 electrode delivers a reversible capacity of 155 mAh g(-1) and presents the best cyclability among all reported oxide-based anode materials.  Density functional theory calculations predict a three-phase separation mechanism, 2Li4Ti5O12+6Na(+)+6e(-)↔Li7Ti5O12+Na6LiTi5O12, which has been confirmed through in situ synchrotron X-ray diffraction and advanced scanning transmission electron microscope imaging techniques.  The three-phase separation reaction has never been seen in any insertion electrode materials for lithium- or sodium-ion batteries.  Furthermore, interfacial structure is clearly resolved at an atomic scale in electrochemically sodiated Li4Ti5O12 for the first time via the advanced electron microscopy.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=LOZGTtr2ZcQPgY8GEu_hzRKDYG3bNImrfW6udTcc2eb-Rnof7boISbntkvexoksv"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC3snlvFClsQ%253D%253D&amp;md5=1ba227dbac0d64af21c548092cc2eb4c</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref52"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref52'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">52</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit52" data-doi="10.1002/smll.201904484"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Natarajan, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Subramanyan, K.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Aravindan, V.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Focus on Spinel Li <sub>4</sub> Ti <sub>5</sub> O <sub>12</sub> as Insertion Type Anode for High-Performance Na-Ion Batteries</span>. <i>Small</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2019</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>15</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">49</span>), <span class="NLM_elocation-id">e1904484</span> <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1002/smll.201904484</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D15%26publication_year%3D2019%26journal%3DSmall%26issue%3D49%26author%3DS.%2BNatarajan%26author%3DK.%2BSubramanyan%26author%3DV.%2BAravindan%26title%3DFocus%2Bon%2BSpinel%2BLi%2B4%2BTi%2B5%2BO%2B12%2Bas%2BInsertion%2BType%2BAnode%2Bfor%2BHigh-Performance%2BNa-Ion%2BBatteries%26doi%3D10.1002%252Fsmll.201904484&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1002%2Fsmll.201904484&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord empty" id="
                            cas_R
                        "><div class="casContent">There is no corresponding record for this reference.</div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref53"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref53'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">53</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit53" data-doi="10.1149/2.100112jes"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Xiong, D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Burns, J. C.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Smith, A. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Sinha, N.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Dahn, J. R.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">A High Precision Study of the Effect of Vinylene Carbonate (VC) Additive in Li/Graphite Cells</span>. <i>J. Electrochem. Soc.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2011</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>158</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">12</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">A1431</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1149/2.100112jes</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D158%26publication_year%3D2011%26pages%3DA1431%26journal%3DJ.%2BElectrochem.%2BSoc.%26issue%3D12%26author%3DD.%2BXiong%26author%3DJ.%2BC.%2BBurns%26author%3DA.%2BJ.%2BSmith%26author%3DN.%2BSinha%26author%3DJ.%2BR.%2BDahn%26title%3DA%2BHigh%2BPrecision%2BStudy%2Bof%2Bthe%2BEffect%2Bof%2BVinylene%2BCarbonate%2B%2528VC%2529%2BAdditive%2Bin%2BLi%252FGraphite%2BCells%26doi%3D10.1149%252F2.100112jes&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1149%2F2.100112jes&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit53R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">53</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">A high precision study of the effect of vinylene carbonate (VC) additive in Li/graphite cells</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Xiong, Deijun; Burns, J. C.; Smith, A. J.; Sinha, Nupur; Dahn, J. R.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of the Electrochemical Society</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2011</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">158</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">12</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">A1431-A1435</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JESOAN</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0013-4651</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Electrochemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Li/graphite coin cells contg. different amts. of vinylene carbonate (VC) electrolyte additive were examd. at different temps. using the High Precision Charger at Dalhousie University.  The charge endpoint capacities as well as the coulombic efficiency (CE) were compared to characterize the effect of the VC additive on the graphite electrode.  The expts. show that VC improves the coulombic efficiency and reduces charge and discharge endpoint slippage at 50 and 60°C.  However, the addn. of VC has little evident effect on the performance of the graphite electrode at 30 and 40°C and also increases the irreversible capacity.  By contrast, addns. of VC have a marked impact on the coulombic efficiency and slippages of NMC pos. electrodes, even at 30°C.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGoV1afo2gycNLVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lgKrINe9_gsbQ"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhsVyks7jF&amp;md5=4bc3ac9566fbb0c9398a5ca90e7b16dd</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref54"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref54'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">54</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit54" data-doi="10.1021/acs.chemmater.5b01627"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Schroder, K.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Alvarado, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Yersak, T. A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Li, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Dudney, N.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Webb, L. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Meng, Y. S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Stevenson, K. J.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">The Effect of Fluoroethylene Carbonate as an Additive on the Solid Electrolyte Interphase on Silicon Lithium-Ion Electrodes</span>. <i>Chem. Mater.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2015</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>27</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">16</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">5531</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">5542</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/acs.chemmater.5b01627</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D27%26publication_year%3D2015%26pages%3D5531-5542%26journal%3DChem.%2BMater.%26issue%3D16%26author%3DK.%2BSchroder%26author%3DJ.%2BAlvarado%26author%3DT.%2BA.%2BYersak%26author%3DJ.%2BLi%26author%3DN.%2BDudney%26author%3DL.%2BJ.%2BWebb%26author%3DY.%2BS.%2BMeng%26author%3DK.%2BJ.%2BStevenson%26title%3DThe%2BEffect%2Bof%2BFluoroethylene%2BCarbonate%2Bas%2Ban%2BAdditive%2Bon%2Bthe%2BSolid%2BElectrolyte%2BInterphase%2Bon%2BSilicon%2BLithium-Ion%2BElectrodes%26doi%3D10.1021%252Facs.chemmater.5b01627&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.5b01627&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit54R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">54</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">The Effect of Fluoroethylene Carbonate as an Additive on the Solid Electrolyte Interphase on Silicon Lithium-Ion Electrodes</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Schroder, Kjell; Alvarado, Judith; Yersak, Thomas A.; Li, Juchuan; Dudney, Nancy; Webb, Lauren J.; Meng, Ying Shirley; Stevenson, Keith J.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Chemistry of Materials</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2015</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">27</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">16</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">5531-5542</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">CMATEX</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0897-4756</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) has become a std. electrolyte additive for use with Si neg. electrodes, but how FEC affects solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) formation on the Si anode's surface is still not well understood.  Herein, SEI formed from LiPF6-based carbonate electrolytes, with and without FEC, were studied on 50 nm thick amorphous Si thin film electrodes to understand the role of FEC on Si electrode surface reactions.  In contrast to previous work, anhyd. and anoxic techniques were used to prevent air and moisture contamination of prepd. SEI films.  This allowed for accurate characterization of the SEI structure and compn. by XPS and time-of-flight secondary ion mass spectrometry depth profiling.  FEC redn. leads to F- ion and LiF formation, consistent with previous computational and exptl. results.  Surprisingly, also these species decrease Li-ion soly. and increase the reactivity of the Si surface.  The effectiveness of FEC at improving the Coulombic efficiency and capacity retention is due to F- ion formation from redn. of the electrolyte, which leads to the chem. attack of any Si-oxide surface passivation layers and the formation of a kinetically stable SEI comprising predominately LiF and Li oxide.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGqSv3p3Tp69f7Vg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lgKrINe9_gsbQ"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXht1OqsbzJ&amp;md5=e86fa14fac83156dfafd6d6eed502ba8</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref55"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref55'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">55</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit55" data-doi="10.1021/acsenergylett.0c00468"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kim, K.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ma, H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Park, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Choi, N.-S.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Electrolyte-Additive-Driven Interfacial Engineering for High-Capacity Electrodes in Lithium-Ion Batteries: Promise and Challenges</span>. <i>ACS Energy Lett.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2020</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>5</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">5</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">1537</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">1553</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/acsenergylett.0c00468</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D5%26publication_year%3D2020%26pages%3D1537-1553%26journal%3DACS%2BEnergy%2BLett.%26issue%3D5%26author%3DK.%2BKim%26author%3DH.%2BMa%26author%3DS.%2BPark%26author%3DN.-S.%2BChoi%26title%3DElectrolyte-Additive-Driven%2BInterfacial%2BEngineering%2Bfor%2BHigh-Capacity%2BElectrodes%2Bin%2BLithium-Ion%2BBatteries%253A%2BPromise%2Band%2BChallenges%26doi%3D10.1021%252Facsenergylett.0c00468&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1021%2Facsenergylett.0c00468&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit55R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">55</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Electrolyte-Additive-Driven Interfacial Engineering for High-Capacity Electrodes in Lithium-Ion Batteries: Promise and Challenges</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Kim, Koeun; Ma, Hyunsoo; Park, Sewon; Choi, Nam-Soon</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">ACS Energy Letters</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2020</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">5</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">5</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">1537-1553</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">AELCCP</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">2380-8195</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A review.  Electrolyte additives have been explored to attain significant breakthroughs in the long-term cycling performance of lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) without sacrificing energy d.; this has been achieved through the development of stable electrode interfacial structures and the elimination of reactive substances.  Here we highlight the potential and the challenges raised by studies on electrolyte additives toward addressing the interfacially induced deterioration of high-capacity electrodes with a focus on Ni-rich layered oxides and Si, which are expected to satisfy the growing demands for high-energy-d. batteries.  We also discuss issues with the design of electrolyte additives for practical viability.  A deep understanding of the roles of existing electrolyte additives depending on their functional groups will aid in the design of functional additive moieties capable of building robust interfacial layers, scavenging undesired reactive species, and suppressing the gas generation that causes safety hazards and shortened lifetimes of LIBs.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGotA865zYIcA7Vg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0ljZMR1_n-eYcg"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXmsV2gtbo%253D&amp;md5=13a54ec47122b6c29d5ecff4ca94473d</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref56"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref56'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">56</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit56" data-doi="10.1021/acs.chemmater.6b02282"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Michan, A. L.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Fluoroethylene Carbonate and Vinylene Carbonate Reduction: Understanding Lithium-Ion Battery Electrolyte Additives and Solid Electrolyte Interphase Formation</span>. <i>Chem.                 10.1021/acs.chemmater.6b02282</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D28%26publication_year%3D2016%26pages%3D8149-8159%26journal%3DChem.%2BMater.%26issue%3D22%26author%3DA.%2BL.%2BMichan%26author%3DB.%2BS.%2BParimalam%26author%3DM.%2BLeskes%26author%3DR.%2BN.%2BKerber%26author%3DT.%2BYoon%26author%3DC.%2BP.%2BGrey%26author%3DB.%2BL.%2BLucht%26title%3DFluoroethylene%2BCarbonate%2Band%2BVinylene%2BCarbonate%2BReduction%253A%2BUnderstanding%2BLithium-Ion%2BBattery%2BElectrolyte%2BAdditives%2Band%2BSolid%2BElectrolyte%2BInterphase%2BFormation%26doi%3D10.1021%252Facs.chemmater.6b02282&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.6b02282&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit56R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">56</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Fluoroethylene Carbonate and Vinylene Carbonate Reduction: Understanding Lithium-Ion Battery Electrolyte Additives and Solid Electrolyte Interphase Formation</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Michan, Alison L.; Parimalam, Bharathy. S.; Leskes, Michal; Kerber, Rachel N.; Yoon, Taeho; Grey, Clare P.; Lucht, Brett L.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Chemistry of Materials</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2016</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">28</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">22</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">8149-8159</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">CMATEX</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0897-4756</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">We have synthesized the products of fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) and vinylene carbonate (VC) via lithium naphthalenide redn.  By analyzing the resulting solid ppts. and gas evolution, our results confirm that both FEC and VC decompn. products include HCO2Li, Li2C2O4, Li2CO3, and polymd. VC.  For FEC, our exptl. data supports a redn. mechanism where FEC reduces to form VC and LiF, followed by subsequent VC redn.  In the FEC redn. product, HCO2Li, Li2C2O4, and Li2CO3 were found in smaller quantities than in the VC redn. product, with no addnl. fluorine environments being detected by solid-state NMR or XPS anal.  With these additives being practically used in higher (FEC) and lower (VC) concns. in the base electrolytes of lithium-ion batteries, our results suggest that the different relative ratios of the inorg. and org. redn. products formed by their decompn. may be relevant to the chem. compn. and morphol. of the solid electrolyte interphase formed in their presence.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGqRaEl0XEDeCLVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0ljZMR1_n-eYcg"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28Xhs1ylurvP&amp;md5=42c57482d705b409e35d7bd110357adf</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref57"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref57'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">57</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit57" data-doi="10.1149/1945-7111/ab75fd"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Fondard, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Irisarri, E.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Courrèges, C.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Palacin, M. Electrochem. Soc.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2020</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>167</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">7</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">070526</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1149/1945-7111/ab75fd</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D167%26publication_year%3D2020%26pages%3D070526%26journal%3DJ.%2BElectrochem.%2BSoc.%26issue%3D7%26author%3DJ.%2BFondard%26author%3DE.%2BIrisarri%26author%3DC.%2BCourr%25C3%25A8ges%26author%3DM.%2BR.%2BPalacin%26author%3DA.%2BPonrouch%26author%3DR.%2BDedryv%25C3%25A8re%26title%3DSEI%2BComposition%2Bon%2BHard%2BCarbon%2Bin%2BNa-Ion%2BBatteries%2BAfter%2BLong%2BCycling%253A%2BInfluence%2Bof%2BSalts%2B%2528NaPF%2B6%252C%2BNaTFSI%2529%2Band%2BAdditives%2B%2528FEC%252C%2BDMCF%2529%26doi%3D10.1149%252F1945-7111%252Fab75fd&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1149%2F1945-7111%2Fab75fd&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit57R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">57</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">SEI composition on hard carbon in Na-Ion batteries after long cycling: Influence of salts (NaPF6, NaTFSI) and Additives (FEC, DMCF)</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Fondard, J.; Irisarri, E.; Courreges, C.; Palacin, M. R.; Ponrouch, A.; Dedryvere, R.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of the Electrochemical Society</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2020</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">167</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">7</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">070526</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JESOAN</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0013-4651</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Electrochemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A study of the solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) on hard-carbon (HC) electrodes in sodium half-cells is presented.  Electrochem. performances over &gt; 100 cycles were compared with two different salts (NaPF6, NaTFSI) and two different electrolyte additives (FEC, DMCF) in a mixt. of EC and DMC solvents.  The best electrochem. performances were obsd. with NaPF6 salt in conjunction with 3% FEC.  The DMCF additive had a detrimental effect in all electrolyte combinations.  The chem. characterization of the SEI was carried out by XPS and showed that the best electrochem. behavior was related to an SEI compn. based on sodium ethylene dicarbonate and NaF, whereas poorer electrochem. performances were assocd. to either low NaF or high Na2CO3 content.  The results reported herein provide an insight on the SEI chem. on hard carbon electrodes in sodium cells after long-term cycling, as a complement to previous studies dealing with the first cycles.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGq4rxL0JhE-c7Vg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0ljZMR1_n-eYcg"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXosVKisL0%253D&amp;md5=fc871aceb661bd6af19f8153b66817bd</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref58"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref58'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">58</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit58" data-doi="10.1002/celc.201600365"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Dahbi, M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Chihara, K.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kubota, K.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Son, J.</span></span>;                 10.1002/celc.201600365</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D3%26publication_year%3D2016%26pages%3D1856-1867%26journal%3DChemElectroChem%26issue%3D11%26author%3DM.%2BDahbi%26author%3DT.%2BNakano%26author%3DN.%2BYabuuchi%26author%3DS.%2BFujimura%26author%3DK.%2BChihara%26author%3DK.%2BKubota%26author%3DJ.%2BSon%26author%3DY.%2BCui%26author%3DH.%2BOji%26author%3DS.%2BKomaba%26title%3DEffect%2Bof%2BHexafluorophosphate%2Band%2BFluoroethylene%2BCarbonate%2Bon%2BElectrochemical%2BPerformance%2Band%2Bthe%2BSurface%2BLayer%2Bof%2BHard%2BCarbon%2Bfor%2BSodium-Ion%2BBatteries%26doi%3D10.1002%252Fcelc.201600365&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1002%2Fcelc.201600365&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit58R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">58</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Effect of Hexafluorophosphate and Fluoroethylene Carbonate on Electrochemical Performance and Surface Layer of Hard Carbon for Sodium-Ion Batteries</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Dahbi, Mouad; Nakano, Takeshi; Yabuuchi, Naoaki; Fujimura, Shun; Chihara, Kuniko; Son, Jin-Young; Cui, Yi-Tao; Oji, Hiroshi; Komaba, Shinichi</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">ChemElectroChem</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2016</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">3</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">11</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">1856-1867</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">CHEMRA</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">2196-0216</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH &amp; Co. KGaA</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Electrochem. sodium insertion for hard carbon is examd. in a cyclic alkylene carbonate-based soln. contg. sodium perchlorate (NaClO4) or sodium hexafluorophosphate (NaPF6) salt with fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) additive to study electrolyte dependency for Na-ion batteries.  NaPF6-based electrolytes provided superior reversibility and cyclability of sodium insertion into hard carbon compared to NaClO4-based ones.  The FEC-derived passivation film improves the capacity retention because of better passivation with a thinner surface layer, which is revealed by hard and soft XPS (PES).  Using both the NaPF6 salt and FEC additive results in a synergetic effect on passivation for the hard-carbon electrode, leading to enhanced cycle performance.  Hard-carbon electrodes with poly (vinylede difluoride) binder in propylene carbonate-based electrolytes contg. NaPF6 and FEC demonstrates the excellent capacity retention with reversible capacity of ca. 250 mAh g-1.  The difference in capacity retention for the electrolytes is expected to originate from a consequence of the difference in the surface interphase layer formed on the hard-carbon electrodes.  Surface analyses with PES and time-of-flight secondary ion mass spectroscopy revealed differences in surface and passivation chem., which depends on the salts, solvents, and FEC additive used for the hard-carbon neg. electrodes.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGoT-YhGkJXMTrVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0ljZMR1_n-eYcg"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhtlegtbzP&amp;md5=f7d038a8c9ca89bf77adff243608c016</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref59"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref59'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">59</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit59" data-doi="10.1016/j.elecom.2012.10.038"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ponrouch, A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Goñi, A. R.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Palacín, M. R.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">High Capacity Hard Carbon Anodes for Sodium Ion Batteries in Additive Free Electrolyte</span>. <i>Electrochem. Commun.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2013</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>27</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">85</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">88</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1016/j.elecom.2012.10.038</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D27%26publication_year%3D2013%26pages%3D85-88%26journal%3DElectrochem.%2BCommun.%26author%3DA.%2BPonrouch%26author%3DA.%2BR.%2BGo%25C3%25B1i%26author%3DM.%2BR.%2BPalac%25C3%25ADn%26title%3DHigh%2BCapacity%2BHard%2BCarbon%2BAnodes%2Bfor%2BSodium%2BIon%2BBatteries%2Bin%2BAdditive%2BFree%2BElectrolyte%26doi%3D10.1016%252Fj.elecom.2012.10.038&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1016%2Fj.elecom.2012.10.038&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit59R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">59</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">High capacity hard carbon anodes for sodium ion batteries in additive free electrolyte</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Ponrouch, A.; Goni, A. R.; Palacin, M. Rosa</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Electrochemistry Communications</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2013</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">27</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue"></span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">85-88</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">ECCMF9</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1388-2481</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Elsevier B.V.</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Electrochem. performance of hard carbon prepd. from sugar pyrolysis was investigated against sodium anodes.  Sp. surface area and graphitization degree are determinant for achieving the highest reversible capacity ever reported (more than 300 mAh/g at C/10 after 120 cycles) with excellent rate capability.  Such results were obtained using additive free EC:PC based electrolyte which appears to induce the formation of a more conducting solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) than that produced in the presence of 2% fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC).</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGo1-09s1Aql_7Vg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0ljZMR1_n-eYcg"> &gt;&gt;                         cas_cit60R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">60</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Sodium carboxymethyl cellulose as a potential binder for hard-carbon negative electrodes in sodium-ion batteries</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Dahbi, Mouad; Nakano, Takeshi; Yabuuchi, Naoaki; Ishikawa, Toru; Kubota, Kei; Fukunishi, Mika; Shibahara, Sota; Son, Jin-Young; Cui, Yi-Tao; Oji, Hiroshi; Komaba, Shinichi</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Electrochemistry Communications</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2014</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">44</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue"></span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">66-69</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">ECCMF9</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1388-2481</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Elsevier B.V.</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">For a non-aq. sodium-ion battery, a hard-carbon neg. electrode with sodium CM-cellulose (CMC) binder demonstrates the superior reversibility and cycleability in NaPF6 propylene carbonate soln. at room temp. to that with ordinary poly(vinylidene difluoride) (PVdF) binder.  Furthermore, effects of monofluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) additive remarkably depend on the combination with binders, CMC and PVdF.  Surface analyses reveal considerable differences in surface and passivation chem. which depends on the binders and FEC additive used for the hard-carbon neg. electrodes.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGoXMgvubxGGmLVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lhjTjL4HNtKaA"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXovFKgsLY%253D&amp;md5=593095f9e512c9979257eeeabee78280</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref61"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref61'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">61</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit61" data-doi="10.1021/acsami.5b02904"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Yildirim, H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kinaci, A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Chan, M. K. Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Greeley, J. P.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">First-Principles Analysis of Defect Thermodynamics and Ion Transport in Inorganic SEI Compounds: LiF and NaF</span>. <i>ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2015</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>7</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">34</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">18985</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">18996</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/acsami.5b02904</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D7%26publication_year%3D2015%26pages%3D18985-18996%26journal%3DACS%2BAppl.%2BMater.%2BInterfaces%26issue%3D34%26author%3DH.%2BYildirim%26author%3DA.%2BKinaci%26author%3DM.%2BK.%2BY.%2BChan%26author%3DJ.%2BP.%2BGreeley%26title%3DFirst-Principles%2BAnalysis%2Bof%2BDefect%2BThermodynamics%2Band%2BIon%2BTransport%2Bin%2BInorganic%2BSEI%2BCompounds%253A%2BLiF%2Band%2BNaF%26doi%3D10.1021%252Facsami.5b02904&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1021%2Facsami.5b02904&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit61R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">61</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">First-Principles Analysis of Defect Thermodynamics and Ion Transport in Inorganic SEI Compounds: LiF and NaF</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Yildirim, Handan; Kinaci, Alper; Chan, Maria K. Y.; Greeley, Jeffrey P.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">ACS Applied Materials &amp; Interfaces</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2015</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">7</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">34</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">18985-18996</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">AAMICK</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1944-8244</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">The formation mechanism and compn. of the solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) in lithium ion batteries has been widely explored.  However, relatively little is known about the function of the SEI as a transport medium.  Such crit. information is directly relevant to battery rate performance, power loss, and capacity fading.  To partially bridge this gap in the case of inorg. SEI compds., we report herein the results of first-principles calcns. on the defect thermodn., the dominant diffusion carriers, and the diffusion pathways assocd. with cryst. LiF and NaF, which are stable components of the SEI in Li-ion and Na-ion batteries, resp.  The thermodn. of common point defects are computed, and the dominant diffusion carriers are detd. over a voltage range of 0-4 V, corresponding to conditions relevant to both anode and cathode SEI's.  Our analyses reveal that for both compds., vacancy defects are energetically more favorable, therefore form more readily than interstitials, due to the close-packed nature of the crystal structures.  However, the vacancy concns. are very small for the diffusion processes facilitated by defects.  Ionic conductivities are calcd. as a function of voltage, considering the diffusion carrier concn. and the diffusion barriers as detd. by nudged elastic band calcns.  These conductivities are more than ten orders of magnitude smaller in NaF than in LiF.  As compared to the diffusivity of Li in other common inorg. SEI compds., such as Li2CO3 and Li2O, the cation diffusivity in LiF and NaF is quite low, with at least three orders of magnitude lower ionic conductivities.  The results quantify the extent to which fluorides pose rate limitations in Li and Na batteries.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGpaMaiGxrecebVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lhjTjL4HNtKaA"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXht12ksb7I&amp;md5=3020ddf82e8a1e83be5fbd67d3a54589</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref62"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref62'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">62</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit62" data-doi="10.1021/ja301266w"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Wang, Y.-Q.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Gu, L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Guo, Y.-G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Li, H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">He, X.-Q.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Tsukimoto, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ikuhara, Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Wan, L.-J.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Rutile-TiO <sub>2</sub> Nanocoating for a High-Rate Li <sub>4</sub> Ti <sub>5</sub> O <sub>12</sub> Anode of a Lithium-Ion Battery</span>. <i>J. Am. Chem. Soc.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2012</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>134</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">18</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">7874</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">7879</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/ja301266w</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D134%26publication_year%3D2012%26pages%3D7874-7879%26journal%3DJ.%2BAm.%2BChem.%2BSoc.%26issue%3D18%26author%3DY.-Q.%2BWang%26author%3DL.%2BGu%26author%3DY.-G.%2BGuo%26author%3DH.%2BLi%26author%3DX.-Q.%2BHe%26author%3DS.%2BTsukimoto%26author%3DY.%2BIkuhara%26author%3DL.-J.%2BWan%26title%3DRutile-TiO%2B2%2BNanocoating%2Bfor%2Ba%2BHigh-Rate%2BLi%2B4%2BTi%2B5%2BO%2B12%2BAnode%2Bof%2Ba%2BLithium-Ion%2BBattery%26doi%3D10.1021%252Fja301266w&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1021%2Fja301266w&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit62R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">62</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Rutile-TiO2 Nanocoating for a High-Rate Li4Ti5O12 Anode of a Lithium-Ion Battery</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Wang, Yong-Qing; Gu, Lin; Guo, Yu-Guo; Li, Hong; He, Xiao-Qing; Tsukimoto, Susumu; Ikuhara, Yuichi; Wan, Li-Jun</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of the American Chemical Society</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2012</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">134</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">18</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">7874-7879</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JACSAT</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0002-7863</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Well-defined Li4Ti5O12 nanosheets terminated with rutile-TiO2 at the edges were synthesized by a facile soln.-based method and revealed directly by an advanced spherical aberration imaging technique.  The rutile-TiO2 terminated Li4Ti5O12 nanosheets show much improved rate capability and specific capacity compared with pure Li4Ti5O12 nanosheets when used as anode materials for Li ion batteries.  The results here give clear evidence of the utility of rutile-TiO2 as a C-free coating layer to improve the kinetics of Li4Ti5O12 toward fast Li insertion/extn.  The C-free nanocoating of rutile-TiO2 is highly effective in improving the electrochem. properties of Li4Ti5O12, promising advanced batteries with high volumetric energy d., high surface stability, and long cycle life compared with the commonly used C nanocoating in electrode materials.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGr0VwW0ZElZCbVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lhjTjL4HNtKaA"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XmtFSqtLY%253D&amp;md5=ee61490c29b0f495b955fdc43ef51f34</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref63"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref63'); <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Bujoli, B.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Gan, Z.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hoatson, G.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Modelling One- and Two-Dimensional Solid-State NMR Spectra</span>. <i>Magn.
