                10.1002/mrc.984</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D40%26publication_year%3D2002%26pages%3D70-76%26journal%3DMagn.%2BReson.%2BChem.%26issue%3D1%26author%3DD.%2BMassiot%26author%3DF.%2BFayon%26author%3DM.%2BCapron%26author%3DI.%2BKing%26author%3DS.%2BLe%2BCalv%25C3%25A9%26author%3DB.%2BAlonso%26author%3DJ.-O.%2BDurand%26author%3DB.%2BBujoli%26author%3DZ.%2BGan%26author%3DG.%2BHoatson%26title%3DModelling%2BOne-%2Band%2BTwo-Dimensional%2BSolid-State%2BNMR%2BSpectra%26doi%3D10.1002%252Fmrc.984&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1002%2Fmrc.984&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit63R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">63</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Modeling one- and two-dimensional solid-state NMR spectra</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Massiot, Dominique; Fayon, Franck; Capron, Mickael; King, Ian; Le Calve, Stephanie; Alonso, Bruno; Durand, Jean-Olivier; Bujoli, Bruno; Gan, Zhehong; Hoatson, Gina</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Magnetic Resonance in Chemistry</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2002</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">40</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">1</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">70-76</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">MRCHEG</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0749-1581</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">John Wiley &amp; Sons Ltd.</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A review.  With the description of more and more complex 1- and two-dimensional NMR expts. comes the need to develop methods to make a comprehensive interpretation of the various different expts. that can be carried out on the same sample or series of related samples.  The authors present some examples of modeling 1- and two-dimensional solid-state NMR spectra of I = 1/2 spin and quadrupolar nuclei, using lab.-developed software that is made available to the NMR community.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGr71caHDG6zjLVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lhjTjL4HNtKaA"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38Xlt1ajuw%253D%253D&amp;md5=d32cb46ca90ac83a8f2d62c95a93a88f</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref64"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref64'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">64</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit64" data-doi="10.1016/j.cplett.2006.06.007"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Thakur, R.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kurur, N.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Madhu, P.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Swept-Frequency Two-Pulse Phase Modulation for Heteronuclear Dipolar Decoupling in Solid-State NMR</span>. <i>Chem. Phys. Lett.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2006</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>426</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">4–6</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">459</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">463</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1016/j.cplett.2006.06.007</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D426%26publication_year%3D2006%26pages%3D459-463%26journal%3DChem.%2BPhys.%2BLett.%26issue%3D4%25E2%2580%25936%26author%3DR.%2BThakur%26author%3DN.%2BKurur%26author%3DP.%2BMadhu%26title%3DSwept-Frequency%2BTwo-Pulse%2BPhase%2BModulation%2Bfor%2BHeteronuclear%2BDipolar%2BDecoupling%2Bin%2BSolid-State%2BNMR%26doi%3D10.1016%252Fj.cplett.2006.06.007&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1016%2Fj.cplett.2006.06.007&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit64R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">64</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Swept-frequency two-pulse phase modulation for heteronuclear dipolar decoupling in solid-state NMR</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Thakur, Rajendra Singh; Kurur, Narayanan D.; Madhu, P. K.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Chemical Physics Letters</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2006</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">426</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">4-6</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">459-463</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">CHPLBC</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0009-2614</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Elsevier B.V.</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">We introduce a heteronuclear dipolar decoupling sequence for application in solid-state NMR.  The sequence, called swept-frequency two-pulse phase modulation (SWf-TPPM), is based on one of the decoupling sequences, TPPM.  The sequence is robust in performance with respect to various exptl. parameters, such as, the pulse flip angle, pulse phase, and offset and a comparison is made with other decoupling schemes, namely TPPM, SPINAL, and XiX, on a sample of U-13C-labeled tyrosine for magic-angle spinning speeds up to 14 kHz.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGohIwVJDXGE-bVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lhjTjL4HNtKaA"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XntlWgs7c%253D&amp;md5=ed9ed195f49e0c590ec60cc1f3218632</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref65"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref65'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">65</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit65" data-doi="10.1007/1-4020-3910-7_89"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Gullion, T.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Rotational-Echo, Double-Resonance NMR</span>. Mater. Sci.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2013</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>68</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">314</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">319</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1016/j.commatsci.2012.10.028</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D68%26publication_year%3D2013%26pages%3D314-319%26journal%3DComput.%2BMater.%2BSci.%26author%3DS.%2BP.%2BOng%26author%3DW.%2BD.%2BRichards%26author%3DA.%2BJain%26author%3DG.%2BHautier%26author%3DM.%2BKocher%26author%3DS.%2BCholia%26author%3DD.%2BGunter%26author%3DV.%2BL.%2BChevrier%26author%3DK.%2BA.%2BPersson%26author%3DG.%2BCeder%26title%3DPython%2BMaterials%2BGenomics%2B%2528Pymatgen%2529%253A%2BA%2BRobust%252C%2BOpen-Source%2BPython%2BLibrary%2Bfor%2BMaterials%2BAnalysis%26doi%3D10.1016%252Fj.commatsci.2012.10.028&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1016%2Fj.commatsci.2012.10.028&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit67R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">67</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Python Materials Genomics (pymatgen): A robust, open-source python library for materials analysis</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Ong, Shyue Ping; Richards, William Davidson; Jain, Anubhav; Hautier, Geoffroy; Kocher, Michael; Cholia, Shreyas; Gunter, Dan; Chevrier, Vincent L.; Persson, Kristin A.; Ceder, Gerbrand</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Computational Materials Science</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2013</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">68</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue"></span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">314-319</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">CMMSEM</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0927-0256</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Elsevier B.V.</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">We present the Python Materials Genomics (pymatgen) library, a robust, open-source Python library for materials anal.  A key enabler in high-throughput computational materials science efforts is a robust set of software tools to perform initial setup for the calcns. (e.g., generation of structures and necessary input files) and post-calcn. anal. to derive useful material properties from raw calcd. data.  The pymatgen library aims to meet these needs by (1) defining core Python objects for materials data representation, (2) providing a well-tested set of structure and thermodn. analyses relevant to many applications, and (3) establishing an open platform for researchers to collaboratively develop sophisticated analyses of materials data obtained both from first principles calcns. and expts.  The pymatgen library also provides convenient tools to obtain useful materials data via the Materials Project's REpresentational State Transfer (REST) Application Programming Interface (API).  As an example, using pymatgen's interface to the Materials Project's RESTful API and phase diagram package, we demonstrate how the phase and electrochem. stability of a recently synthesized material, Li4SnS4, can be analyzed using a min. of computing resources.  We find that Li4SnS4 is a stable phase in the Li-Sn-S phase diagram (consistent with the fact that it can be synthesized), but the narrow range of lithium chem. potentials for which it is predicted to be stable would suggest that it is not intrinsically stable against typical electrodes used in lithium-ion batteries.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGpaZmfhPTuVrLVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lhkpfUsC2SvNQ"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhsVGjt7g%253D&amp;md5=104f567dbd8f4199911ded91bc42100e</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref68"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref68'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">68</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit68" data-doi="10.1524/zkri.220.5.567.65075"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Clark, S. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Segall, M. D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Pickard, C. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hasnip, P. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Probert, M. I. C.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">First Principles Methods Using CASTEP</span>. <i>Z. Kristallogr. Cryst. Mater.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2005</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>220</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">5–6</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">567</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">570</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1524/zkri.220.5.567.65075</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D220%26publication_year%3D2005%26pages%3D567-570%26journal%3DZ.%2BKristallogr.%2BCryst.%2BMater.%26issue%3D5%25E2%2580%25936%26author%3DS.%2BJ.%2BClark%26author%3DM.%2BD.%2BSegall%26author%3DC.%2BJ.%2BPickard%26author%3DP.%2BJ.%2BHasnip%26author%3DM.%2BI.%2BJ.%2BProbert%26author%3DK.%2BRefson%26author%3DM.%2BC.%2BPayne%26title%3DFirst%2BPrinciples%2BMethods%2BUsing%2BCASTEP%26doi%3D10.1524%252Fzkri.220.5.567.65075&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1524%2Fzkri.220.5.567.65075&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit68R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">68</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">First principles methods using CASTEP</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Clark, Stewart J.; Segall, Matthew D.; Pickard, Chris J.; Hasnip, Phil J.; Probert, Matt I. J.; Refson, Keith; Payne, Mike C.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Zeitschrift fuer Kristallographie</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2005</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">220</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">5-6</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">567-570</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">ZEKRDZ</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0044-2968</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Oldenbourg Wissenschaftsverlag GmbH</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">The CASTEP code for first principles electronic structure calcns. is described.  A brief, non-tech. overview is given and some of the features and capabilities highlighted.  Some features which are unique to CASTEP are described and near-future development plans outlined.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGooz4-HvIpWsLVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lhkpfUsC2SvNQ"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXmsVSitbk%253D&amp;md5=edb75e2f9d4df4ad83f4df7db21888e7</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref69"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref69'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">69</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit69" data-doi="10.1103/PhysRevB.76.024401"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Yates, J. R.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Pickard, C. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Mauri, F.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Calculation of NMR Chemical Shifts for Extended Systems Using Ultrasoft Pseudopotentials</span>. <i>Phys. Rev. B</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2007</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>76</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">2</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">024401</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1103/PhysRevB.76.024401</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D76%26publication_year%3D2007%26pages%3D024401%26journal%3DPhys.%2BRev.%2BB%26issue%3D2%26author%3DJ.%2BR.%2BYates%26author%3DC.%2BJ.%2BPickard%26author%3DF.%2BMauri%26title%3DCalculation%2Bof%2BNMR%2BChemical%2BShifts%2Bfor%2BExtended%2BSystems%2BUsing%2BUltrasoft%2BPseudopotentials%26doi%3D10.1103%252FPhysRevB.76.024401&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1103%2FPhysRevB.76.024401&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit69R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">69</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Calculation of NMR chemical shifts for extended systems using ultrasoft pseudopotentials</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Yates, Jonathan R.; Pickard, Chris J.; Mauri, Francesco</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Physical Review B: Condensed Matter and Materials Physics</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2007</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">76</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">2</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">024401/1-024401/11</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">PRBMDO</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1098-0121</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Physical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">The authors present a scheme for the calcn. of magnetic response parameters in insulators using ultrasoft pseudopotentials.  It uses the gauge-including projector augmented wave method [C. J. Pickard and F. Mauri, Phys. Rev. B 63, 245101(2001)] to obtain all-electron accuracy for both finite and infinitely periodic systems.  In detail the calcn. of NMR chem. shieldings are considered.  The approach is successfully validated 1st for mol. systems by comparing calcd. chem. shieldings for a range of mols. with quantum chem. results and then in the solid state by comparing 17O NMR parameters calcd. for silicates with expt.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGq3iYusryxitrVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lhkpfUsC2SvNQ"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXos1ajtr8%253D&amp;md5=8aea5f8a0810a82518bfa5f9c6fad19f</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref70"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref70'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">70</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit70" data-doi="10.1103/PhysRevB.63.245101"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Pickard, C. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Mauri, F.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">All-Electron Magnetic Response with Pseudopotentials: NMR Chemical Shifts</span>. <i>Phys. Rev. B</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2001</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>63</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">24</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">245101</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1103/PhysRevB.63.245101</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D63%26publication_year%3D2001%26pages%3D245101%26journal%3DPhys.%2BRev.%2BB%26issue%3D24%26author%3DC.%2BJ.%2BPickard%26author%3DF.%2BMauri%26title%3DAll-Electron%2BMagnetic%2BResponse%2Bwith%2BPseudopotentials%253A%2BNMR%2BChemical%2BShifts%26doi%3D10.1103%252FPhysRevB.63.245101&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1103%2FPhysRevB.63.245101&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit70R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">70</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">All-electron magnetic response with pseudopotentials: NMR chemical shifts</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Pickard, Chris J.; Mauri, Francesco</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Physical Review B: Condensed Matter and Materials Physics</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2001</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">63</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">24</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">245101/1-245101/13</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">PRBMDO</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0163-1829</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Physical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A theory for the ab initio calcn. of all-electron NMR chem. shifts in insulators using pseudopotentials is presented.  It is formulated for both finite and infinitely periodic systems and is based on an extension to the projector augmented-wave approach of Blochl [P. E. Blochl, Phys. Rev. B 50, 17953 (1994)] and the method of Mauri et al. [F. Mauri, B. G. Pfrommer, and S. G. Louie, Phys. Rev. Lett. 77, 5300 (1996)].  The theory is successfully validated for mols. by comparison with a selection of quantum chem. results, and in periodic systems by comparison with plane-wave all-electron results for diamond.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGo2yQHc0EjyKLVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lhkpfUsC2SvNQ"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXlt12rs74%253D&amp;md5=7ae73923f2a7cc90a36a5e3c7ef2c35a</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref71"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref71'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">71</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit71" data-doi="10.1103/PhysRevLett.77.3865"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Perdew, J. P.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Burke, K.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ernzerhof, M.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Generalized Gradient Approximation Made Simple</span>. <i>Phys. Rev. Lett.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">1996</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>77</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">18</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">3865</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">3868</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1103/PhysRevLett.77.3865</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D77%26publication_year%3D1996%26pages%3D3865-3868%26journal%3DPhys.%2BRev.%2BLett.%26issue%3D18%26author%3DJ.%2BP.%2BPerdew%26author%3DK.%2BBurke%26author%3DM.%2BErnzerhof%26title%3DGeneralized%2BGradient%2BApproximation%2BMade%2BSimple%26doi%3D10.1103%252FPhysRevLett.77.3865&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1103%2FPhysRevLett.77.3865&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit71R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">71</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Generalized gradient approximation made simple</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Perdew, John P.; Burke, Kieron; Ernzerhof, Matthias</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Physical Review Letters</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">1996</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">77</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">18</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">3865-3868</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">PRLTAO</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0031-9007</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Physical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Generalized gradient approxns. (GGA's) for the exchange-correlation energy improve upon the local spin d. (LSD) description of atoms, mols., and solids.  We present a simple derivation of a simple GGA, in which all parameters (other than those in LSD) are fundamental consts.  Only general features of the detailed construction underlying the Perdew-Wang 1991 (PW91) GGA are invoked.  Improvements over PW91 include an accurate description of the linear response of the uniform electron gas, correct behavior under uniform scaling, and a smoother potential.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGokga1tVzFw07Vg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lhkpfUsC2SvNQ"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK28XmsVCgsbs%253D&amp;md5=55943538406ee74f93aabdf882cd4630</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref72"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref72'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">72</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit72" data-doi="10.1063/1.1541625"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Yates, J. R.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Pickard, C. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Payne, M. C.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Mauri, F.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Relativistic Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Chemical Shifts of Heavy Nuclei with Pseudopotentials and the Zeroth-Order Regular Approximation</span>. <i>J. Chem. Phys.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2003</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>118</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">13</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">5746</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">5753</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1063/1.1541625</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D118%26publication_year%3D2003%26pages%3D5746-5753%26journal%3DJ.%2BChem.%2BPhys.%26issue%3D13%26author%3DJ.%2BR.%2BYates%26author%3DC.%2BJ.%2BPickard%26author%3DM.%2BC.%2BPayne%26author%3DF.%2BMauri%26title%3DRelativistic%2BNuclear%2BMagnetic%2BResonance%2BChemical%2BShifts%2Bof%2BHeavy%2BNuclei%2Bwith%2BPseudopotentials%2Band%2Bthe%2BZeroth-Order%2BRegular%2BApproximation%26doi%3D10.1063%252F1.1541625&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1063%2F1.1541625&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit72R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">72</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Relativistic nuclear magnetic resonance chemical shifts of heavy nuclei with pseudopotentials and the zeroth-order regular approximation</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Yates, Jonathan R.; Pickard, Chris J.; Payne, Mike C.; Mauri, Francesco</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Chemical Physics</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2003</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">118</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">13</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">5746-5753</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JCPSA6</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0021-9606</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Institute of Physics</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">We present a method for the 1st principles d. functional calcn. of relativistic all-electron NMR chem. shifts using pseudopotentials.  The method is based on the gauge including projector augmented wave approach of Pickard and Mauri (2001).  Relativistic effects are included at the level of the scalar-relativistic zeroth-order regular approxn.  The method allows chem. shifts of large, low symmetry structures contg. heavy elements to be calcd. efficiently.  We demonstrate its success for a range of Se and Te contg. mols.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGoLY52N4fV7hrVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lhkpfUsC2SvNQ"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXitlemsr0%253D&amp;md5=488734071412154e1b1ae04245018c5e</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref73"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref73'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">73</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit73" data-doi="10.1039/D2TA05823E"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Sebti, E.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Qi, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Richardson, P. Power Sources</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2015</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>283</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">243</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">250</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:

                        cas_cit75R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">75</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Synthesis of lithium titanate nanorods as anode materials for lithium and sodium ion batteries with superior electrochemical performance</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Zhou, Qian; Liu, Li; Tan, Jinli; Yan, Zichao; Huang, Zhifeng; Wang, Xianyou</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Power Sources</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2015</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">283</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue"></span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">243-250</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JPSODZ</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0378-7753</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Elsevier B.V.</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Li4Ti5O12 nanorods have been successfully synthesized via hydrothermal method using TiO2-B as titanium source and template.  Such Li4Ti5O12 nanorods with sizes of 100-200 nm in diam. and 1-2 μm in length can be obsd.  The Li4Ti5O12 nanorods exhibit high discharge capacity of about 101.1 mAh g-1 after 1000 cycles at 20C for the lithium ion battery anode.  The Li4Ti5O12 nanorods also show excellent sodium storage performance, which have a reversible capacity of approx. 131.6 mAh g-1 after 100 cycles at 0.1C.  Based on the electrochem. performance, it is suggested that Li4Ti5O12 nanorods have a great potential for lithium and sodium ion battery that are available as large-scale storage devices for applications such as automotive and stationary energy storage.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGocVSAr2EY5YbVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lir7xYNKFJ7_A"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXjtlWhsrk%253D&amp;md5=31df4368148259649bd3002b718246c2</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref76"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref76'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">76</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit76" data-doi="10.1039/C7TA03173D"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Liu, Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Liu, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hou, M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Fan, L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Wang, Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Xia, Y.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Carbon-Coated Li <sub>4</sub> Ti <sub>5</sub> O <sub>12</sub> Nanoparticles with High Electrochemical Performance as Anode Material in Sodium-Ion Batteries</span>. <i>J.                 10.1016/j.ssnmr.2019.02.003</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D99%26publication_year%3D2019%26pages%3D7-14%26journal%3DSolid%2BState%2BNucl.%2BMagn.%2BReson.%26issue%3DFebruary%26author%3DA.%2BSvirinovsky-Arbeli%26author%3DD.%2BRosenberg%26author%3DD.%2BKrotkov%26author%3DR.%2BDamari%26author%3DK.%2BKundu%26author%3DA.%2BFeintuch%26author%3DL.%2BHouben%26author%3DS.%2BFleischer%26author%3DM.%2BLeskes%26title%3DThe%2BEffects%2Bof%2BSample%2BConductivity%2Bon%2Bthe%2BEfficacy%2Bof%2BDynamic%2BNuclear%2BPolarization%2Bfor%2BSensitivity%2BEnhancement%2Bin%2BSolid%2BState%2BNMR%2BSpectroscopy%26doi%3D10.1016%252Fj.ssnmr.2019.02.003&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1016%2Fj.ssnmr.2019.02.003&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord empty" id="
                            cas_R
                        "><div class="casContent">There is no corresponding record for this reference.</div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref83"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref83'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">83</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit83" data-doi="10.1021/acs.jpcc.0c00858"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Harchol, A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Reuveni, G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ri, V.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Thomas, B.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Carmieli, R.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Herber, R. H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kim, C.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Leskes, M.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Endogenous Dynamic Nuclear Polarization for Sensitivity Enhancement in Solid-State NMR of Electrode Materials</span>. <i>J. Phys. Chem. C</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2020</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>124</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">13</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">7082</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">7090</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/acs.jpcc.0c00858</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D124%26publication_year%3D2020%26pages%3D7082-7090%26journal%3DJ.%2BPhys.%2BChem.%2BC%26issue%3D13%26author%3DA.%2BHarchol%26author%3DG.%2BReuveni%26author%3DV.%2BRi%26author%3DB.%2BThomas%26author%3DR.%2BCarmieli%26author%3DR.%2BH.%2BHerber%26author%3DC.%2BKim%26author%3DM.%2BLeskes%26title%3DEndogenous%2BDynamic%2BNuclear%2BPolarization%2Bfor%2BSensitivity%2BEnhancement%2Bin%2BSolid-State%2BNMR%2Bof%2BElectrode%2BMaterials%26doi%3D10.1021%252Facs.jpcc.0c00858&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1021%2Facs.jpcc.0c00858&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit83R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">83</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Endogenous Dynamic Nuclear Polarization for Sensitivity Enhancement in Solid-State NMR of Electrode Materials</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Harchol, Adi; Reuveni, Guy; Ri, Vitalii; Thomas, Brijith; Carmieli, Raanan; Herber, Rolfe H.; Kim, Chunjoong; Leskes, Michal</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Physical Chemistry C</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2020</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">124</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">13</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">7082-7090</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JPCCCK</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1932-7447</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Rational design of materials for energy storage systems relies on our ability to probe these materials at various length scales.  Solid-state NMR spectroscopy is a powerful approach for gaining chem. and structural insights at the at./mol. level, but its low detection sensitivity often limits applicability.  This limitation can be overcome by transferring the high polarization of electron spins to the sample of interest in a process called dynamic nuclear polarization (DNP).  Here, we employ for the first time metal ion-based DNP to probe pristine and cycled composite battery electrodes.  A new and efficient DNP agent, Fe(III), is introduced, yielding lithium signal enhancement up to 180 when substituted in the anode material Li4Ti5O12.  In addn. for being DNP active, Fe(III) improves the anode performance.  Redn. of Fe(III) to Fe(II) upon cycling can be monitored in the loss of DNP activity.  We show that the dopant can be reactivated (return to Fe(III)) for DNP by increasing the cycling potential window.  Furthermore, we demonstrate that the deleterious effect of carbon additives on the DNP process can be eliminated by using carbon free electrodes, doped with Fe(III) and Mn(II), which provide good electrochem. performance as well as sensitivity in DNP-NMR.  We expect that the approach presented here will expand the applicability of DNP for studying materials for frontier challenges in materials chem. assocd. with energy and sustainability.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGpT9MjWnIILJLVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lir7xYNKFJ7_A"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXktlOntrs%253D&amp;md5=9a22e73f910fd29994f4ca3f7ace0b3a</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref84"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref84'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">84</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit84" data-doi="10.1039/C4TA04428B"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ponrouch, A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Monti, D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Boschin, A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Steen, B.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Johansson, P.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Palacín, M. R.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Non-Aqueous Electrolytes for Sodium-Ion Batteries</span>. <i>J. Mater. Chem. A</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2015</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>3</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">1</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">22</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">42</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1039/C4TA04428B</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D3%26publication_year%3D2015%26pages%3D22-42%26journal%3DJ.%2BMater.%2BChem.%2BA%26issue%3D1%26author%3DA.%2BPonrouch%26author%3DD.%2BMonti%26author%3DA.%2BBoschin%26author%3DB.%2BSteen%26author%3DP.%2BJohansson%26author%3DM.%2BR.%2BPalac%25C3%25ADn%26title%3DNon-Aqueous%2BElectrolytes%2Bfor%2BSodium-Ion%2BBatteries%26doi%3D10.1039%252FC4TA04428B&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1039%2FC4TA04428B&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit84R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">84</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Non-aqueous electrolytes for sodium-ion batteries</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Ponrouch, A.; Monti, D.; Boschin, A.; Steen, B.; Johansson, P.; Palacin, M. R.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2015</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">3</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">1</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">22-42</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JMCAET</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">2050-7496</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Royal Society of Chemistry</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A review.  The 1st review of the various electrolytes currently used and developed for Na-ion batteries (SIBs), both in terms of materials and concepts, is presented.  In contrast to the Li-ion battery (LIB), which is a mature technol. for which a more or less unanimously accepted std. electrolyte exists: 1 M LiPF6 in EC/DMC, the electrolyte of choice for SIBs has not yet fully conformed to a std.  This is true for both materials: salts, solvents, or additives, and concept, using the main track of org. solvents or aiming for other concepts.  SIB research currently prospers, benefitting from using know-how gained from 30 years of LIB R and D.  Here the currently employed electrolytes are emphasized and their effects on practical SIB performance are outlined, scrutinizing the rationale for specific choices made, salts, solvents, additives, concns., etc. for each specific cell set-up and usage conditions.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGpb_d9E3Qe0wLVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lhFmRnFtfaqqA"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhslOjtLfI&amp;md5=b99d9ac3e00e101e25ffc33ee1bef953</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref85"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref85'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">85</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit85" data-doi="10.1021/jacs.6b11333"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Reeve, Z. E. M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Franko, C. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Harris, K. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Yadegari, H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Sun, X.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Goward, G. R.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Detection of Electrochemical Reaction Products from the Sodium–Oxygen Cell with Solid-State 23 Na NMR Spectroscopy</span>. <i>J. Am. Chem. Soc.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2017</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>139</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">2</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">595</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">598</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/jacs.6b11333</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D139%26publication_year%3D2017%26pages%3D595-598%26journal%3DJ.%2BAm.%2BChem.%2BSoc.%26issue%3D2%26author%3DZ.%2BE.%2BM.%2BReeve%26author%3DC.%2BJ.%2BFranko%26author%3DK.%2BJ.%2BHarris%26author%3DH.%2BYadegari%26author%3DX.%2BSun%26author%3DG.%2BR.%2BGoward%26title%3DDetection%2Bof%2BElectrochemical%2BReaction%2BProducts%2Bfrom%2Bthe%2BSodium%25E2%2580%2593Oxygen%2BCell%2Bwith%2BSolid-State%2B23%2BNa%2BNMR%2BSpectroscopy%26doi%3D10.1021%252Fjacs.6b11333&amp;doi=10.1021%2Fjacs.4c06823&amp;doiOfLink=10.1021%2Fjacs.6b11333&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit85R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">85</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Detection of Electrochemical Reaction Products from the Sodium-Oxygen Cell with Solid-State 23Na NMR Spectroscopy</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Reeve, Zoe E. M.; Franko, Christopher J.; Harris, Kristopher J.; Yadegari, Hossein; Sun, Xueliang; Goward, Gillian R.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of the American Chemical Society</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2017</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">139</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">2</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">595-598</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JACSAT</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0002-7863</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">23Na MAS NMR spectra of sodium-oxygen (Na-O2) cathodes reveals a combination of degrdn. species: newly obsd. sodium fluoride (NaF) and the expected sodium carbonate (Na2CO3), as well as the desired reaction product sodium peroxide (Na2O2).  The initial reaction product, sodium superoxide (NaO2), is not present in a measurable quantity in the 23Na NMR spectra of the cycled electrodes.  The reactivity of solid NaO2 is probed further, and NaF is found to be formed through a reaction between the electrochem. generated NaO2 and the electrode binder, polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF).  The instability of cell components in the presence of desired electrochem. reaction products is clearly problematic and bears further investigation.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGpcQ5k3r3w1E7Vg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lhFmRnFtfaqqA"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XitFCgsL7P&amp;md5=f682ef8dad015e35d69ff014487f5fc7</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref86"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" onclick="showRef(event, 'ref86'); return false;" data-citation="" class="refNumLink">86</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit86" data-doi="10.1021/acs.chemrev.1c00662"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Shcherbakov, A.
