Soc.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2010</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>132</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">44</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">15459</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">15461</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/ja104771z</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit27R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">27</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Surface Enhanced NMR Spectroscopy by Dynamic Nuclear Polarization</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Lesage, Anne; Lelli, Moreno; Gajan, David; Caporini, Marc A.; Vitzthum, Veronika; Mieville, Pascal; Alauzun, Johan; Roussey, Arthur; Thieuleux, Chloe; Mehdi, Ahmad; Bodenhausen, Geoffrey; Coperet, Christophe; Emsley, Lyndon</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of the American Chemical Society</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2010</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">132</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">44</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">15459-15461</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JACSAT</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0002-7863</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">It is shown that surface NMR spectra can be greatly enhanced using dynamic nuclear polarization.  Polarization is transferred from the protons of the solvent to the rare nuclei (here carbon-13 at natural isotopic abundance) at the surface, yielding at least a 50-fold signal enhancement for surface species covalently incorporated into a silica framework.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGr9nLUzyyCqU7Vg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lja-ZVd8YHjMg"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhtFChs7rN&amp;md5=490221f26c5c0356120504f159fdb837</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref28"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref28" class="rightTabRefNumLink">28</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit28" data-doi="10.1021/jacs.5b03905"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Perras, F. a.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kobayashi, T.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Pruski, M.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Natural Abundance 17 O DNP Two-Dimensional and Surface-Enhanced NMR Spectroscopy</span>. <i>J. Am. Chem. Soc.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2015</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>137</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">26</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">8336</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">8339</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/jacs.5b03905</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit28R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">28</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Natural Abundance 17O DNP Two-Dimensional and Surface-Enhanced NMR Spectroscopy</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Perras, Frederic A.; Kobayashi, Takeshi; Pruski, Marek</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of the American Chemical Society</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2015</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">137</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">26</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">8336-8339</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JACSAT</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0002-7863</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Due to its extremely low natural abundance and quadrupolar nature, the 17O nuclide is very rarely used for spectroscopic study of solids by NMR without isotope enrichment.  Addnl., the applicability of dynamic nuclear polarization (DNP), which leads to sensitivity enhancements of 2 orders of magnitude, to 17O is wrought with challenges due to the lack of spin diffusion and low polarization transfer efficiency from 1H.  The authors demonstrate new DNP-based measurements that extend 17O solid-state NMR beyond its current capabilities.  The use of the PRESTO technique instead of conventional 1H-17O cross-polarization greatly improves the sensitivity and enables the facile measurement of undistorted line shapes and two-dimensional 1H-17O HETCOR NMR spectra as well as accurate internuclear distance measurements at natural abundance.  This was applied for distinguishing H-bonded and lone 17O sites on the surface of silica gel; the 1-dimensional spectrum of which could not be used to ext. such detail.  Lastly, this greatly enhanced sensitivity has enabled, for the 1st time, the detection of surface hydroxyl sites on mesoporous SiO2 at natural abundance, thereby extending the concept of DNP surface-enhanced NMR spectroscopy to the 17O nuclide.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGokXMIa6MXXb7Vg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lja-ZVd8YHjMg"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhtVKitrjM&amp;md5=e9b78dc14d223e7b739db2e329e164b7</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref29"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref29" class="rightTabRefNumLink">29</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit29" data-doi="10.1021/acs.jpclett.9b01185"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Brownbill, N. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Lee, D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">De Paëpe, G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Blanc, F.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Detection of the Surface of Crystalline Y2O3 Using Direct 89Y Dynamic Nuclear Polarization</span>. <i>J. Phys. Chem. Lett.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2019</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>10</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">12</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">3501</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">3508</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/acs.jpclett.9b01185</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit29R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">29</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Detection of the Surface of Crystalline Y2O3 Using Direct 89Y Dynamic Nuclear Polarization</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Brownbill, Nick J.; Lee, Daniel; De Paepe, Gael; Blanc, Frederic</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Physical Chemistry Letters</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2019</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">10</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">12</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">3501-3508</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JPCLCD</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1948-7185</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Nuclei with low gyromagnetic ratio (γ) present a serious sensitivity challenge for NMR (NMR) spectroscopy.  Recently, dynamic nuclear polarization (DNP) has shown great promise in overcoming this hurdle by indirect hyperpolarization (via 1H) of these low-γ nuclei.  Here we show that at a magnetic field of 9.4 T and cryogenic temp. of about 110 K direct DNP of 89Y in a frozen soln. of Y(NO3)3 can offer signal enhancements greater than 80 times using exogenous trityl OX063 monoradical by satisfying the cross effect magic angle spinning (MAS) DNP mechanism.  The large signal enhancement achieved permits 89Y NMR spectra of Y2O3 and Gd2O3-added Y2O3 materials to be obtained quickly (∼30 min), revealing a range of surface yttrium hydroxyl groups in addn. to the two octahedral yttrium signals of the core.  The results open up promises for the observation of low gyromagnetic ratio nuclei and the detection of corresponding surface and (sub-)surface sites.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGqXsQY_cZPmibVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lja-ZVd8YHjMg"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXhtV2murfM&amp;md5=404ff5906b406cb8afcfda855c7a8684</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref30"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref30" class="rightTabRefNumLink">30</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit30" data-doi="10.1002/anie.201206102"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Takahashi, H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Lee, D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Dubois, L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Bardet, M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hediger, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">De Paëpe, G.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Rapid Natural-Abundance 2D 13C-13C Correlation Spectroscopy Using Dynamic Nuclear Polarization Enhanced Solid-State NMR and Matrix-Free Sample Preparation</span>. <i>Angew.                         rightTab-cas_cit32R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">32</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Untangling the Condensation Network of Organosiloxanes on Nanoparticles using 2D 29Si-29Si Solid-State NMR Enhanced by Dynamic Nuclear Polarization</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Lee, Daniel; Monin, Guillaume; Duong, Nghia Tuan; Lopez, Isabel Zamanillo; Bardet, Michel; Mareau, Vincent; Gonon, Laurent; De Paepe, Gael</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of the American Chemical Society</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2014</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">136</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">39</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">13781-13788</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JACSAT</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0002-7863</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Silica (SiO2) nanoparticles (NPs) were functionalized by silanization to produce a surface covered with organosiloxanes.  Information about the surface coverage and the nature, if any, of organosiloxane polymn., whether parallel or perpendicular to the surface, is highly desired.  To this extent, two-dimensional homonuclear 29Si solid-state NMR could be employed.  However, owing to the sensitivity limitations assocd. with the low natural abundance (4.7%) of 29Si and the difficulty and expense of isotopic labeling here, this technique would usually be deemed impracticable.  Nevertheless, we show that recent developments in the field of dynamic nuclear polarization under magic angle spinning (MAS-DNP) could be used to dramatically increase the sensitivity of the NMR expts., resulting in a timesaving factor of ∼625 compared to conventional solid-state NMR.  This allowed the acquisition of previously infeasible data.  Using both through-space and through-bond 2D 29Si-29Si correlation expts., it is shown that the required reaction conditions favor lateral polymn. and domain growth.  Moreover, the natural abundance correlation expts. permitted the estn. of 2JSi-O-Si-couplings (13.8 ± 1.4 Hz for surface silica) and interat. distances (3.04 ± 0.08 Å for surface silica) since complications assocd. with many-spin systems and also sensitivity were avoided.  The work detailed herein not only demonstrates the possibility of using MAS-DNP to greatly facilitate the acquisition of 2D 29Si-29Si correlation spectra but also shows that this technique can be used in a routine fashion to characterize surface grafting networks and gain structural constraints, which can be related to a system's chem. and phys. properties.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGqpkPIluBytMbVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lja-ZVd8YHjMg"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhsVWltL7E&amp;md5=b73a77fc16a1c06cdf0f218fa3a236b3</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref33"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref33" class="rightTabRefNumLink">33</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit33" data-doi="10.1021/acs.jpcc.6b02579"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Perras, F. A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Chaudhary, U.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Slowing, I.                         rightTab-cas_cit33R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">33</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Probing Surface Hydrogen Bonding and Dynamics by Natural Abundance, Multidimensional, 17O DNP-NMR Spectroscopy</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Perras, Frederic A.; Chaudhary, Umesh; Slowing, Igor I.; Pruski, Marek</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Physical Chemistry C</span>

            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Dynamic nuclear polarization (DNP)-enhanced solid-state NMR (SSNMR) spectroscopy is increasingly being used as a tool for the at.-level characterization of surface sites.  DNP surface-enhanced SSNMR spectroscopy of materials has, however, been limited to studying relatively receptive nuclei, and the particularly rare 17O nuclide, which is of great interest for materials science, has not been utilized.  We demonstrate that advanced 17O SSNMR expts. can be performed on surface species at natural isotopic abundance using DNP.  We use 17O DNP surface-enhanced 2D SSNMR to measure 17O{1H} HETCOR spectra as well as dipolar oscillations on a series of thermally treated mesoporous silica nanoparticle samples having different pore diams.  These expts. allow for a nonintrusive and unambiguous characterization of hydrogen bonding and dynamics at the surface of the material; no other single expt. can give such details about the interactions at the surface.  Our data show that, upon drying, strongly hydrogen-bonded surface silanols, whose motions are greatly restricted by the interaction when compared to lone silanols, are selectively dehydroxylated.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGotHiXfqoCew7Vg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lgIPo1pOVNC2w"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XnsVWju78%253D&amp;md5=09515ce2e6deaefa6554b23fd196f5ee</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref34"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref34" class="rightTabRefNumLink">34</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit34" data-doi="10.1021/acs.jpclett.6b02590"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Leskes, M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kim, G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Liu, T.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Michan, A. P.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Surface-Sensitive NMR Detection of the Solid Electrolyte Interphase Layer on Reduced Graphene Oxide</span>. <i>J. Phys. Chem.                 10.1021/acs.jpclett.6b02590</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit34R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">34</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Surface-Sensitive NMR Detection of the Solid Electrolyte Interphase Layer on Reduced Graphene Oxide</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Leskes, Michal; Kim, Gunwoo; Liu, Tao; Michan, Alison L.; Aussenac, Fabien; Dorffer, Patrick; Paul, Subhradip; Grey, Clare P.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Physical Chemistry Letters</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2017</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">8</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">5</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">1078-1085</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JPCLCD</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1948-7185</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Forming a stable solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) is crit. for rechargeable batteries' performance and lifetime.  Understanding its formation requires anal. techniques that provide mol.-level insight.  Here, dynamic nuclear polarization (DNP) is utilized for the first time to enhance the sensitivity of solid-state NMR (ssNMR) spectroscopy to the SEI.  The approach is demonstrated on reduced graphene oxide (rGO) cycled in Li-ion cells in natural abundance and 13C-enriched electrolyte solvents.  Our results indicate that DNP enhances the signal of outer SEI layers, enabling detection of natural abundance 13C spectra from this component of the SEI on reasonable time frames.  Furthermore, 13C-enriched electrolyte measurements at 100 K provide ample sensitivity without DNP due to the vast amt. of SEI filling the rGO pores, thereby allowing differentiation of the inner and outer SEI layer compn.  Developing this approach further will benefit the study of many electrode materials, equipping ssNMR with the necessary sensitivity to probe the SEI efficiently.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGoX38VthFLASbVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lgIPo1pOVNC2w"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXis1yitbY%253D&amp;md5=20a88fb3f41b07ff0c93c8eecaa42af2</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref35"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref35" class="rightTabRefNumLink">35</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit35" data-doi="10.1021/jacs.8b03408"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Jin, Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kneusels, N. P.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Understanding Fluoroethylene Carbonate and Vinylene Carbonate Based Electrolytes for Si Anodes in Lithium Ion Batteries with NMR Spectroscopy</span>. <i>J.                         rightTab-cas_cit35R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">35</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Understanding Fluoroethylene Carbonate and Vinylene Carbonate Based Electrolytes for Si Anodes in Lithium Ion Batteries with NMR Spectroscopy</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Jin, Yanting; Kneusels, Nis-Julian H.; Marbella, Lauren E.; Castillo-Martinez, Elizabeth; Magusin, Pieter C. M. M.; Weatherup, Robert S.; Jonsson, Erlendur; Liu, Tao; Paul, Subhradip; Grey, Clare P.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of the American Chemical Society</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2018</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">140</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">31</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">9854-9867</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JACSAT</span>;

            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) and vinylene carbonate (VC) are widely used as electrolyte additives in Li ion batteries.  Here, we analyze the solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) formed on binder-free Si nanowire (SiNW) electrodes in pure FEC or VC electrolytes contg. 1M LiPF6 by solid-state NMR with and without dynamic nuclear polarization (DNP) enhancement.  We find that the polymeric SEIs formed in pure FEC or VC electrolytes consist mainly of cross-linked poly(ethylene oxide) (PEO) and aliph. chain functionalities along with addnl. carbonate and carboxylate species.  The formation of branched fragments is further confirmed by 13C-13C correlation NMR expts.  The presence of cross-linked PEO-type polymers in FEC and VC correlates with good capacity retention and high Coulombic efficiencies of the SiNWs.  Using 29Si DNP NMR, we are able to probe the interfacial region between SEI and the Si surface for the 1st time with NMR spectroscopy.  Organosiloxanes form upon cycling, confirming that some of the org. SEI is covalently bonded to the Si surface.  We suggest that both the polymeric structure of the SEI and the nature of its adhesion to the redox-active materials are important for electrochem. performance.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGpqZ16XcY7nLbVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lgIPo1pOVNC2w"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXht1OgsrfO&amp;md5=b64d96608ab89b88152b96e7dd299efb</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref36"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref36" class="rightTabRefNumLink">36</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit36" data-doi="10.1038/s41467-020-16114-x"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hope, M. A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Rinkel, B. L. D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Gunnarsdóttir, A. B.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Märker, K.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Menkin, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Paul, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Sergeyev, I.                 10.1038/s41467-020-16114-x</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit36R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">36</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Selective NMR observation of the SEI-metal interface by dynamic nuclear polarisation from lithium metal</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Hope, Michael A.; Rinkel, Bernardine L. D.; Gunnarsdottir, Anna B.; Marker, Katharina; Menkin, Svetlana; Paul, Subhradip; Sergeyev, Ivan V.; Grey, Clare P.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Nature Communications</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2020</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">11</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">1</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">2224</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">NCAOBW</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">2041-1723</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Nature Research</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Abstr.: While lithium metal represents the ultimate high-energy-d. battery anode material, its use is limited by dendrite formation and assocd. safety risks, motivating studies of the solid-electrolyte interphase layer that forms on the lithium, which is key in controlling lithium metal deposition.  Dynamic nuclear polarisation enhanced NMR can provide important structural information; however, typical exogenous dynamic nuclear polarisation expts., in which org. radicals are added to the sample, require cryogenic sample cooling and are not selective for the interface between the metal and the solid-electrolyte interphase.  Here we instead exploit the conduction electrons of lithium metal to achieve an order of magnitude hyperpolarisation at room temp.  We enhance the 7Li, 1H and 19F NMR spectra of solid-electrolyte interphase species selectively, revealing their chem. nature and spatial distribution.  These expts. pave the way for more ambitious room temp. in situ dynamic nuclear polarisation studies of batteries and the selective enhancement of metal-solid interfaces in a wider range of systems.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGoRkjXrsReJzLVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lgIPo1pOVNC2w"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXptVeju7g%253D&amp;md5=d135f28d4097cc3a51445c26c6ce2620</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref37"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref37" class="rightTabRefNumLink">37</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit37" data-doi="10.1016/j.pnmrs.2023.08.002"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Jardón-Álvarez, D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Leskes, M.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Metal Ions Based Dynamic Nuclear Polarization: MI-DNP</span>. <i>Prog. Nucl. Magn. Reson. Spectrosc.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2023</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>138–139</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">70</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">104</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1016/j.pnmrs.2023.08.002</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord empty" id="
                            rightTab-cas_R
                        "><div class="casContent">There is no corresponding record for this reference.</div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref38"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref38" class="rightTabRefNumLink">38</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit38" data-doi="10.1021/jacs.8b11015"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Wolf, T.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kumar, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Singh, H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Chakrabarty, T.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Aussenac, F.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Frenkel, A. I.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Major, D. T.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Leskes, M.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Endogenous Dynamic Nuclear Polarization for Natural Abundance 17 O and Lithium NMR in the Bulk of Inorganic Solids</span>. <i>J. Am. Chem. Soc.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2019</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>141</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">1</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">451</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">462</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/jacs.8b11015</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit38R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">38</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Endogenous Dynamic Nuclear Polarization for Natural Abundance 17O and Lithium NMR in the Bulk of Inorganic Solids</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Wolf, Tamar; Kumar, Sandeep; Singh, Harishchandra; Chakrabarty, Tanmoy; Aussenac, Fabien; Frenkel, Anatoly I.; Major, Dan Thomas; Leskes, Michal</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of the American Chemical Society</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2019</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">141</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">1</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">451-462</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JACSAT</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0002-7863</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">In recent years magic angle spinning-dynamic nuclear polarization (MAS-DNP) has developed as an excellent approach for boosting the sensitivity of solid-state NMR (ssNMR) spectroscopy, thereby enabling the characterization of challenging systems in biol. and chem.  Most commonly, MAS-DNP is based on the use of nitroxide biradicals as polarizing agents.  In materials science, since the use of nitroxides often limits the signal enhancement to the materials' surface and subsurface layers, there is need for hyperpolarization approaches which will provide sensitivity in the bulk of micron sized particles.  Recently, an alternative in the form of paramagnetic metal ions has emerged.  Here we demonstrate the remarkable efficacy of Mn(II) dopants, used as endogenous polarization agents for MAS-DNP, in enabling the detection of 17O at a natural abundance of only 0.038%.  Distinct oxygen sites are identified in the bulk of micron-sized crystals, including battery anode materials Li4Ti5O12 (LTO) and Li2ZnTi3O8, as well as the phosphor materials NaCaPO4 and MgAl2O4, all doped with Mn(II) ions.  D. functional theory calcns. are used to assign the resonances to specific oxygen environments in these phases.  Depending on the Mn(II) dopant concn., we obtain significant signal enhancement factors, 142 and 24, for 6Li and 7Li nuclei in LTO, resp.  We furthermore follow the changes in the 6,7Li LTO resonances and det. their enhancement factors as a function of Mn(II) concn.  The results presented show that MAS-DNP from paramagnetic metal ion dopants provides an efficient approach for probing informative nuclei such as 17O, despite their low gyromagnetic ratio and negligible abundance, without isotope enrichment.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGqAjNfzVZuD-bVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lgIPo1pOVNC2w"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXisVKrsLfO&amp;md5=1bfa28ee86f2559a24bfc26458d56f4d</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref39"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref39" class="rightTabRefNumLink">39</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit39" data-doi="10.1021/acs.jpclett.0c01527"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Jardón-Álvarez, D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Reuveni, G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Harchol, A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Leskes, M.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Enabling Natural Abundance 17O Solid-State NMR by Direct Polarization from Paramagnetic Metal Ions</span>. <i>J. Phys. Chem. Lett.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2020</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>11</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">14</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">5439</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">5445</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/acs.jpclett.0c01527</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit39R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">39</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Enabling Natural Abundance 17O Solid-State NMR by Direct Polarization from Paramagnetic Metal Ions</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Jardon-Alvarez, Daniel; Reuveni, Guy; Harchol, Adi; Leskes, Michal</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Physical Chemistry Letters</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2020</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">11</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">14</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">5439-5445</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JPCLCD</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1948-7185</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Dynamic nuclear polarization (DNP) significantly enhances the sensitivity of NMR, increasing its applications and the quality of NMR spectroscopy as a characterization tool for materials.  Efficient spin diffusion among the nuclear spins is considered to be essential for spreading the hyperpolarization throughout the sample, enabling large DNP enhancements.  This scenario mostly limits the polarization enhancement of low-sensitivity nuclei in inorg. materials to the surface sites when the polarization source is an exogenous radical.  In metal-ion-based DNP, the polarization agents are distributed in the bulk sample and act as a source of both relaxation and polarization enhancement.  As long as the polarization agent is the main source of relaxation, the enhancement does not depend on the distance between the nucleus and dopant.  As a consequence, the requirement of efficient spin diffusion is lifted, and the entire sample can be directly polarized.  The authors exploit this finding to measure high-quality NMR spectra of 17O in the electrode material Li4Ti5O12 doped with Fe(III) despite its low abundance and long relaxation time.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGrxCyD-dggJvbVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lgIPo1pOVNC2w"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXhtF2iu7jN&amp;md5=690d3d90850d04511770dc3ee0ee7b7d</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref40"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref40" class="rightTabRefNumLink">40</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit40" data-doi="10.1021/acs.jpclett.1c00221"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Jardón-Álvarez, D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kahn, N.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Houben, L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Leskes, M.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Oxygen Vacancy Distribution in Yttrium-Doped Ceria from 89 Y– 89 Y Correlations via Dynamic Nuclear Polarization Solid-State NMR</span>. <i>J. Phys. Chem. Lett.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2021</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>12</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">11</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">2964</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">2969</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/acs.jpclett.1c00221</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit40R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">40</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Oxygen Vacancy Distribution in Yttrium-Doped Ceria from 89Y-89Y Correlations via Dynamic Nuclear Polarization Solid-State NMR</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Jardon-Alvarez, Daniel; Kahn, Nitzan; Houben, Lothar; Leskes, Michal</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Physical Chemistry Letters</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2021</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">12</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">11</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">2964-2969</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JPCLCD</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1948-7185</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Comprehending the oxygen vacancy distribution in oxide ion conductors requires structural insights over various length scales: from the local coordination preferences to the possible formation of agglomerates comprising a large no. of vacancies.  In Y-doped ceria, 89Y NMR enables differentiation of yttrium sites by quantification of the oxygen vacancies in their first coordination sphere.  Because of the extremely low sensitivity of 89Y, longer-range information was so far not available from NMR.  Herein, we utilize metal ion-based dynamic nuclear polarization, where polarization from Gd(III) dopants provides large sensitivity enhancements homogeneously throughout the bulk of the sample.  This enables following 89Y-89Y homonuclear dipolar correlations and probing the local distribution of yttrium sites, which show no evidence of the formation of oxygen vacancy rich regions.  The presented approach can provide valuable structural insights for designing oxide ion conductors.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGpcu_EZj63337Vg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lgIPo1pOVNC2w"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3MXmsFWgsLo%253D&amp;md5=2631c2b725e53371a7424487c2f61c38</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref41"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref41" class="rightTabRefNumLink">41</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit41" data-doi="10.1021/acs.jpcc.1c04479"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hope, M. A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Björgvinsdóttir, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Halat, D.                 10.1021/acs.chemmater.0c02698</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord empty" id="
                            rightTab-cas_R
                        "><div class="casContent">There is no corresponding record for this reference.</div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref43"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref43" class="rightTabRefNumLink">43</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit43" data-doi="10.1021/jacs.1c00215"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Haber, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Rosy</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Saha, A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Brontvein, O.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Carmieli, R.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Zohar, A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Noked, M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Leskes, M.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Structure and Functionality of an Alkylated Li<sub>x</sub>Si<sub>y</sub>O<sub>z</sub> Interphase for High-Energy Cathodes from DNP-ssNMR Spectroscopy</span>. <i>J. Am. Chem. Soc.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2021</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>143</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">12</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">4694</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">4704</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/jacs.1c00215</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit43R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">43</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Structure and Functionality of an Alkylated LixSiyOz Interphase for High-Energy Cathodes from DNP-ssNMR Spectroscopy</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Haber, Shira; Rosy; Saha, Arka; Brontvein, Olga; Carmieli, Raanan; Zohar, Arava; Noked, Malachi; Leskes, Michal</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of the American Chemical Society</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2021</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">143</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">12</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">4694-4704</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JACSAT</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0002-7863</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Degrdn. processes at the cathode-electrolyte interface are a major limitation in the development of high-energy lithium-ion rechargeable batteries.  Deposition of protective thin coating layers on the surface of high-energy cathodes is a promising approach to control interfacial reactions.  However, rational design of effective protection layers is limited by the scarcity of anal. tools that can probe thin, disordered, and heterogeneous phases.  Here we propose a new structural approach based on solid-state NMR spectroscopy coupled with dynamic nuclear polarization (DNP) for characterizing thin coating layers.  We demonstrate the approach on an efficient alkylated LixSiyOz coating layer.  By utilizing different sources for DNP, exogenous from nitroxide biradicals and endogenous from paramagnetic metal ion dopants, we reveal the outer and inner surface layers of the deposited artificial interphase and construct a structural model for the coating.  In addn., lithium isotope exchange expts. provide direct evidence for the function of the surface layer, shedding light on its role in the enhanced rate performance of coated cathodes.  The presented methodol. and results advance us in identifying the key properties of effective coatings and may enable rational design of protective and ion-conducting surface layers.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGrF7pQS_Z0ozbVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lg3bgzgdDr1XA"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3MXmvVCls7o%253D&amp;md5=f502969087a62f47f99049f3d64702a1</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref44"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref44" class="rightTabRefNumLink">44</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit44" data-doi="10.1126/sciadv.abm4606"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Gao, L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Chen, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Chen, Q.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kong, X.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">The Chemical Evolution of Solid Electrolyte Interface in Sodium Metal Batteries</span>. <i>Sci.                 10.1016/j.ensm.2019.10.006</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord empty" id="
                            rightTab-cas_R
                        "><div class="casContent">There is no corresponding record for this reference.</div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref46"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref46" class="rightTabRefNumLink">46</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit46" data-doi="10.1002/celc.201801621"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Carboni, M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Manzi, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Armstrong, A. R.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Billaud, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Brutti, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Younesi, R.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Analysis of the Solid Electrolyte Interphase on Hard Carbon Electrodes in Sodium-Ion Batteries</span>. <i>ChemElectroChem</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2019</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>6</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">6</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">1745</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">1753</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1002/celc.201801621</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit46R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">46</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Analysis of the Solid Electrolyte Interphase on Hard Carbon Electrodes in Sodium-Ion Batteries</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Carboni, Marco; Manzi, Jessica; Armstrong, Antony Robert; Billaud, Juliette; Brutti, Serfio; Younesi, Reza</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">ChemElectroChem</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2019</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">6</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">6</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">1745-1753</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">CHEMRA</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">2196-0216</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH &amp; Co. KGaA</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">The compn., morphol., and evolution of the solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) formed on hard carbon (HC) electrodes upon cycling in sodium-ion batteries are investigated.  A microporous HC was prepd. by pyrolysis of D-(+)-glucose at 1000°C followed by ball-milling.  HC electrodes were galvanostatically cycled at room temp. in sodium-ion half-cells using an aprotic electrolyte of 1 M sodium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide dissolved in propylene carbonate with 3 wt % fluoroethylene carbonate additive.  The evolution of the electrode/electrolyte interface was studied by impedance spectroscopy upon cycling and ex situ by spectroscopy and microscopy.  The irreversible capacity displayed by the HC electrodes in the first galvanostatic cycle is probably due to the accumulation of redox inactive NaxC phases and the pptn. of a porous, org.-inorg. hybrid SEI layer over the HC electrodes.  This passivation film further evolves in morphol. and compn. upon cycling and stabilizes after approx. ten galvanostatic cycles at low current rates.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGoxfxYGHDiWH7Vg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lg3bgzgdDr1XA"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXislCitb4%253D&amp;md5=f270889f543452dd44280d802b0dbbd7</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref47"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref47" class="rightTabRefNumLink">47</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit47" data-doi="10.1039/D0EE03916K"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Chen, D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Zhang, W.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Luo, K.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Song, Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Zhong, Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Liu, Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Wang, G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Zhong, B.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Wu, Z.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Guo, X.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Hard Carbon for Sodium Storage: Mechanism and Optimization Strategies toward Commercialization</span>. <i>Energy Environ. Sci.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2021</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>14</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">4</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">2244</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">2262</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1039/D0EE03916K</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit47R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">47</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Hard carbon for sodium storage: mechanism and optimization strategies toward commercialization</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Chen, Dequan; Zhang, Wen; Luo, Kangying; Song, Yang; Zhong, Yanjun; Liu, Yuxia; Wang, Gongke; Zhong, Benhe; Wu, Zhenguo; Guo, Xiaodong</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Energy &amp; Environmental Science</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2021</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">14</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">4</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">2244-2262</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">EESNBY</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1754-5706</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Royal Society of Chemistry</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) have shown promising prospects for complementarity to lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) in the field of grid-scale energy storage.  After a decade of continuous fundamental research on SIBs, it's becoming increasingly urgent to advance the commercialization.  For SIB anode materials, hard carbon is the most mature and currently the only material likely to be commercialized, but it is still far away from large-scale industrialization.  Herein, we carry out a comprehensive overview of the current state of the art in terms of three main aspects.  Firstly, a fundamental understanding of the microstructure and sodium storage mechanism of hard carbon is introduced, which can be categorized into three different processes: capacitive adsorption, nanopore filling, and intercalation in carbon interlayers.  Then, based on an in-depth understanding of the sodium storage mechanism, optimization methods in terms of increasing the specific capacity, rate performance, initial coulombic efficiency (ICE), and long-cycling stability are comprehensively summarized and analyzed.  Finally, potential methods and assocd. benefits for the design of carbon structures and the solid electrolyte interface (SEI) are discussed, hoping to provide useful guidelines for future research and commercialization.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGo4e0jCHDDXgrVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lg3bgzgdDr1XA"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3MXntlSjsb8%253D&amp;md5=d979cb5c94cd743b47028b42d41754fa</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref48"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref48" class="rightTabRefNumLink">48</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit48" data-doi="10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00642"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Lee, B.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Paek, E.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Mitlin, D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Lee, S. W.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Sodium Metal Anodes: Emerging Solutions to Dendrite Growth</span>. <i>Chem. Rev.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2019</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>119</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">8</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">5416</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">5460</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/acs.chemrev.8b00642</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit48R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">48</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Sodium metal anodes: Emerging solutions to dendrite growth</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Lee, Byeongyong; Paek, Eunsu; Mitlin, David; Lee, Seung Woo</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States)</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2019</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">119</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">8</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">5416-5460</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">CHREAY</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0009-2665</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">This comprehensive Review focuses on the key challenges and recent progress regarding sodium-metal anodes employed in sodium-metal batteries (SMBs).  The metal anode is the essential component of emerging energy storage systems such as sodium sulfur and sodium selenium, which are discussed as example full-cell applications.  We begin with a description of the differences in the chem. and phys. properties of Na metal vs. the oft-studied Li metal, and a corresponding discussion regarding the no. of ways in which Na does not follow Li-inherited paradigms in its electrochem. behavior.  We detail the major challenges for Na-metal systems that at this time limit the feasibility of SMBs.  The core Na anode problems are the following interrelated degrdn. mechanisms: An unstable solid electrolyte interphase with most org. electrolytes, "mossy" and "lath-like" metal dendrite growth for liq. systems, poor Coulombic efficiency, and gas evolution.  Even solid-state Na batteries are not immune, with metal dendrites being reported.  The solns. may be subdivided into the following interrelated taxonomy: Improved electrolytes and electrolyte additives tailored for Na-metal anodes, interfacial engineering between the metal and the liq. or solid electrolyte, electrode architectures that both reduce the c.d. during plating-stripping and serve as effective hosts that shield the Na metal from excessive reactions, and alloy design to tune the bulk properties of the metal per se.  For instance, stable plating-stripping of Na is extremely difficult with conventional carbonate solvents but has been reported with ethers and glymes.  Solid-state electrolytes (SSEs) such as beta-alumina solid electrolyte (BASE), sodium superionic conductor (NASICON), and sodium thiophosphate (75Na2S·25P2S5) present highly exciting opportunities for SMBs that avoid the dangers of flammable liqs.  Even SSEs are not immune to dendrites, however, which grow through the defects in the bulk pellet, but may be controlled through interfacial energy modification.  We conclude with a discussion of the key research areas that we feel are the most fruitful for further pursuit.  In our opinion, greatly improved understanding and control of the SEI structure is the key to cycling stability.  A holistic approach involving complementary post-mortem, in situ, and operando analyses to elucidate full battery cell level structure-performance relations is advocated.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGqQ1buYt3eMx7Vg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lg3bgzgdDr1XA"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXmsFCrtL4%253D&amp;md5=50399f6bff0463f55ea84f50d36fb802</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref49"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref49" class="rightTabRefNumLink">49</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit49" data-doi="10.1038/s41467-020-15938-x"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Bray, J. M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Doswell, C. L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Pavlovskaya, G. E.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Chen, L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kishore, B.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Au, H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Alptekin, H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kendrick, E.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Titirici, M.-M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Meersmann, T.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Britton, M. M.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Operando Visualisation of Battery Chemistry in a Sodium-Ion Battery by 23Na Magnetic Resonance Imaging</span>. <i>Nat. Commun.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2020</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>11</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">1</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">2083</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1038/s41467-020-15938-x</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit49R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">49</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Operando visualisation of battery chemistry in a sodium-ion battery by 23Na magnetic resonance imaging</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Bray, Joshua M.; Doswell, Claire L.; Pavlovskaya, Galina E.; Chen, Lin; Kishore, Brij; Au, Heather; Alptekin, Hande; Kendrick, Emma; Titirici, Maria-Magdalena; Meersmann, Thomas; Britton, Melanie M.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Nature Communications</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2020</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">11</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">1</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">2083</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">NCAOBW</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">2041-1723</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Nature Research</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Sodium-ion batteries are a promising battery technol. for their cost and sustainability.  This has led to increasing interest in the development of new sodium-ion batteries and new anal. methods to non-invasively, directly visualise battery chem.  Here we report operando 1H and 23Na NMR spectroscopy and imaging expts. to observe the speciation and distribution of sodium in the electrode and electrolyte during sodiation and desodiation of hard carbon in a sodium metal cell and a sodium-ion full-cell configuration.  The evolution of the hard carbon sodiation and subsequent formation and evolution of sodium dendrites, upon over-sodiation of the hard carbon, are obsd. and mapped by 23Na NMR spectroscopy and imaging, and their three-dimensional microstructure visualised by 1H magnetic resonance imaging.  We also observe, for the first time, the formation of metallic sodium species on hard carbon upon first charge (formation) in a full-cell configuration.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGqlISiMMjJe-bVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lg3bgzgdDr1XA"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXosVOmu7w%253D&amp;md5=dd9f9f777d0e67de51e9f0c49bd5a1e0</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref50"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref50" class="rightTabRefNumLink">50</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit50" data-doi="10.1039/C6TA04611H"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Mei, Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Huang, Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hu, X.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Nanostructured Ti-Based Anode Materials for Na-Ion Batteries</span>. <i>J. Mater. Chem. A</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2016</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>4</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">31</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">12001</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">12013</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1039/C6TA04611H</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit50R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">50</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Nanostructured Ti-based anode materials for Na-ion batteries</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Mei, Yueni; Huang, Yunhui; Hu, Xianluo</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2016</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">4</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">31</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">12001-12013</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JMCAET</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">2050-7496</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Royal Society of Chemistry</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">With the shortage of fossil energy and global climate change, renewable energy sources offer the most promising solns. to these challenges.  However, the intermittence of energy sources such as solar and wind requires sustainable energy storage technologies.  Nowadays, electrochem. energy storage technologies and applications have attracted much attention, including portable elec. devices, elec. vehicles and smart power grids.  Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have been widely applied in these areas because of their safety, portability and high energy d.  Nevertheless, the resources of lithium are limited and the vast consumption of lithium has pushed up the price of lithium compds., urging people to search for resourceful materials.  Sodium can be a promising alternative due to its high abundance and low cost.  Furthermore, titanium-based materials have become a hot spot for anode materials in sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), with their advantages of high safety and structural stability.  In this review, we summarize the recent advances in Ti-based anode materials for SIB applications.  We highlight the design and engineering of Ti-based nanoarchitectures, esp. emphasizing the effective enhancement in performance and the related sodium storage mechanism.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGpa4N56ebVXIbVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lg3bgzgdDr1XA"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhtVynt73M&amp;md5=40308f2ab8b2beb4f73c5fe67992c973</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref51"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref51" class="rightTabRefNumLink">51</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit51" data-doi="10.1038/ncomms2878"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Sun, Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Zhao, L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Pan, H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Lu, X.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Gu, L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hu, Y.-S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Li, H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Armand, M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ikuhara, Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Chen, L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Huang, X.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Direct Atomic-Scale Confirmation of Three-Phase Storage Mechanism in Li4Ti5O12 Anodes for Room-Temperature Sodium-Ion Batteries</span>. <i>Nat. Commun.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2013</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>4</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">1</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">1870</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1038/ncomms2878</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit51R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">51</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Direct atomic-scale confirmation of three-phase storage mechanism in Li4Ti5O12 anodes for room-temperature sodium-ion batteries</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Sun Yang; Zhao Liang; Pan Huilin; Lu Xia; Gu Lin; Hu Yong-Sheng; Li Hong; Armand Michel; Ikuhara Yuichi; Chen Liquan; Huang Xuejie</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Nature communications</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2013</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">4</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue"></span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">1870</span>
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn"></span>.
    </div><div class="casAbstract">Room-temperature sodium-ion batteries attract increasing attention for large-scale energy storage applications in renewable energy and smart grid.  However, the development of suitable anode materials remains a challenging issue.  Here we demonstrate that the spinel Li4Ti5O12, well-known as a 'zero-strain' anode for lithium-ion batteries, can also store sodium, displaying an average storage voltage of 0.91 V.  With an appropriate binder, the Li4Ti5O12 electrode delivers a reversible capacity of 155 mAh g(-1) and presents the best cyclability among all reported oxide-based anode materials.  Density functional theory calculations predict a three-phase separation mechanism, 2Li4Ti5O12+6Na(+)+6e(-)↔Li7Ti5O12+Na6LiTi5O12, which has been confirmed through in situ synchrotron X-ray diffraction and advanced scanning transmission electron microscope imaging techniques.  The three-phase separation reaction has never been seen in any insertion electrode materials for lithium- or sodium-ion batteries.  Furthermore, interfacial structure is clearly resolved at an atomic scale in electrochemically sodiated Li4Ti5O12 for the first time via the advanced electron microscopy.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=LOZGTtr2ZcQPgY8GEu_hzRKDYG3bNImrfW6udTcc2ebPP-YrkrZbn7ntkvexoksv"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC3snlvFClsQ%253D%253D&amp;md5=1ba227dbac0d64af21c548092cc2eb4c</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref52"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref52" class="rightTabRefNumLink">52</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit52" data-doi="10.1002/smll.201904484"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Natarajan, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Subramanyan, K.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Aravindan, V.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Focus on Spinel Li <sub>4</sub> Ti <sub>5</sub> O <sub>12</sub> as Insertion Type Anode for High-Performance Na-Ion Batteries</span>. <i>Small</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2019</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>15</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">49</span>), <span class="NLM_elocation-id">e1904484</span> <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:

                        rightTab-cas_cit53R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">53</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">A high precision study of the effect of vinylene carbonate (VC) additive in Li/graphite cells</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Xiong, Deijun; Burns, J. C.; Smith, A. J.; Sinha, Nupur; Dahn, J. R.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of the Electrochemical Society</span>

            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Electrochemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Li/graphite coin cells contg. different amts. of vinylene carbonate (VC) electrolyte additive were examd. at different temps. using the High Precision Charger at Dalhousie University.  The charge endpoint capacities as well as the coulombic efficiency (CE) were compared to characterize the effect of the VC additive on the graphite electrode.  The expts. show that VC improves the coulombic efficiency and reduces charge and discharge endpoint slippage at 50 and 60°C.  However, the addn. of VC has little evident effect on the performance of the graphite electrode at 30 and 40°C and also increases the irreversible capacity.  By contrast, addns. of VC have a marked impact on the coulombic efficiency and slippages of NMC pos. electrodes, even at 30°C.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGoV1afo2gycNLVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lj_ZN0H1W-X2w"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhsVyks7jF&amp;md5=4bc3ac9566fbb0c9398a5ca90e7b16dd</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref54"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref54" class="rightTabRefNumLink">54</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit54" data-doi="10.1021/acs.chemmater.5b01627"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Schroder, K.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Alvarado, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Yersak, T.                         rightTab-cas_cit54R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">54</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">The Effect of Fluoroethylene Carbonate as an Additive on the Solid Electrolyte Interphase on Silicon Lithium-Ion Electrodes</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Schroder, Kjell; Alvarado, Judith; Yersak, Thomas A.; Li, Juchuan; Dudney, Nancy; Webb, Lauren J.; Meng, Ying Shirley; Stevenson, Keith J.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Chemistry of Materials</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2015</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">27</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">16</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">5531-5542</span>CODEN:
