            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) has become a std. electrolyte additive for use with Si neg. electrodes, but how FEC affects solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) formation on the Si anode's surface is still not well understood.  Herein, SEI formed from LiPF6-based carbonate electrolytes, with and without FEC, were studied on 50 nm thick amorphous Si thin film electrodes to understand the role of FEC on Si electrode surface reactions.  In contrast to previous work, anhyd. and anoxic techniques were used to prevent air and moisture contamination of prepd. SEI films.  This allowed for accurate characterization of the SEI structure and compn. by XPS and time-of-flight secondary ion mass spectrometry depth profiling.  FEC redn. leads to F- ion and LiF formation, consistent with previous computational and exptl. results.  Surprisingly, also these species decrease Li-ion soly. and increase the reactivity of the Si surface.  The effectiveness of FEC at improving the Coulombic efficiency and capacity retention is due to F- ion formation from redn. of the electrolyte, which leads to the chem. attack of any Si-oxide surface passivation layers and the formation of a kinetically stable SEI comprising predominately LiF and Li oxide.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGqSv3p3Tp69f7Vg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lj_ZN0H1W-X2w"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXht1OqsbzJ&amp;md5=e86fa14fac83156dfafd6d6eed502ba8</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref55"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref55" class="rightTabRefNumLink">55</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit55" data-doi="10.1021/acsenergylett.0c00468"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kim, K.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ma, H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Park, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Choi, N.-S.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Electrolyte-Additive-Driven Interfacial Engineering for High-Capacity Electrodes in Lithium-Ion Batteries: Promise and Challenges</span>. <i>ACS Energy Lett.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2020</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>5</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">5</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">1537</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">1553</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/acsenergylett.0c00468</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit55R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">55</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Electrolyte-Additive-Driven Interfacial Engineering for High-Capacity Electrodes in Lithium-Ion Batteries: Promise and Challenges</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Kim, Koeun; Ma, Hyunsoo; Park, Sewon; Choi, Nam-Soon</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">ACS Energy Letters</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2020</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">5</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">5</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">1537-1553</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">AELCCP</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">2380-8195</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A review.  Electrolyte additives have been explored to attain significant breakthroughs in the long-term cycling performance of lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) without sacrificing energy d.; this has been achieved through the development of stable electrode interfacial structures and the elimination of reactive substances.  Here we highlight the potential and the challenges raised by studies on electrolyte additives toward addressing the interfacially induced deterioration of high-capacity electrodes with a focus on Ni-rich layered oxides and Si, which are expected to satisfy the growing demands for high-energy-d. batteries.  We also discuss issues with the design of electrolyte additives for practical viability.  A deep understanding of the roles of existing electrolyte additives depending on their functional groups will aid in the design of functional additive moieties capable of building robust interfacial layers, scavenging undesired reactive species, and suppressing the gas generation that causes safety hazards and shortened lifetimes of LIBs.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGotA865zYIcA7Vg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lj_ZN0H1W-X2w"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXmsV2gtbo%253D&amp;md5=13a54ec47122b6c29d5ecff4ca94473d</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref56"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref56" class="rightTabRefNumLink">56</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit56" data-doi="10.1021/acs.chemmater.6b02282"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Michan, A.             (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">We have synthesized the products of fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) and vinylene carbonate (VC) via lithium naphthalenide redn.  By analyzing the resulting solid ppts. and gas evolution, our results confirm that both FEC and VC decompn. products include HCO2Li, Li2C2O4, Li2CO3, and polymd. VC.  For FEC, our exptl. data supports a redn. mechanism where FEC reduces to form VC and LiF, followed by subsequent VC redn.  In the FEC redn. product, HCO2Li, Li2C2O4, and Li2CO3 were found in smaller quantities than in the VC redn. product, with no addnl. fluorine environments being detected by solid-state NMR or XPS anal.  With these additives being practically used in higher (FEC) and lower (VC) concns. in the base electrolytes of lithium-ion batteries, our results suggest that the different relative ratios of the inorg. and org. redn. products formed by their decompn. may be relevant to the chem. compn. and morphol. of the solid electrolyte interphase formed in their presence.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGqRaEl0XEDeCLVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lj_ZN0H1W-X2w"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28Xhs1ylurvP&amp;md5=42c57482d705b409e35d7bd110357adf</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref57"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref57" class="rightTabRefNumLink">57</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit57" data-doi="10.1149/1945-7111/ab75fd"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Fondard, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Irisarri, E.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Courrèges, C.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Palacin, M.                 10.1149/1945-7111/ab75fd</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit57R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">57</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">SEI composition on hard carbon in Na-Ion batteries after long cycling: Influence of salts (NaPF6, NaTFSI) and Additives (FEC, DMCF)</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Fondard, J.; Irisarri, E.; Courreges, C.; Palacin, M. R.; Ponrouch, A.; Dedryvere, R.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of the Electrochemical Society</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2020</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">167</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">7</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">070526</span>CODEN:

            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Electrochemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A study of the solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) on hard-carbon (HC) electrodes in sodium half-cells is presented.  Electrochem. performances over &gt; 100 cycles were compared with two different salts (NaPF6, NaTFSI) and two different electrolyte additives (FEC, DMCF) in a mixt. of EC and DMC solvents.  The best electrochem. performances were obsd. with NaPF6 salt in conjunction with 3% FEC.  The DMCF additive had a detrimental effect in all electrolyte combinations.  The chem. characterization of the SEI was carried out by XPS and showed that the best electrochem. behavior was related to an SEI compn. based on sodium ethylene dicarbonate and NaF, whereas poorer electrochem. performances were assocd. to either low NaF or high Na2CO3 content.  The results reported herein provide an insight on the SEI chem. on hard carbon electrodes in sodium cells after long-term cycling, as a complement to previous studies dealing with the first cycles.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGq4rxL0JhE-c7Vg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lj_ZN0H1W-X2w"> &gt;&gt;                 10.1002/celc.201600365</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit58R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">58</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Effect of Hexafluorophosphate and Fluoroethylene Carbonate on Electrochemical Performance and Surface Layer of Hard Carbon for Sodium-Ion Batteries</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Dahbi, Mouad; Nakano, Takeshi; Yabuuchi, Naoaki; Fujimura, Shun; Chihara, Kuniko; Son, Jin-Young; Cui, Yi-Tao; Oji, Hiroshi; Komaba, Shinichi</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">ChemElectroChem</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2016</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">3</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">11</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">1856-1867</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">CHEMRA</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">2196-0216</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH &amp; Co. KGaA</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Electrochem. sodium insertion for hard carbon is examd. in a cyclic alkylene carbonate-based soln. contg. sodium perchlorate (NaClO4) or sodium hexafluorophosphate (NaPF6) salt with fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) additive to study electrolyte dependency for Na-ion batteries.  NaPF6-based electrolytes provided superior reversibility and cyclability of sodium insertion into hard carbon compared to NaClO4-based ones.  The FEC-derived passivation film improves the capacity retention because of better passivation with a thinner surface layer, which is revealed by hard and soft XPS (PES).  Using both the NaPF6 salt and FEC additive results in a synergetic effect on passivation for the hard-carbon electrode, leading to enhanced cycle performance.  Hard-carbon electrodes with poly (vinylede difluoride) binder in propylene carbonate-based electrolytes contg. NaPF6 and FEC demonstrates the excellent capacity retention with reversible capacity of ca. 250 mAh g-1.  The difference in capacity retention for the electrolytes is expected to originate from a consequence of the difference in the surface interphase layer formed on the hard-carbon electrodes.  Surface analyses with PES and time-of-flight secondary ion mass spectroscopy revealed differences in surface and passivation chem., which depends on the salts, solvents, and FEC additive used for the hard-carbon neg. electrodes.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGoT-YhGkJXMTrVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lj_ZN0H1W-X2w"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhtlegtbzP&amp;md5=f7d038a8c9ca89bf77adff243608c016</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref59"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref59" class="rightTabRefNumLink">59</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit59" data-doi="10.1016/j.elecom.2012.10.038"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ponrouch, A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Goñi, A.         </div><div class="casAbstract">Electrochem. performance of hard carbon prepd. from sugar pyrolysis was investigated against sodium anodes.  Sp. surface area and graphitization degree are determinant for achieving the highest reversible capacity ever reported (more than 300 mAh/g at C/10 after 120 cycles) with excellent rate capability.  Such results were obtained using additive free EC:PC based electrolyte which appears to induce the formation of a more conducting solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) than that produced in the presence of 2% fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC).</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGo1-09s1Aql_7Vg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lh5JrgrrOzD3Q"> &gt;&gt;                         rightTab-cas_cit60R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">60</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Sodium carboxymethyl cellulose as a potential binder for hard-carbon negative electrodes in sodium-ion batteries</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Dahbi, Mouad; Nakano, Takeshi; Yabuuchi, Naoaki; Ishikawa, Toru; Kubota, Kei; Fukunishi, Mika; Shibahara, Sota; Son, Jin-Young; Cui, Yi-Tao; Oji, Hiroshi; Komaba, Shinichi</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Electrochemistry Communications</span>

            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Elsevier B.V.</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">For a non-aq. sodium-ion battery, a hard-carbon neg. electrode with sodium CM-cellulose (CMC) binder demonstrates the superior reversibility and cycleability in NaPF6 propylene carbonate soln. at room temp. to that with ordinary poly(vinylidene difluoride) (PVdF) binder. K. Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Greeley, J. P.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">First-Principles Analysis of Defect Thermodynamics and Ion Transport in Inorganic SEI Compounds: LiF and NaF</span>. <i>ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2015</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>7</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">34</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">18985</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">18996</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/acsami.5b02904</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit61R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">61</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">First-Principles Analysis of Defect Thermodynamics and Ion Transport in Inorganic SEI Compounds: LiF and NaF</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Yildirim, Handan; Kinaci, Alper; Chan, Maria K. Y.; Greeley, Jeffrey P.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">ACS Applied Materials &amp; Interfaces</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2015</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">7</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">34</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">18985-18996</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">AAMICK</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1944-8244</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">The formation mechanism and compn. of the solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) in lithium ion batteries has been widely explored.  However, relatively little is known about the function of the SEI as a transport medium.  Such crit. information is directly relevant to battery rate performance, power loss, and capacity fading.  To partially bridge this gap in the case of inorg. SEI compds., we report herein the results of first-principles calcns. on the defect thermodn., the dominant diffusion carriers, and the diffusion pathways assocd. with cryst. LiF and NaF, which are stable components of the SEI in Li-ion and Na-ion batteries, resp.  The thermodn. of common point defects are computed, and the dominant diffusion carriers are detd. over a voltage range of 0-4 V, corresponding to conditions relevant to both anode and cathode SEI's.  Our analyses reveal that for both compds., vacancy defects are energetically more favorable, therefore form more readily than interstitials, due to the close-packed nature of the crystal structures.  However, the vacancy concns. are very small for the diffusion processes facilitated by defects.  Ionic conductivities are calcd. as a function of voltage, considering the diffusion carrier concn. and the diffusion barriers as detd. by nudged elastic band calcns.  These conductivities are more than ten orders of magnitude smaller in NaF than in LiF.  As compared to the diffusivity of Li in other common inorg. SEI compds., such as Li2CO3 and Li2O, the cation diffusivity in LiF and NaF is quite low, with at least three orders of magnitude lower ionic conductivities.  The results quantify the extent to which fluorides pose rate limitations in Li and Na batteries.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGpaMaiGxrecebVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lh5JrgrrOzD3Q"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXht12ksb7I&amp;md5=3020ddf82e8a1e83be5fbd67d3a54589</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref62"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref62" class="rightTabRefNumLink">62</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit62" data-doi="10.1021/ja301266w"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Wang, Y.-Q.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Gu, L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Guo, Y.-G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Li, H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">He, X.-Q.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Tsukimoto, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ikuhara, Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Wan, L.-J.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Rutile-TiO <sub>2</sub> Nanocoating for a High-Rate Li <sub>4</sub> Ti <sub>5</sub> O <sub>12</sub> Anode of a Lithium-Ion Battery</span>. <i>J. Am. Chem. Soc.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2012</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>134</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">18</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">7874</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">7879</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/ja301266w</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit62R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">62</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Rutile-TiO2 Nanocoating for a High-Rate Li4Ti5O12 Anode of a Lithium-Ion Battery</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Wang, Yong-Qing; Gu, Lin; Guo, Yu-Guo; Li, Hong; He, Xiao-Qing; Tsukimoto, Susumu; Ikuhara, Yuichi; Wan, Li-Jun</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of the American Chemical Society</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2012</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">134</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">18</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">7874-7879</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JACSAT</span>;

            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Well-defined Li4Ti5O12 nanosheets terminated with rutile-TiO2 at the edges were synthesized by a facile soln.-based method and revealed directly by an advanced spherical aberration imaging technique.  The rutile-TiO2 terminated Li4Ti5O12 nanosheets show much improved rate capability and specific capacity compared with pure Li4Ti5O12 nanosheets when used as anode materials for Li ion batteries.  The results here give clear evidence of the utility of rutile-TiO2 as a C-free coating layer to improve the kinetics of Li4Ti5O12 toward fast Li insertion/extn.  The C-free nanocoating of rutile-TiO2 is highly effective in improving the electrochem. properties of Li4Ti5O12, promising advanced batteries with high volumetric energy d., high surface stability, and long cycle life compared with the commonly used C nanocoating in electrode materials.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGr0VwW0ZElZCbVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lh5JrgrrOzD3Q"> &gt;&gt;             (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">John Wiley &amp; Sons Ltd.</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A review.  With the description of more and more complex 1- and two-dimensional NMR expts. comes the need to develop methods to make a comprehensive interpretation of the various different expts. that can be carried out on the same sample or series of related samples.  The authors present some examples of modeling 1- and two-dimensional solid-state NMR spectra of I = 1/2 spin and quadrupolar nuclei, using lab.-developed software that is made available to the NMR community.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGr71caHDG6zjLVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lh5JrgrrOzD3Q"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38Xlt1ajuw%253D%253D&amp;md5=d32cb46ca90ac83a8f2d62c95a93a88f</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref64"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref64" class="rightTabRefNumLink">64</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit64" data-doi="10.1016/j.cplett.2006.06.007"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Thakur, R.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kurur, N.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Madhu, P.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Swept-Frequency Two-Pulse Phase Modulation for Heteronuclear Dipolar Decoupling in Solid-State NMR</span>. <i>Chem.                 10.1016/j.cplett.2006.06.007</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit64R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">64</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Swept-frequency two-pulse phase modulation for heteronuclear dipolar decoupling in solid-state NMR</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Thakur, Rajendra Singh; Kurur, Narayanan D.; Madhu, P. K.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Chemical Physics Letters</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2006</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">426</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">4-6</span>),

        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0009-2614</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Elsevier B.V.</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">We introduce a heteronuclear dipolar decoupling sequence for application in solid-state NMR.  The sequence, called swept-frequency two-pulse phase modulation (SWf-TPPM), is based on one of the decoupling sequences, TPPM.  The sequence is robust in performance with respect to various exptl. parameters, such as, the pulse flip angle, pulse phase, and offset and a comparison is made with other decoupling schemes, namely TPPM, SPINAL, and XiX, on a sample of U-13C-labeled tyrosine for magic-angle spinning speeds up to 14 kHz.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGohIwVJDXGE-bVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lh5JrgrrOzD3Q"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XntlWgs7c%253D&amp;md5=ed9ed195f49e0c590ec60cc1f3218632</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref65"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref65" class="rightTabRefNumLink">65</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit65" data-doi="10.1007/1-4020-3910-7_89"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Gullion, T.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Rotational-Echo, Double-Resonance NMR</span>. In  <i>Modern Magnetic Resonance</i>; <span class="NLM_publisher-name">Springer Netherlands</span>: <span class="NLM_publisher-loc">Dordrecht</span>, <span class="NLM_year">2008</span>; pp  <span class="NLM_fpage">713</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">718</span>.<span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1007/1-4020-3910-7_89</span> .</span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord empty" id="

A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ceder, G.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Python Materials Genomics (Pymatgen): A Robust, Open-Source Python Library for Materials Analysis</span>. <i>Comput. Mater. Sci.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2013</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>68</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">314</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">319</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1016/j.commatsci.2012.10.028</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit67R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">67</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Python Materials Genomics (pymatgen): A robust, open-source python library for materials analysis</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Ong, Shyue Ping; Richards, William Davidson; Jain, Anubhav; Hautier, Geoffroy; Kocher, Michael; Cholia, Shreyas; Gunter, Dan; Chevrier, Vincent L.; Persson, Kristin A.; Ceder, Gerbrand</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Computational Materials Science</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2013</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">68</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue"></span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">314-319</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">CMMSEM</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0927-0256</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Elsevier B.V.</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">We present the Python Materials Genomics (pymatgen) library, a robust, open-source Python library for materials anal.  A key enabler in high-throughput computational materials science efforts is a robust set of software tools to perform initial setup for the calcns. (e.g., generation of structures and necessary input files) and post-calcn. anal. to derive useful material properties from raw calcd. data.  The pymatgen library aims to meet these needs by (1) defining core Python objects for materials data representation, (2) providing a well-tested set of structure and thermodn. analyses relevant to many applications, and (3) establishing an open platform for researchers to collaboratively develop sophisticated analyses of materials data obtained both from first principles calcns. and expts.  The pymatgen library also provides convenient tools to obtain useful materials data via the Materials Project's REpresentational State Transfer (REST) Application Programming Interface (API).  As an example, using pymatgen's interface to the Materials Project's RESTful API and phase diagram package, we demonstrate how the phase and electrochem. stability of a recently synthesized material, Li4SnS4, can be analyzed using a min. of computing resources.  We find that Li4SnS4 is a stable phase in the Li-Sn-S phase diagram (consistent with the fact that it can be synthesized), but the narrow range of lithium chem. potentials for which it is predicted to be stable would suggest that it is not intrinsically stable against typical electrodes used in lithium-ion batteries.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGpaZmfhPTuVrLVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lh5JrgrrOzD3Q"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhsVGjt7g%253D&amp;md5=104f567dbd8f4199911ded91bc42100e</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref68"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref68" class="rightTabRefNumLink">68</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit68" data-doi="10.1524/zkri.220.5.567.65075"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Clark, S.             (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Oldenbourg Wissenschaftsverlag GmbH</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">The CASTEP code for first principles electronic structure calcns. is described.  A brief, non-tech. overview is given and some of the features and capabilities highlighted.  Some features which are unique to CASTEP are described and near-future development plans outlined.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGooz4-HvIpWsLVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lg0o1c76St1bA"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXmsVSitbk%253D&amp;md5=edb75e2f9d4df4ad83f4df7db21888e7</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref69"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref69" class="rightTabRefNumLink">69</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit69" data-doi="10.1103/PhysRevB.76.024401"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Yates, J.                 10.1103/PhysRevB.76.024401</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit69R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">69</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Calculation of NMR chemical shifts for extended systems using ultrasoft pseudopotentials</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Yates, Jonathan R.; Pickard, Chris J.; Mauri, Francesco</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Physical Review B: Condensed Matter and Materials Physics</span>

    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">76</span>

            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Physical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">The authors present a scheme for the calcn. of magnetic response parameters in insulators using ultrasoft pseudopotentials.  It uses the gauge-including projector augmented wave method [C. J. Pickard and F. Mauri, Phys. Rev. B 63, 245101(2001)] to obtain all-electron accuracy for both finite and infinitely periodic systems.  In detail the calcn. of NMR chem. shieldings are considered.  The approach is successfully validated 1st for mol. systems by comparing calcd. chem. shieldings for a range of mols. with quantum chem. results and then in the solid state by comparing 17O NMR parameters calcd. for silicates with expt.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGq3iYusryxitrVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lg0o1c76St1bA"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXos1ajtr8%253D&amp;md5=8aea5f8a0810a82518bfa5f9c6fad19f</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref70"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref70" class="rightTabRefNumLink">70</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit70" data-doi="10.1103/PhysRevB.63.245101"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Pickard, C. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Mauri, F.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">All-Electron Magnetic Response with Pseudopotentials: NMR Chemical Shifts</span>. <i>Phys.                 10.1103/PhysRevB.63.245101</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit70R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">70</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">All-electron magnetic response with pseudopotentials: NMR chemical shifts</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Pickard, Chris J.; Mauri, Francesco</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Physical Review B: Condensed Matter and Materials Physics</span>

            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Physical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A theory for the ab initio calcn. of all-electron NMR chem. shifts in insulators using pseudopotentials is presented.  It is formulated for both finite and infinitely periodic systems and is based on an extension to the projector augmented-wave approach of Blochl [P. E. Blochl, Phys. Rev. B 50, 17953 (1994)] and the method of Mauri et al. [F. Mauri, B. G. Pfrommer, and S. G. Louie, Phys. Rev. Lett. 77, 5300 (1996)].  The theory is successfully validated for mols. by comparison with a selection of quantum chem. results, and in periodic systems by comparison with plane-wave all-electron results for diamond.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGo2yQHc0EjyKLVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lg0o1c76St1bA"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXlt12rs74%253D&amp;md5=7ae73923f2a7cc90a36a5e3c7ef2c35a</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref71"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref71" class="rightTabRefNumLink">71</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit71" data-doi="10.1103/PhysRevLett.77.3865"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Perdew, J. Rev. Lett.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">1996</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>77</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">18</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">3865</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">3868</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1103/PhysRevLett.77.3865</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit71R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">71</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Generalized gradient approximation made simple</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Perdew, John P.; Burke, Kieron; Ernzerhof, Matthias</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Physical Review Letters</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">1996</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">77</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">18</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">3865-3868</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">PRLTAO</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0031-9007</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Physical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Generalized gradient approxns. (GGA's) for the exchange-correlation energy improve upon the local spin d. (LSD) description of atoms, mols., and solids.  We present a simple derivation of a simple GGA, in which all parameters (other than those in LSD) are fundamental consts.  Only general features of the detailed construction underlying the Perdew-Wang 1991 (PW91) GGA are invoked.  Improvements over PW91 include an accurate description of the linear response of the uniform electron gas, correct behavior under uniform scaling, and a smoother potential.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGokga1tVzFw07Vg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lg0o1c76St1bA"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK28XmsVCgsbs%253D&amp;md5=55943538406ee74f93aabdf882cd4630</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref72"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref72" class="rightTabRefNumLink">72</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit72" data-doi="10.1063/1.1541625"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Yates, J. R.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Pickard, C. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Payne, M. C.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Mauri, F.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Relativistic Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Chemical Shifts of Heavy Nuclei with Pseudopotentials and the Zeroth-Order Regular Approximation</span>. <i>J. Chem. Phys.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2003</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>118</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">13</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">5746</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">5753</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1063/1.1541625</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="

        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2003</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">118</span>

            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Institute of Physics</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">We present a method for the 1st principles d. functional calcn. of relativistic all-electron NMR chem. shifts using pseudopotentials.  The method is based on the gauge including projector augmented wave approach of Pickard and Mauri (2001).  Relativistic effects are included at the level of the scalar-relativistic zeroth-order regular approxn.  The method allows chem. shifts of large, low symmetry structures contg. heavy elements to be calcd. efficiently.  We demonstrate its success for a range of Se and Te contg. mols.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGoLY52N4fV7hrVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lg0o1c76St1bA"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXitlemsr0%253D&amp;md5=488734071412154e1b1ae04245018c5e</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref73"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref73" class="rightTabRefNumLink">73</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit73" data-doi="10.1039/D2TA05823E"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Sebti, E.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Qi, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Richardson, P.                 10.1039/D2TA05823E</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord empty" id="
                            rightTab-cas_R
                        "><div class="casContent">There is no corresponding record for this reference.</div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref74"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref74" class="rightTabRefNumLink">74</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit74" data-doi="10.1088/1674-1056/21/2/028201"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Zhao, L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Pan, H.-L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hu, Y.-S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Li, H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Chen, L.-Q.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Spinel Lithium Titanate (Li <sub>4</sub> Ti <sub>5</sub> O <sub>12</sub>) as Novel Anode Material for Room-Temperature Sodium-Ion Battery</span>. <i>Chin. Phys. B</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2012</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>21</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">2</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">028201</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1088/1674-1056/21/2/028201</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord empty" id="
                            rightTab-cas_R
                        "><div class="casContent">There is no corresponding record for this reference.</div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref75"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref75" class="rightTabRefNumLink">75</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit75" data-doi="10.1016/j.jpowsour.2015.02.061"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Zhou, Q.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Liu, L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Tan, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Yan, Z.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Huang, Z.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Wang, X.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Synthesis of Lithium Titanate Nanorods as Anode Materials for Lithium and Sodium Ion Batteries with Superior Electrochemical Performance</span>. <i>J. Power Sources</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2015</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>283</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">243</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">250</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1016/j.jpowsour.2015.02.061</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit75R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">75</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Synthesis of lithium titanate nanorods as anode materials for lithium and sodium ion batteries with superior electrochemical performance</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Zhou, Qian; Liu, Li; Tan, Jinli; Yan, Zichao; Huang, Zhifeng; Wang, Xianyou</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Power Sources</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2015</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">283</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue"></span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">243-250</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JPSODZ</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0378-7753</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Elsevier B.V.</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Li4Ti5O12 nanorods have been successfully synthesized via hydrothermal method using TiO2-B as titanium source and template.  Such Li4Ti5O12 nanorods with sizes of 100-200 nm in diam. and 1-2 μm in length can be obsd.  The Li4Ti5O12 nanorods exhibit high discharge capacity of about 101.1 mAh g-1 after 1000 cycles at 20C for the lithium ion battery anode.  The Li4Ti5O12 nanorods also show excellent sodium storage performance, which have a reversible capacity of approx. 131.6 mAh g-1 after 100 cycles at 0.1C.  Based on the electrochem. performance, it is suggested that Li4Ti5O12 nanorods have a great potential for lithium and sodium ion battery that are available as large-scale storage devices for applications such as automotive and stationary energy storage.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGocVSAr2EY5YbVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lg0o1c76St1bA"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXjtlWhsrk%253D&amp;md5=31df4368148259649bd3002b718246c2</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref76"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref76" class="rightTabRefNumLink">76</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit76" data-doi="10.1039/C7TA03173D"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Liu, Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Liu, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hou, M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Fan, L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Wang, Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Xia, Y.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Carbon-Coated Li <sub>4</sub> Ti <sub>5</sub> O <sub>12</sub> Nanoparticles with High Electrochemical Performance as Anode Material in Sodium-Ion Batteries</span>. <i>J. Magn. Reson.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2019</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>99</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">February</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">7</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">14</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1016/j.ssnmr.2019.02.003</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord empty" id="
                            rightTab-cas_R
                        "><div class="casContent">There is no corresponding record for this reference.</div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref83"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref83" class="rightTabRefNumLink">83</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit83" data-doi="10.1021/acs.jpcc.0c00858"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Harchol, A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Reuveni, G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ri, V.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Thomas, B.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Carmieli, R.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Herber, R. H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kim, C.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Leskes, M.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Endogenous Dynamic Nuclear Polarization for Sensitivity Enhancement in Solid-State NMR of Electrode Materials</span>. <i>J. Phys. Chem. C</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2020</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>124</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">13</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">7082</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">7090</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/acs.jpcc.0c00858</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit83R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">83</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Endogenous Dynamic Nuclear Polarization for Sensitivity Enhancement in Solid-State NMR of Electrode Materials</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Harchol, Adi; Reuveni, Guy; Ri, Vitalii; Thomas, Brijith; Carmieli, Raanan; Herber, Rolfe H.; Kim, Chunjoong; Leskes, Michal</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Physical Chemistry C</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2020</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">124</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">13</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">7082-7090</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JPCCCK</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1932-7447</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Rational design of materials for energy storage systems relies on our ability to probe these materials at various length scales.  Solid-state NMR spectroscopy is a powerful approach for gaining chem. and structural insights at the at./mol. level, but its low detection sensitivity often limits applicability.  This limitation can be overcome by transferring the high polarization of electron spins to the sample of interest in a process called dynamic nuclear polarization (DNP).  Here, we employ for the first time metal ion-based DNP to probe pristine and cycled composite battery electrodes.  A new and efficient DNP agent, Fe(III), is introduced, yielding lithium signal enhancement up to 180 when substituted in the anode material Li4Ti5O12.  In addn. for being DNP active, Fe(III) improves the anode performance.  Redn. of Fe(III) to Fe(II) upon cycling can be monitored in the loss of DNP activity.  We show that the dopant can be reactivated (return to Fe(III)) for DNP by increasing the cycling potential window.  Furthermore, we demonstrate that the deleterious effect of carbon additives on the DNP process can be eliminated by using carbon free electrodes, doped with Fe(III) and Mn(II), which provide good electrochem. performance as well as sensitivity in DNP-NMR.  We expect that the approach presented here will expand the applicability of DNP for studying materials for frontier challenges in materials chem. assocd. with energy and sustainability.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGpT9MjWnIILJLVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0liNya2G66Xdxw"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXktlOntrs%253D&amp;md5=9a22e73f910fd29994f4ca3f7ace0b3a</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref84"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref84" class="rightTabRefNumLink">84</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit84" data-doi="10.1039/C4TA04428B"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ponrouch, A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Monti, D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Boschin, A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Steen, B.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Johansson, P.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Palacín, M. R.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Non-Aqueous Electrolytes for Sodium-Ion Batteries</span>. <i>J. Mater. Chem. A</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2015</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>3</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">1</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">22</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">42</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1039/C4TA04428B</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit84R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">84</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Non-aqueous electrolytes for sodium-ion batteries</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Ponrouch, A.; Monti, D.; Boschin, A.; Steen, B.; Johansson, P.; Palacin, M. R.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2015</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">3</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">1</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">22-42</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JMCAET</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">2050-7496</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Royal Society of Chemistry</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A review.  The 1st review of the various electrolytes currently used and developed for Na-ion batteries (SIBs), both in terms of materials and concepts, is presented.  In contrast to the Li-ion battery (LIB), which is a mature technol. for which a more or less unanimously accepted std. electrolyte exists: 1 M LiPF6 in EC/DMC, the electrolyte of choice for SIBs has not yet fully conformed to a std.  This is true for both materials: salts, solvents, or additives, and concept, using the main track of org. solvents or aiming for other concepts.  SIB research currently prospers, benefitting from using know-how gained from 30 years of LIB R and D.  Here the currently employed electrolytes are emphasized and their effects on practical SIB performance are outlined, scrutinizing the rationale for specific choices made, salts, solvents, additives, concns., etc. for each specific cell set-up and usage conditions.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGpb_d9E3Qe0wLVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0liNya2G66Xdxw"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhslOjtLfI&amp;md5=b99d9ac3e00e101e25ffc33ee1bef953</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref85"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref85" class="rightTabRefNumLink">85</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit85" data-doi="10.1021/jacs.6b11333"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Reeve, Z. E. M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Franko, C. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Harris, K.
