Soc.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2017</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>139</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">2</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">595</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">598</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/jacs.6b11333</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit85R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">85</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Detection of Electrochemical Reaction Products from the Sodium-Oxygen Cell with Solid-State 23Na NMR Spectroscopy</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Reeve, Zoe E. M.; Franko, Christopher J.; Harris, Kristopher J.; Yadegari, Hossein; Sun, Xueliang; Goward, Gillian R.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of the American Chemical Society</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2017</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">139</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">2</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">595-598</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JACSAT</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0002-7863</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">23Na MAS NMR spectra of sodium-oxygen (Na-O2) cathodes reveals a combination of degrdn. species: newly obsd. sodium fluoride (NaF) and the expected sodium carbonate (Na2CO3), as well as the desired reaction product sodium peroxide (Na2O2).  The initial reaction product, sodium superoxide (NaO2), is not present in a measurable quantity in the 23Na NMR spectra of the cycled electrodes.  The reactivity of solid NaO2 is probed further, and NaF is found to be formed through a reaction between the electrochem. generated NaO2 and the electrode binder, polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF).  The instability of cell components in the presence of desired electrochem. reaction products is clearly problematic and bears further investigation.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGpcQ5k3r3w1E7Vg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0liNya2G66Xdxw"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XitFCgsL7P&amp;md5=f682ef8dad015e35d69ff014487f5fc7</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref86"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref86" class="rightTabRefNumLink">86</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit86" data-doi="10.1021/acs.chemrev.1c00662"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Shcherbakov, A. A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Medeiros-Silva, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Tran, N.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Gelenter, M. D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hong, M.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">From Angstroms to Nanometers: Measuring Interatomic Distances by Solid-State NMR</span>. <i>Chem. Rev.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2022</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>122</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">10</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">9848</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">9879</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/acs.chemrev.1c00662</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit86R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">86</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">From Angstroms to Nanometers: Measuring Interatomic Distances by Solid-State NMR</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Shcherbakov, Alexander A.; Medeiros-Silva, Joao; Tran, Nhi; Gelenter, Martin D.; Hong, Mei</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States)</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2022</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">122</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">10</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">9848-9879</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">CHREAY</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0009-2665</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A review.  Internuclear distances represent one of the main structural constraints in mol. structure detn. using solid-state NMR spectroscopy, complementing chem. shifts and orientational restraints.  Although a large no. of magic-angle-spinning (MAS) NMR techniques have been available for distance measurements, traditional 13C and 15N NMR expts. are inherently limited to distances of a few angstroms due to the low gyromagnetic ratios of these nuclei.  Recent development of fast MAS triple-resonance 19F and 1H NMR probes has stimulated the design of MAS NMR expts. that measure distances in the 1-2 nm range with high sensitivity.  This review describes the principles and applications of these multiplexed multidimensional correlation distance NMR expts., with an emphasis on 19F- and 1H-based distance expts.  Representative applications of these long-distance NMR methods to biol. macromols. as well as small mols. are reviewed.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGqNkk-oVFCehrVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0liNya2G66Xdxw"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3MXitlSjsbvN&amp;md5=9b34cd494b05dadec7c18e43ed332c19</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref87"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref87" class="rightTabRefNumLink">87</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit87" data-doi="10.1021/acs.chemmater.5b04408"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Michan, A. L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Leskes, M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Grey, C. P.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Voltage Dependent Solid Electrolyte Interphase Formation in Silicon Electrodes: Monitoring the Formation of Organic Decomposition Products</span>. <i>Chem. Mater.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2016</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>28</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">1</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">385</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">398</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/acs.chemmater.5b04408</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit87R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">87</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Voltage Dependent Solid Electrolyte Interphase Formation in Silicon Electrodes: Monitoring the Formation of Organic Decomposition Products</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Michan, Alison L.; Leskes, Michal; Grey, Clare P.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Chemistry of Materials</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2016</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">28</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">1</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">385-398</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">CMATEX</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0897-4756</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">The solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) passivating layer that grows on all battery electrodes during cycling is crit. to the long-term capacity retention of lithium-ion batteries.  Yet, it is inherently difficult to study because of its nanoscale thickness, amorphous composite structure, and air sensitivity.  Here, we employ an exptl. strategy using 1H, 7Li, 19F, and 13C solid-state NMR (ssNMR) to gain insight into the decompn. products in the SEI formed on silicon electrodes, the uncontrolled growth of the SEI representing a major failure mechanism that prevents the practical use of silicon in lithium-ion batteries.  The voltage dependent formation of the SEI is confirmed, with the SEI growth correlating with irreversible capacity.  By studying both conductive carbon and mixed Si/C composite electrodes sep., a correlation with increased capacity loss of the composite system and the low-voltage silicon plateau is demonstrated.  Using selective 13C labeling, we detect decompn. products of the electrolyte solvents ethylene carbonate (EC) and di-Me carbonate (DMC) independently.  EC decompn. products are present in higher concns. and are dominated by oligomer species.  Lithium semicarbonates, lithium fluoride, and lithium carbonate products are also seen.  Ab initio calcns. have been carried out to aid in the assignment of NMR shifts. ssNMR applied to both rinsed and unrinsed electrodes show that the orgs. are easily rinsed away, suggesting that they are located on the outer layer of the SEI.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGpBEe6q-VLOG7Vg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0liNya2G66Xdxw"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhvVOrt77J&amp;md5=0a011397966da5021fbd00b331eb3687</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref88"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref88" class="rightTabRefNumLink">88</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit88" data-doi="10.1111/j.1551-2916.2009.03468.x"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Xue, X.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kanzaki, M.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Proton Distributions and Hydrogen Bonding in Crystalline and Glassy Hydrous Silicates and Related Inorganic Materials: Insights from High-Resolution Solid-State Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy</span>. <i>J. Am. Ceram. Soc.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2009</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>92</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">12</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">2803</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">2830</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1111/j.1551-2916.2009.03468.x</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit88R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">88</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Proton distributions and hydrogen bonding in crystalline and glassy hydrous silicates and related inorganic materials: insights from high-resolution solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Xue, Xianyu; Kanzaki, Masami</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of the American Ceramic Society</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2009</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">92</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">12</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">2803-2830</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JACTAW</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0002-7820</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Wiley-Blackwell</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A review.  Solid-state 1H NMR spectroscopy has developed into a versatile, high-resoln. method for elucidating the detailed structures of both cryst. and amorphous materials.  Here, we summarize our recent endeavors in applying this method to cryst. and glassy silicates and related inorg. materials.  We first present updated correlations between 1H chem. shift and O···O and H···O distances of O-H···O hydrogen bonds, derived from a comprehensive 1H chem. shift database contg. both original high-quality fast magic angle spinning (MAS) and two-dimensional combined rotation and multiple pulse spectroscopy (CRAMPS)-MAS NMR data and literature MAS NMR data for a large no. of inorg. compds., including phosphates, silicates, (oxy)hydroxides, borates, sulfates, and carbonates.  These correlations may be used to est. hydrogen-bonding distances for inorg. oxide materials of unknown structures.  We then present case studies for the application of high-resoln. two-dimensional 1H CRAMPS-MAS NMR to unravel the order/disorder of proton distributions in cryst. high-pressure hydrous silicates.  Finally, we summarize some of our results on the water speciation in hydrous (alumino)silicate glasses of a range of compns. obtained through comprehensive 1H MAS NMR, and 29Si-1H and 27Al-1H double-resonance NMR expts., and analyze them in the framework of a quasi-chem. model.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGp-ZgvjvuZbMrVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0liNya2G66Xdxw"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhsFCgtb3J&amp;md5=1df62f951143ce32e7eb3ba80c6dd6b5</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref89"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref89" class="rightTabRefNumLink">89</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit89" data-doi="10.1021/acs.jpcc.0c00280"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ajili, W.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Laurent, G. P.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Menguy, N.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Gansmuller, A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Huchette, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Auzoux-Bordenave, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Nassif, N.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Azais, T.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Chemical Heterogeneities within the Disordered Mineral Domains of Aragonite Platelets in Nacre from the European Abalone <i>Haliotis Tuberculata</i></span>. <i>J. Phys. Chem. C</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2020</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>124</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">26</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">14118</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">14130</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/acs.jpcc.0c00280</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit89R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">89</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Chemical heterogeneities within the disordered mineral domains of aragonite platelets in nacre from the European abalone Haliotis tuberculata</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Ajili, Widad; Laurent, Guillaume P.; Menguy, Nicolas; Gansmuller, Axel; Huchette, Sylvain; Auzoux-Bordenave, Stephanie; Nassif, Nadine; Azais, Thierry</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Physical Chemistry C</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2020</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">124</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">26</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">14118-14130</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JPCCCK</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1932-7447</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Since the observation in 2005 of a disordered mineral layer at the surface of aragonite platelets in abalone Haliotis laevigata nacre, the model of the organo-mineral interface in such biomineralized tissue has been challenged.  As a direct interaction between the aragonite cryst. core and the org. matrix is no longer appropriate to describe such interface, a structural description of the disordered mineral domains at the at. level is a key for a comprehensive view of nacre ultrastructure.  We use European abalone Haliotis tuberculata as a model to investigate aragonite nacre through high-resoln. transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) and multinuclear solid state NMR (ssNMR).  The presence of a disordered domain around aragonite crystals is shown through HR-TEM observations similarly to H. laevigata.  The structure and the ionic compn. of the disordered mineral environments of H. tuberculata nacre are investigated through 1H, 13C, 43Ca, and 23Na ssNMR.  Interestingly, we demonstrate that the disordered mineral domains in nacre seem to be heterogeneous in terms of structure and chem. compn. and do not match with amorphous calcium carbonate stricto sensu.  At least 3 different carbonates species are evidenced, including CO32- and HCO3- present in the same mineral domain and closely assocd. with rigid H2O mols.  The local disorder around these ions is found to be inhomogeneous as some CO32- possess an aragonitic environment and are rather ordered (according to the position and line width of their 13C resonance) whereas, in opposition, the chem. environment around HCO3- is highly distributed.  The anal. of potential cations as counterions revealed the presence of disordered Ca2+ and the presence of Na+ closely assocd. with HCO3-.  On the basis of these structural data, we propose an at.-level model for the disordered domains in abalone nacre where the protonation level of carbonate ions, the proportion of sodium ions and the local disorder are increasing from the inner to the outer part of disordered domains.  These results give an unprecedented structural view at the at. scale of such disordered mineral domains in nacre aragonite tablets.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGp3IBaMya73ObVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0liNya2G66Xdxw"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXhtVKqtb7E&amp;md5=a193f0ca7370d865bf1157dea3741d4e</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref90"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref90" class="rightTabRefNumLink">90</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit90" data-doi="10.1038/s41524-018-0064-0"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Wang, A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kadam, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Li, H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Shi, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Qi, Y.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Review on Modeling of the Anode Solid Electrolyte Interphase (SEI) for Lithium-Ion Batteries</span>. <i>npj Comput. Mater.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2018</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>4</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">1</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">15</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1038/s41524-018-0064-0</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord empty" id="
                            rightTab-cas_R
                        "><div class="casContent">There is no corresponding record for this reference.</div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref91"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref91" class="rightTabRefNumLink">91</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit91" data-doi="10.1021/ja305366r"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Shi, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Lu, P.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Liu, Z.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Qi, Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hector, L. G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Li, H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Harris, S. J.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Direct Calculation of Li-Ion Transport in the Solid Electrolyte Interphase</span>. <i>J. Am. Chem. Soc.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2012</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>134</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">37</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">15476</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">15487</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/ja305366r</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit91R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">91</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Direct Calculation of Li-Ion Transport in the Solid Electrolyte Interphase</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Shi, Siqi; Lu, Peng; Liu, Zhongyi; Qi, Yue; Hector, Louis G.; Li, Hong; Harris, Stephen J.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of the American Chemical Society</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2012</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">134</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">37</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">15476-15487</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JACSAT</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0002-7863</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">The mechanism of Li+ transport through the solid electrolyte interphase (SEI), a passivating film on electrode surfaces, has never been clearly elucidated despite its overwhelming importance to Li-ion battery operation and lifetime.  The present paper develops a multiscale theor. methodol. to reveal the mechanism of Li+ transport in a SEI film.  The methodol. incorporates the boundary conditions of the first direct diffusion measurements on a model SEI consisting of porous (outer) org. and dense (inner) inorg. layers (similar to typical SEI films).  New exptl. evidence confirms that the inner layer in the ∼20 nm thick model SEI is primarily cryst. Li2CO3.  Using d. functional theory, we first detd. that the dominant diffusion carrier in Li2CO3 below the voltage range of SEI formation is excess interstitial Li+.  This diffuses via a knock-off mechanism to maintain higher O-coordination, rather than direct-hopping through empty spaces in the Li2CO3 lattice.  Mesoscale diffusion equations were then formulated upon a new two-layer/two-mechanism model: pore diffusion in the outer layer and knock-off diffusion in the inner layer.  This diffusion model predicted the unusual isotope ratio 6Li+/7Li+ profile measured by TOF-SIMS, which increases from the SEI/electrolyte surface and peaks at a depth of 5 nm, and then gradually decreases within the dense layer.  With no fitting parameters, our approach is applicable to model general transport properties, such as ionic cond., for SEI films on the surface of other electrodes, from the at. scale to the mesoscale, as well as aging phenomenon.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGoR_d9LatgDZLVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lhKnyY0oe6pcA"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38Xht1amurfL&amp;md5=ac1c60312a465faa495cad46905ea0a7</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref92"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref92" class="rightTabRefNumLink">92</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit92" data-doi="10.1039/C7EE03122J"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Zhan, C.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Wu, T.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Lu, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Amine, K.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Dissolution, Migration, and Deposition of Transition Metal Ions in Li-Ion Batteries Exemplified by Mn-Based Cathodes-A Critical Review</span>. <i>Energy Environ. Sci.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2018</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>11</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">2</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">243</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">257</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1039/C7EE03122J</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit92R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">92</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Dissolution, migration, and deposition of transition metal ions in Li-ion batteries exemplified by Mn-based cathodes - a critical review</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Zhan, Chun; Wu, Tianpin; Lu, Jun; Amine, Khalil</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Energy &amp; Environmental Science</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2018</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">11</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">2</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">243-257</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">EESNBY</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1754-5706</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Royal Society of Chemistry</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Unlike the revolutionary advances in the anodes of lithium-ion batteries from Li intercalation materials to Li alloy and/or conversion reaction materials, the development of the cathode is still dominated by the Li intercalation compds.  Transition metal ions are essential in these cathodes as the rapid redox reaction centers, and one of the biggest challenges for the TM-based cathodes is the capacity and power fading esp. at an elevated temp., which is directly assocd. with the dissoln.-migration-deposition (DMD) process of TMs from the cathode materials.  This process not only alters the surface structure of the cathode materials, but more importantly, changes the SEI compn. at the anode side.  There is no doubt that the TM-DMD issue should be addressed thoroughly to unlock the potential of these compds. to enable a prolonged battery lifetime.  This review article mainly focuses on research activities with regard to the DMD process in TM-based cathode materials.  In the first four sections, we choose Mn-based cathodes as an example to discuss how Mn DMD relates to the capacity fade of the cell, and what possible approaches might suppress the DMD process by modification of the electrode or electrolyte.  In the fifth section, we discuss the TM DMD process in Ni-, Co-, Fe- and V-contg. cathode materials.  This article reviews the frontier electrochem. research on TM-based cathodes and summarizes the progress and challenges, thereby helping to advance future R&amp;D of LIBs.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGrVn0W4mokKILVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lhKnyY0oe6pcA"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhvFyhurfJ&amp;md5=a91ee6e60f8b6e145a75e19cc76020f9</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref93"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref93" class="rightTabRefNumLink">93</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit93" data-doi="10.1021/acsami.1c15174"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ells, A. W.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">May, R.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Marbella, L. E.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Potassium Fluoride and Carbonate Lead to Cell Failure in Potassium-Ion Batteries</span>. <i>ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2021</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>13</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">45</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">53841</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">53849</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/acsami.1c15174</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord empty" id="
                            rightTab-cas_R
                        "><div class="casContent">There is no corresponding record for this reference.</div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref94"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref94" class="rightTabRefNumLink">94</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit94" data-doi="10.1007/s10904-013-9977-8"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Doeff, M. M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Cabana, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Shirpour, M.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Titanate Anodes for Sodium Ion Batteries</span>. <i>J. Inorg. Organomet. Polym. Mater.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2014</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>24</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">1</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">5</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">14</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1007/s10904-013-9977-8</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit94R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">94</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Titanate Anodes for Sodium Ion Batteries</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Doeff, Marca M.; Cabana, Jordi; Shirpour, Mona</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Inorganic and Organometallic Polymers and Materials</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2014</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">24</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">1</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">5-14</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JIOPAY</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1574-1443</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Springer</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">For reasons of cost and supply security issues, there is growing interest in the development of rechargeable sodium ion batteries, particularly for large-scale grid storage applications.  Like the much better known and technol. important lithium ion analogs, the devices operate by shuttling alkali metal cations between two host materials, which undergo insertion processes at different electrochem. potentials.  A particular challenge for the sodium systems is identification of a suitable anode material due to the fact that sodium does not intercalate into graphite.  Although several alternatives, including disordered carbons and alloys are being investigated, the most promising options at present lie with titanates, not in the least because of attractive characteristics such as low toxicity, ease of synthesis, wide availability, and low cost.  A large variety of sodium titanate compds. can be prepd., many of which have tunnel or layered structures that can readily undergo reversible reductive intercalation reactions.  A brief overview of the phys., structural, and electrochem. characteristics of several of the most promising materials for sodium-ion battery applications is given in this paper, and a comparison is made between the sodium and the lithium insertion behaviors.  For some of these compds., insertion of sodium occurs at unusually low potentials, a feature that has important implications for the design of high-energy sodium-ion systems.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGpE11hLFpfiJ7Vg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lhKnyY0oe6pcA"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhsFalu7nI&amp;md5=72b832199e9b02b97dcddf838ab4d13a</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref95"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref95" class="rightTabRefNumLink">95</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit95" data-doi="10.1039/C6TA04611H"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Mei, Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Huang, Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hu, X.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Nanostructured Ti-Based Anode Materials for Na-Ion Batteries</span>. <i>J. Mater. Chem. A</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2016</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>4</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">31</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">12001</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">12013</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1039/C6TA04611H</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit95R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">95</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Nanostructured Ti-based anode materials for Na-ion batteries</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Mei, Yueni; Huang, Yunhui; Hu, Xianluo</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2016</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">4</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">31</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">12001-12013</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JMCAET</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">2050-7496</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Royal Society of Chemistry</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">With the shortage of fossil energy and global climate change, renewable energy sources offer the most promising solns. to these challenges.  However, the intermittence of energy sources such as solar and wind requires sustainable energy storage technologies.  Nowadays, electrochem. energy storage technologies and applications have attracted much attention, including portable elec. devices, elec. vehicles and smart power grids.  Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have been widely applied in these areas because of their safety, portability and high energy d.  Nevertheless, the resources of lithium are limited and the vast consumption of lithium has pushed up the price of lithium compds., urging people to search for resourceful materials.  Sodium can be a promising alternative due to its high abundance and low cost.  Furthermore, titanium-based materials have become a hot spot for anode materials in sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), with their advantages of high safety and structural stability.  In this review, we summarize the recent advances in Ti-based anode materials for SIB applications.  We highlight the design and engineering of Ti-based nanoarchitectures, esp. emphasizing the effective enhancement in performance and the related sodium storage mechanism.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGpa4N56ebVXIbVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lhKnyY0oe6pcA"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhtVynt73M&amp;md5=40308f2ab8b2beb4f73c5fe67992c973</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref96"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref96" class="rightTabRefNumLink">96</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit96" data-doi="10.1002/aenm.201802175"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Xu, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ding, Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Liu, X.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Zhang, Q.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Wang, K.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Chen, J.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Boosting Potassium Storage Capacity Based on Stress-Induced Size-Dependent Solid-Solution Behavior</span>. <i>Adv. Energy Mater.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2018</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>8</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">32</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">1802175</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1002/aenm.201802175</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord empty" id="
                            rightTab-cas_R
                        "><div class="casContent">There is no corresponding record for this reference.</div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref97"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref97" class="rightTabRefNumLink">97</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit97" data-doi="10.1021/acsami.7b15314"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Dong, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Li, Z.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Xing, Z.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Wu, X.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ji, X.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Zhang, X.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Novel Potassium-Ion Hybrid Capacitor Based on an Anode of K <sub>2</sub> Ti <sub>6</sub> O <sub>13</sub> Microscaffolds</span>. <i>ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2018</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>10</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">18</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">15542</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">15547</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/acsami.7b15314</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit97R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">97</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Novel Potassium-Ion Hybrid Capacitor Based on an Anode of K2Ti6O13 Microscaffolds</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Dong, Shengyang; Li, Zhifei; Xing, Zhenyu; Wu, Xianyong; Ji, Xiulei; Zhang, Xiaogang</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">ACS Applied Materials &amp; Interfaces</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2018</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">10</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">18</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">15542-15547</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">AAMICK</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1944-8244</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">To fill the gap between batteries and supercapacitors requires integration of the following features in a single system: energy d. well above that of supercapacitors, cycle life much longer than Li-ion batteries, and low cost.  Along this line, we report a novel nonaq. potassium-ion hybrid capacitor (KIC) that employs an anode of K2Ti6O13 (KTO) microscaffolds constructed by nanorods and a cathode of N-doped nanoporous graphenic carbon (NGC).  K2Ti6O13 microscaffolds are studied for potential applications as the anode material in potassium-ion storage for the first time.  This material exhibits an excellent capacity retention of 85% after 1000 cycles.  In addn., the NGC//KTO KIC delivers a high energy d. of 58.2 Wh kg-1 based on the active mass in both electrodes, high power d. of 7200 W kg-1, and outstanding cycling stability over 5000 cycles.  The usage of K ions as the anode charge carrier instead of Li ions and the amenable performance of this device suggest that hybrid capacitor devices may welcome a new era of beyond lithium.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGqvQ9aCqnSZDLVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lhKnyY0oe6pcA"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXot1Cit7w%253D&amp;md5=291f44f32bbbe83d705d68d5e690357a</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref98"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref98" class="rightTabRefNumLink">98</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit98" data-doi="10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00463"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hosaka, T.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kubota, K.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hameed, A. S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Komaba, S.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Research Development on K-Ion Batteries</span>. <i>Chem. Rev.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2020</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>120</i></span> (<span class="NLM_issue">14</span>),  <span class="NLM_fpage">6358</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">6466</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00463</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit98R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">98</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Research Development on K-Ion Batteries</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Hosaka, Tomooki; Kubota, Kei; Hameed, A. Shahul; Komaba, Shinichi</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States)</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2020</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">120</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">14</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">6358-6466</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">CHREAY</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0009-2665</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A review.  Li-ion batteries (LIBs), commercialized in 1991, have the highest energy d. among practical secondary batteries and are widely utilized in electronics, elec. vehicles, and even stationary energy storage systems.  Along with the expansion of their demand and application, concern about the resources of Li and Co is growing.  Therefore, secondary batteries composed of earth-abundant elements are desired to complement LIBs.  In recent years, K-ion batteries (KIBs) have attracted significant attention as potential alternatives to LIBs.  Previous studies have developed pos. and neg. electrode materials for KIBs and demonstrated several unique advantages of KIBs over LIBs and Na-ion batteries (NIBs).  Thus, besides being free from any scarce/toxic elements, the low std. electrode potentials of K/K+ electrodes lead to high operation voltages competitive to those obsd. in LIBs.  Moreover, K+ ions exhibit faster ionic diffusion in electrolytes due to weaker interaction with solvents and anions than that of Li+ ions; this is essential to realize high-power KIBs.  This review comprehensively covers the studies on electrochem. materials for KIBs, including electrode and electrolyte materials and a discussion on recent achievements and remaining/emerging issues.  The review also includes insights into electrode reactions and solid-state ionics and nonaq. soln. chem. as well as perspectives on the research-based development of KIBs compared to those of LIBs and NIBs.</div></div><div class="moreSciFi"><a title="Retrieve detailed record, substances, reactions and more for this article from SciFinder ®" href="https://scifinder.cas.org/scifinder/view/link_v1/reference.jsf?l=BmxxGlm8wGoJrb33gTbyWrVg90H21EOLACvtfcHk0lhKnyY0oe6pcA"> &gt;&gt; More from SciFinder <sup>®</sup></a></div><span class="casRefUrl">https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&amp;resolution=options&amp;coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXpt1SktA%253D%253D&amp;md5=5fc9c70fd50f3c11485aa101098b5e22</span></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref99"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref99" class="rightTabRefNumLink">99</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit99"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hope, M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Rinkel, B.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Gunnarsdottir, A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Marker, K.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Menkin, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Paul, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Sergeyev, I.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Grey, C.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">DNP-Enhanced NMR of Lithium Dendrites: Selective Observation of the Solid–Electrolyte Interphase</span>. <i>ChemRxiv</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2019</span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">1</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">33</span></span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="casRecord empty" id="
                            rightTab-cas_R
                        "><div class="casContent">There is no corresponding record for this reference.</div></div></div></div></div></li></ol></li><li id="pane-m3" aria-labelledby="pane-m3" class="tab__pane tab__pane-suppInfo"><h2 class="supp-info-label">Supporting Information</h2><div class="article_supporting-info" id="rightTab-notes1"><div class="article_content-header"><div class="article_content-header-row"><div class="article_content-title" tabindex="0"><h2 id="rightTab-_i25">Supporting Information</h2></div></div></div><hr><p class="last">The Supporting Information is available free of charge at <a href="/doi/10.1021/jacs.4c06823?goto=supporting-info" class="ext-link">https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/jacs.4c06823</a>.</p><ul class="NLM_list-list_type-label" id="silist"><li><p class="inline">Additional materials characterization with XRD, SEM, TEM and electrochemical performance; <sup>23</sup>Na NMR spectra of reference compounds; NMR quantification of sodium and lithium at different SOC; Details on the CASTEP calculations; <sup>1</sup>H MAS DNP spectra obtained in exogenous DNP experiments and enhancement factors of different <sup>23</sup>Na sites obtained in <sup>1</sup>H–<sup>23</sup>Na CP; Images of the cycled ppLTO electrodes; CW EPR X-band spectra; <sup>17</sup>O MAS DNP spectrum of Mn doped cycled ppLTO; <sup>23</sup>Na spectra with deconvolution obtained for various samples with endogenous DNP; XPS depth profiling results (<a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/suppl_file/ja4c06823_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">PDF</a>)</p></li></ul><p></p><div class="supInfoBoxOnFTP "><div class="sup-info-attachments"><ul><li><a class="suppl-anchor" href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/jacs.4c06823/suppl_file/ja4c06823_si_001.pdf">ja4c06823_si_001.pdf (1.19 MB)</a></li></ul></div></div><div id="rightTab-figshare-widget"></div><br><div class="TermsAndConditionsDropzoneRight" data-pb-dropzone="TermsAndConditionsDropzoneRight"><div data-widget-def="UX3HTMLWidget" data-widget-id="b84e6b6c-b4d0-4427-b286-3cf14d52d013" class="mb-4">
        



        
        <h2>Terms &amp; Conditions</h2>
<p>Most electronic Supporting Information files are available without a subscription to ACS Web Editions. Such files may be downloaded by article for research use (if there is a public use license linked to the relevant article, that license may permit other uses). Permission may be obtained from ACS for other uses through requests via the RightsLink permission system:
<a href="/page/copyright/permissions.html" title="RightsLink">http://pubs.acs.org/page/copyright/permissions.html</a>.</p>

        </div></div></div></li></ul></div></div></div></div></article></main>

                    
                        



        
        <script nonce="90f6efc06b5a775c-SJC">
(function(){
	
	/*Event Tracking for RIS menu dropdown - Article pages*/

	$('.cit-download-dropdown_button').on('click',function(e)
	{	
		e.preventDefault();
	    gtag('event', 'Export', { 'event_category': 'Citation', 'event_label':'Main'});

	});


	$('.cit-download-dropdown_content ul li').on('click',function(e)
	{	
	//	e.preventDefault();
	    var idx = $(this).index();
	    
	    var label = '';
	    if (idx === 0 ) {
	    	label = 'Citation';
	    } else if (idx === 1 ) {
	    	label = 'Abstract';
	    } else if (idx === 2 ) {
	    	label = 'Reference';
	    } else if (idx === 3 ) {
	    	label = 'More Options';
	    }
	   
	   gtag('event', 'Export', { 'event_category': 'Citation', 'event_label':label});
	});

	$('.header_contnav-next a').on('click', function(e){
        e.preventDefault();
        gtag('event', 'Top', { 'event_category': 'Article', 'event_label':'Right Arrow'});
	}); 

 	$('.header_contnav-pre a').on('click', function(e){
	    e.preventDefault();
	     gtag('event', 'Top', { 'event_category': 'Article', 'event_label':'Left Arrow'});
	}); 

	$('.share_button').on('click', function(e){
		e.preventDefault();
		gtag('event', 'Top', { 'event_category': 'Article', 'event_label':'Share'});
	});

	$("#pane-m1con").on('click', function(e) {
		e.preventDefault();
		gtag('event', 'Sidebar', { 'event_category': 'Article', 'event_label':'Figures'});
	});

	$("#pane-m2con").on('click', function(e) {
		e.preventDefault();
	    gtag('event', 'Sidebar', { 'event_category': 'Article', 'event_label':'References'});
	});

	$("#pane-m3con").on('click', function(e) {
		e.preventDefault();
		gtag('event', 'Sidebar', { 'event_category': 'Article', 'event_label':'Supporting Info'});
	});

	$('.tab__close').on('click', function(){
		gtag('event', 'Sidebar', { 'event_category': 'Article', 'event_label':'Close'});
	}); 



})();

</script>

<script type="text/javascript" nonce="90f6efc06b5a775c-SJC">
    adroll_adv_id = "3LBZJ4KXKBF2PJ46QCMT3X";
    adroll_pix_id = "6EITYRDI4FFGJPSZQ62UJJ";

    (function () {
        var _onload = function(){
            if (document.readyState && !/loaded|complete/.test(document.readyState)){setTimeout(_onload, 10);return}
            if (!window.__adroll_loaded){__adroll_loaded=true;setTimeout(_onload, 50);return}
            var scr = document.createElement("script");
            var host = (("https:" == document.location.protocol) ? "https://s.adroll.com" : "http://a.adroll.com");
            scr.setAttribute('async', 'true');
            scr.type = "text/javascript";
            scr.src = host + "/j/roundtrip.js";
            ((document.getElementsByTagName('head') || [null])[0] ||
                document.getElementsByTagName('script')[0].parentNode).appendChild(scr);
        };
        if (window.addEventListener) {window.addEventListener('load', _onload, false);}
        else {window.attachEvent('onload', _onload)}
    }());
</script>

    display:block;
    width: 100%;

    margin-top: -1px;
}

        <script nonce="90f6efc06b5a775c-SJC">
// LIT-455776 workaround
// Moving the popup before the header content for tab accessibility
document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', () => {
    const headerNode = $('.header_content');
    const popupNode = $('.pairing-affiliations-popup');

    if (!headerNode.length || !popupNode.length)
        return;

    popupNode.insertBefore(headerNode);  
});
</script>

        <div id="sys-message-panel" style="display: none;">
    <div class="system-message-logo-area"><a id="asterisk"><i class="icon-asterisk"></i></a></div>
    <div class="sys-message-content">
        <a id="closebtn" href="#"><i class="icon-times-circle-o"></i></a>
        <!-- <h2>System Message</h2> -->
        <span class="system-message-date">Sunday, February 09, 2025</span>
        <p>Please be aware that pubs.acs.org is undergoing maintenance from Saturday February 1 to Monday Febraury 3, that may have an impact on your experience. During this time, you may not be able to access certain features like login, purchasing single articles, saving searches or running existing saved searches, modifying your e-Alert preferences, or accessing Librarian administrative functions. We appreciate your patience as we continue to improve the ACS Publications platform.</p>

        <!--<p>We are undergoing maintenance which may impact PDF downloads for some users. This update will complete shortly and we appreciate your patience while we improve the ACS Publications Platform.</p>-->
 
        <!-- <p>On Tuesday, July 23, we will complete an update to our article pages. You may find that some elements are not aligned on these pages while the final work is completed.<br>
            Thank you for your patience.</p> -->
    </div>

<script nonce="90f6efc06b5a775c-SJC">
    document.addEventListener("DOMContentLoaded", function(){
    // Function to get a Human readable formatted date
    function getFormattedDateForMaintenance() {
        let today = new Date();
        let dd = String(today.getDate()).padStart(2, '0');
        //January is 0
        let mm = String(today.getMonth() + 1).padStart(2, '0'); 
        let yyyy = today.getFullYear();
        
        let daysOfWeek = ['Sunday', 'Monday', 'Tuesday', 'Wednesday', 'Thursday', 'Friday', 'Saturday'];
        let monthsOfYear = ['January', 'February', 'March', 'April', 'May', 'June', 'July', 'August', 'September', 'October', 'November', 'December'];

        let dayOfWeek = daysOfWeek[today.getDay()];
        let monthOfYear = monthsOfYear[today.getMonth()];

        return dayOfWeek + ', ' + monthOfYear + ' ' + dd + ', ' + yyyy;
    }
    
    // Insert the date into the .system-message-date element
    document.querySelector('.system-message-date').innerText = getFormattedDateForMaintenance();
});
</script>

                    
                        



        
        <!-- Hotjar Tracking Code for https://pubs.acs.org/ -->
<script nonce="90f6efc06b5a775c-SJC">
    (function(h,o,t,j,a,r){
        h.hj=h.hj||function(){(h.hj.q=h.hj.q||[]).push(arguments)};
        h._hjSettings={hjid:3120009,hjsv:6};
        a=o.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
        r=o.createElement('script');r.async=1;
        r.src=t+h._hjSettings.hjid+j+h._hjSettings.hjsv;
        a.appendChild(r);
    })(window,document,'https://static.hotjar.com/c/hotjar-','.js?sv=');
</script>

    /*margin-right: 14px;*/
    /*float: right;*/
    font-weight: bold;
}
#gdpr-message-btn {
    width: 60px;
    height: 38px;
    background: #4b8fc2;
    border-radius: 4px;
    color: white;
    display: inline-block;
    margin-top: -4px;
    font-size: 12px;
}
a#closebtn {
    float: right;
    color: #d4e5ef;
}
#gdpr-input {
    width: 200px;
    height: 30px;
    border-radius: 3px;
    border-width: 1px;
    box-shadow: none;
    margin-right: 10px;
    font-size: 14px;
    outline: none;

}

    font-size: 15px;
    margin-top: 10px;
}

    height: 160px;
}

	#gdpr-message-content h3 {
		width: 80%;
		text-align: left;
	}
}

<div id="gdpr-message-modal" role="dialog" aria-modal="false" aria-label="cookies policy" tabindex="0">
    <div id="gdpr-message-content">

<script type="text/javascript" nonce="90f6efc06b5a775c-SJC">
"use strict"
//Script checks gdpr cookie and submits form
	/* 
	Create an in-page pop-up message, only for the InfoCentral homepage, that will gather email registrants for the library marketing list.
	 
	Needs the end point
	*/

var infoCentralCapture = (function() {

    //Detect mobile device
    window.mobilecheck = function() {
        var check = false;
        (function(a){if(/(android|bb\d+|meego).+mobile|avantgo|bada\/|blackberry|blazer|compal|elaine|fennec|hiptop|iemobile|ip(hone|od)|iris|kindle|lge |maemo|midp|mmp|mobile.+firefox|netfront|opera m(ob|in)i|palm( os)?|phone|p(ixi|re)\/|plucker|pocket|psp|series(4|6)0|symbian|treo|up\.(browser|link)|vodafone|wap|windows ce|xda|xiino/i.test(a)||/1207|6310|6590|3gso|4thp|50[1-6]i|770s|802s|a wa|abac|ac(er|oo|s\-)|ai(ko|rn)|al(av|ca|co)|amoi|an(ex|ny|yw)|aptu|ar(ch|go)|as(te|us)|attw|au(di|\-m|r |s )|avan|be(ck|ll|nq)|bi(lb|rd)|bl(ac|az)|br(e|v)w|bumb|bw\-(n|u)|c55\/|capi|ccwa|cdm\-|cell|chtm|cldc|cmd\-|co(mp|nd)|craw|da(it|ll|ng)|dbte|dc\-s|devi|dica|dmob|do(c|p)o|ds(12|\-d)|el(49|ai)|em(l2|ul)|er(ic|k0)|esl8|ez([4-7]0|os|wa|ze)|fetc|fly(\-|_)|g1 u|g560|gene|gf\-5|g\-mo|go(\.w|od)|gr(ad|un)|haie|hcit|hd\-(m|p|t)|hei\-|hi(pt|ta)|hp( i|ip)|hs\-c|ht(c(\-| |_|a|g|p|s|t)|tp)|hu(aw|tc)|i\-(20|go|ma)|i230|iac( |\-|\/)|ibro|idea|ig01|ikom|im1k|inno|ipaq|iris|ja(t|v)a|jbro|jemu|jigs|kddi|keji|kgt( |\/)|klon|kpt |kwc\-|kyo(c|k)|le(no|xi)|lg( g|\/(k|l|u)|50|54|\-[a-w])|libw|lynx|m1\-w|m3ga|m50\/|ma(te|ui|xo)|mc(01|21|ca)|m\-cr|me(rc|ri)|mi(o8|oa|ts)|mmef|mo(01|02|bi|de|do|t(\-| |o|v)|zz)|mt(50|p1|v )|mwbp|mywa|n10[0-2]|n20[2-3]|n30(0|2)|n50(0|2|5)|n7(0(0|1)|10)|ne((c|m)\-|on|tf|wf|wg|wt)|nok(6|i)|nzph|o2im|op(ti|wv)|oran|owg1|p800|pan(a|d|t)|pdxg|pg(13|\-([1-8]|c))|phil|pire|pl(ay|uc)|pn\-2|po(ck|rt|se)|prox|psio|pt\-g|qa\-a|qc(07|12|21|32|60|\-[2-7]|i\-)|qtek|r380|r600|raks|rim9|ro(ve|zo)|s55\/|sa(ge|ma|mm|ms|ny|va)|sc(01|h\-|oo|p\-)|sdk\/|se(c(\-|0|1)|47|mc|nd|ri)|sgh\-|shar|sie(\-|m)|sk\-0|sl(45|id)|sm(al|ar|b3|it|t5)|so(ft|ny)|sp(01|h\-|v\-|v )|sy(01|mb)|t2(18|50)|t6(00|10|18)|ta(gt|lk)|tcl\-|tdg\-|tel(i|m)|tim\-|t\-mo|to(pl|sh)|ts(70|m\-|m3|m5)|tx\-9|up(\.b|g1|si)|utst|v400|v750|veri|vi(rg|te)|vk(40|5[0-3]|\-v)|vm40|voda|vulc|vx(52|53|60|61|70|80|81|83|85|98)|w3c(\-| )|webc|whit|wi(g |nc|nw)|wmlb|wonu|x700|yas\-|your|zeto|zte\-/i.test(a.substr(0,4))) check = true;})(navigator.userAgent||navigator.vendor||window.opera);
              return check;
        };

    var _isMobile = window.mobilecheck();
    if (_isMobile) {
        $('#gdpr-message-modal').addClass('mobile');
    }

    var emailValid = "",
        time = 3000,
        btnStatus = true,
        errorStatus = false,
        errormessage = "<p class='gdpr_err'><b>Please Enter a valid email address<b><p>";

    function init() {
        setTimeout(function() {
            var cookieExist = getCookie("gdpr");
            if (cookieExist) {
                //console.log("gdpr cookie exist");
                return false;
            } else {
                //console.log("gdpr cookie does not exist")
                gdprMessage();
            }
            //Events
            $('#closebtn').on("click", hideForm);

            //Handle submit
            $('#gdpr-message-btn').on("click", function(event) {
                handleClick();
            });

            // //Hide if clicked outside div - TO DO stop handling click after submit
            // $(document).click(function(event) {
            // 	event.stopPropagation();
            //   console.log(event.target);
            //   if (!$(event.target).closest("#gdpr-message-content").length) {
            //     $("body").find("#gdpr-message-modal").hide();
            //     $(this).off();
            //   }
            // });
            $('#gdpr-con-btn').click(function() {
                setCookie("gdpr", "true");
                hideForm();
            });
        }, time);
    }

    //Show the message
    function gdprMessage() {
        //console.log("Show GDPR Message");
        var tMessage, emailInput, messageButton, ewrap;

        $('#gdpr-message-modal').show();
    }

    function handleClick() {
        //console.log($("#gdpr-input").val());
        emailValid = validateEmail($("#gdpr-input").val());
        if (emailValid) {
            //Submit the form
            //Hide form
            if ($('.gdpr_err')) {
                $('.gdpr_err').hide();
            }

            $("#gdpr-message-content")
                //If successful then...
            setCookie("gdpr", "true");
            //console.log("emailValid " + emailValid + " submiting form");
        } else {
            //Show error message
            gdprErrorMessage();
            //console.log("emailValid " + emailValid);
        }
    }

    function gdprErrorMessage() {
        if (errorStatus) {
            return false;
        } else {
            errorStatus = true;
            $("#gdpr-message-content").append(errormessage);
        }
    }

    function validateEmail(email) {
        var re = /^(([^<>()\[\]\\.,;:\s@"]+(\.[^<>()\[\]\\.,;:\s@"]+)*)|(".+"))@((\[[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\])|(([a-zA-Z\-0-9]+\.)+[a-zA-Z]{2,}))$/;
        return re.test(String(email).toLowerCase());
    }

    function setCookie(name, value) {
        var expires = "";
        expires = "; expires=Fri, 31 Dec 9999 23:59:59 GMT";
        document.cookie = name + "=" + (value || "") + expires + "; path=/";
    }

    function getCookie(name) {
        var match = document.cookie.match(new RegExp(name + '=([^;]+)'));
        if (match) return match[1];
    }

    function hideForm() { //And set cookie
        $('#gdpr-message-modal').hide();
        setCookie("gdpr", "false");
        gtag('event', 'GDPR Modal', { 'event_category': 'Pubs GDPR', 'event_label':'GDPR Dismissal'});
    }

    return {
        init: init
    }
})();

$(document).ready(infoCentralCapture.init);
</script>


                    
                        



        
        <script nonce="90f6efc06b5a775c-SJC">
var currentJournal = "Journal of the American Chemical Society";
$(".citationLinks > a").click(function(e){
    if($(this).text() === "ACS Full Text ") {
        gtag('event', 'ACS Full Text', { 'event_category': 'Reference _Click', 'event_label':currentJournal});
    }
    else if($(this).text() === "Crossref") {
        gtag('event', 'Crossref', { 'event_category': 'Reference _Click', 'event_label':currentJournal});
    }
    else if($(this).text() === "CAS") {
        gtag('event', 'CAS', { 'event_category': 'Reference _Click', 'event_label':currentJournal});
    }
    else if($(this).text() === "PubMed") {
        gtag('event', 'PubMed', { 'event_category': 'Reference _Click', 'event_label':currentJournal});
    }
    else if($(this).text() === "Google Scholar") {
        gtag('event', 'Google Scholar', { 'event_category': 'Reference _Click', 'event_label':currentJournal});
    }
    else if($(this).hasClass("issue-item_open-url") === true) {
        gtag('event', 'OpenURL', { 'event_category': 'Reference _Click', 'event_label':currentJournal});
    }
});
</script>

                    
                        



        
        <script nonce="90f6efc06b5a775c-SJC">
$(document).ready(function(){
    var cookie = "";
    var uri = "/doi/full/10.1021/html_original_uri?id=123";
    console.log("ACSPubs2 start");
    $.getJSON('https://extreme-ip-lookup.com/json/', function(data, status) {
            if ( status == 'success' ) {
                $.each(data, function(i, field){
                    cookie=cookie.concat(i+' = '+field+" - ");
                });
                
            } else {
                    cookie=status;
            }

            cookie1 = cookie;
            cookie = cookie1 + "; path=/; domain=.acs.org";
            //document.cookie = "ACSPubs2= "+ btoa(cookie) ;
            $.cookie("ACSPubs2", btoa(cookie), {path: '/'}); // Session cookie valid across the entire site.
            //TODO send cookie val to the controller for logging
            console.log("ACSPubs2 success");
    })
    .fail(function(xx, status, err){
        cookie="error: 127.0.0.1";
        //document.cookie = "ACSPubs2= "+ btoa(cookie) ;
        $.cookie("ACSPubs2", btoa(cookie), {path: '/'}); // Session cookie valid across the entire site.
        console.log("ACSPubs2 failed");
        //TODO send cookie val to the controller for logging
    });
});    
</script>
